Again, whether functioning in an ordinary or in a special way the Committee recommends that the Authority be responsible for the collection and assembly of admissible evidence for appropriate civil or criminal court proceedings. The Committee does not perceive successful proceedings as the sole criterion by which to eventually judge the Authority's success. But it does believe that the task of ensuring, either from within its own resources or by supervising and co- ordinating the work of other agencies, that admissable evidence is assembled, will act as a focus for the Authority's activities. It is not incompatible with the task of investigating and compiling intelligence and should be undertaken as a matter of course.
I return to the distinction between ordinary and special functions of the Authority.
Ordinary Functions

Ordinary functions are those which can be undertaken by the Authority of its own volition, independent of Government directive. They should be clearly set out and sufficiently empowered as a direct statutory charter for its activities.
Such ordinary functions would include-
the collection, analysis and dissemination of criminal information and intelligence;
the investigation of 'relevant criminal activity';
to assist such investigation, the creation of task forces comprised of Commonwealth agencies and the co-ordination of task forces consisting of State and Commonwealth agencies;
the making of recommendations for law reform.

The carrying out of these functions would enable the Authority to get a long way down the track without specific governmental initiative or intervention, and would represent a considerable advance on the present Bill.

The Committee was most concerned at the apparent lack of co-operation between the Government agencies in the provision of information relevant to combatting organised crime. The Authority would be severely impaired if this intolerable situation were to continue.
The Committee therefore recommends:
The Bill should be amended to empower the Authority to require the transfer to it of information held by any other Commonwealth agency;

that the various secrecy provisions in Commonwealth legislation preventing the disclosure of information held by Commonwealth agencies should be overcome by the secrecy provision governing the Authority;

the Bill should be redrafted to provide for the Authority, in exercising its ordinary functions and powers, to receive from the Commissioner of Taxation information relevant to taxation or tax-related offences;

the Bill should be redrafted to provide the Authority with the power necessary to enter into arrangements with State instrumentalities private institutions and persons to receive information from them.
Special Functions

Special Functions embrace a range of coercive powers whereby the Authority will be able to compel persons to assist in its investigations. The Committee recommends that such coercive powers should only be exercisable under a term of reference granted by Government. It would be salutary for the Authority to be constrained to articulate reasons for wishing to exercise extraordinary powers, and salutary for governments to have to take responsibility for permitting such exercise.

The major special functions and powers with which the Committee deals are the powers to compel the attendance of persons to give evidence and the power to compel the answering of questions or the production of documents. Its recommendations have been designed to advance the ability of the Authority to gather and assemble admissable evidence.
Passports

Thus, concerning the attendance of witnesses, the Committee endorses the Bill's provision for the delivery up of passports, but further recommends that the Authority should be empowered to apply to a judicial officer for an order to arrest a person where there are reasonable grounds for believing that the person is about to leave Australia to avoid giving evidence to the Authority.
Summons to Appear

The Committee also consider it sufficient that the summons to appear should set out the notice describing the terms of reference given under Clauses 11 and 12 without the need to set out the general nature of any line of questioning.
Search Warrants

In relation to search warrants, the Committee is anxious that material not be tampered with or destroyed which may be the case if normal ''notice to produce'' procedures were employed in some circumstances. The Committee endorses the general tenor of the provision requiring application to a judge for a search warrant where such loss of evidence is likely, but it considers the requirement that the evidentiary material which the Authority seeks to seize be on the premises in the 24 hours following the issue of the warrant is unnecessarily limiting.

It should be sufficient that the Authority have reasonable grounds for suspecting that at that time, or some definite future time within the one month life of the warrant, the evidence is likely to be in a particular place.
The Compelling of Answers and Documents

In relation to compelling the answering of questions or the producing of documentary materials the Committee's recommendations were much influenced by the desire to enable the Authority to ''follow the money trail'' either without hindrance altogether, or in a way which allowed as much of the evidence as possible to be admitted in later court proceedings. Documents evidencing property or financial transactions assume particular importance in this regard.
Legal Professional Privilege

For that reason, for example, the Committee recognises the claim of legal professional privilege but only in the narrowest understanding as set down in the recent High Court decisions in Baker v. Campbell and Grant v. Downs. These confine the privilege to communications brought into existence for the sole purpose of their being submitted to a legal adviser for advice; or for the sole purpose of their use in existing or anticipated legal proceedings.
Self-Incrimination

In its endeavour to ensure that effective court proceedings could be taken on the basis of admissible evidence, the Committee was conscious of the strictures of the common law courts that the right to refuse to answer questions or produce documents on the grounds of self-incrimination is not to be abrogated, except by express terms and then generally in a way which does not allow self- incriminatory evidence to be used against the person compelled to give such evidence.
The Committee deliberated at length on the balance to be struck. In the end the regime proposed:
(1) does not acknowledge any claim to the privilege made by corporations;

(2) does not acknowledge any inhibition on the use of compelled evidence in civil proceedings. This is particularly important in stemming the cash flow, or confiscating the assets, of criminal organisations;
(3) in prosecutions for an offence (criminal proceedings)

(a) does not acknowledge any claim to the privilege in relation to records of a business or financial institution. These documents, so essential to the following of the money trail, can be freely used as admissible evidence against any person including the (natural) person compelled to make them available to the Authority;

(b) acknowledges the force of a person's claim to the privilege to remain silent on the grounds that certain oral testimony or documents (other than 3a) may tend to incriminate him. The Committee recommends that the claim be abrogated or over-ridden, but the compelled answer or document, or evidence derived from it, should not be available as evidence in criminal proceedings against the person compelled to give such evidence. Of course, the evidence is available against that person in civil proceedings, and against any other person in any court proceedings;

(4) recommends that the grant of an indemnity in return for compelling self- incrimating answers or documents (to be known as a ''use-derivative use indemnity'') should be granted by the Authority and not by the Attorney-General as presently provided in the Bill.

In comparison with the Bill, these recommendations narrow the range of compelled evidence in relation to which the privilege can be claimed (see 3 (a)) but strengthen the indemnity offered to a person in the instance where the claim is recognised but abrogated.

The Committee believes it has struck the right balance and is particularly mindful of evidence received which suggested that such recommendations would not lead to the loss of admissible evidence against major targets. In fact, we believe that we have enhanced the possibility of furnishing such evidence in criminal prosecutions.
Taxation Records

The Committee considers that the Authority should have speedy access to the fullest range of taxation records relevant to its enquiries under its terms of reference. The National Crime Authority (Consequental Amendments) Bill sets out a cumbersome procedure requiring an order of a judge of the Federal Court who is required to give attention to criteria much more restrictive than is the case with designated Royal Commissions, many other Commonwealth agencies (and State and P.N.G. tax departments), who have ready access to tax records for the purpose of administering laws for which they are responsible. The Committee recommends similar access in the case of the Authority and considers that information derived from the handing over of such records ought be available for use in preparing court proceedings.
The Inter-Governmental Committee

It is desirable to have a body which represents the range of Governments throughout the Federation whose co-operation at a practical level will be of great assistance to the Authority. The constitutional reality of State and Commonwealth jurisdictions must also be recognised.

The Committee has therefore accepted the need for an Inter-Governmental Committee (consisting of the Commonwealth and participating States) but has greatly reduced those occasions on which it can exercise a decisive influence on the Authority's activities.

Thus, if this Committee's recommendations on ordinary functions are accepted, the I.G.C. loses the ability to frustrate a line of enquiry or impede the gathering of evidence by non coercive means. The Authority can go a long way without directive from, or dependence on, the I.G.C.
Granting of a Reference

It is desirable that the Authority be required to justify, and governments be prepared to accept the responsibility for, the exercise of special functions. This should be expressed in the granting of terms of reference.

But possibly the greatest defect in the Bill is contained in Clause 9 (3) which allows one member of the I.G.C. to veto the whole resolution approving a term of reference, rather than merely that portion of it over which the Government exercising the veto has jurisdiction. The latter cannot be prevented as it is constitutionally required that the Commonwealth or relevant State confer coercive powers in relation to the investigation of offences in their respective jurisdiction.

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth be able to grant the Authority a reference relating to relevant criminal activity offending Commonwealth laws without the concurrence of the I.G.C. This is constitutionally sound and recognises the practical point that the Authority is Commonwealth established and funded.

In those matters which involve a breach of State law occurring wholely within a State, the Committee recognises the constitutional need for the State Minister, sufficiently empowered by State law, to put the reference before the I.G.C. for its approval so as to confer coercive powers on the Authority. In that sense only does the Committee recognise a veto power existing within a State.

In cases of mixed references, that is those involving Commonwealth and State jurisdictions and laws, clause 9 (3) should be amended to provide that any State veto is limited to that portion of the reference which falls wholly within its jurisdiction in the sense explained above. The reference must remain alive in relation to the jurisdictions of either the Commonwealth or such other States which wish to grant a reference. In summary, the resolution approving the reference must not wholly founder because of a veto exercised by one particular Government.
Withdrawal of a Reference

To prevent the frustration of the use of coercive powers by the withdrawal of a reference part way through an investigation the Committee recommends in the case of the Commonwealth that such withdrawal only take place on the affirmative resolution of both Houses of Parliament. This enables the early termination of coercive powers where the Government can demonstrate good reason, yet lessens the chance of an inquiry being truncated for unscrupulous reasons. Commonwealth legislation cannot prohibit the State withdrawal of its portion of a reference.
Duplication of Police Enquiries

A matter of concern related to the requirement that the I.G.C. not approve a reference to the Authority unless satisfied that ordinary police methods of investigation were not likely to be effective. Whilst agreeing with the need to avoid duplication of effort which could be undertaken by existing agencies, the Committee considers that the present Bill requires a judgment which could be speculative and premature. It therefore recommends that before approving a reference to the Authority, the I.G.C. shall take into account whether ordinary police methods of investigation into the matter are likely to be effective.
Seeking of a Reference by the Authority

The Authority should be expressly empowered to approach the I.G.C. in order argue the case for a reference. If the Committee's recommendations as to ordinary functions are accepted the Authority will have undertaken considerable investigations before concluding that terms of reference are necessary. The results of such investigation can be laid before the I.G.C. If the request is rejected the Authority should only be entitled to report such rejection in its annual report if it is satisfied that to do so would not prejudice the reputation or safety or fair trial of any person or the operations of law enforcement agencies.
Publicity
A major issue requiring resolution by the Committee was that of the publicity which ought to attach to the work of the Authority, particularly in its hearings .
Private Hearings

The Committee acknowledges the concern of the Bill to prevent disclosure to the public of the indentity of persons whose reputation, safety or fair trial might be at stake. The Bill vests power in the Authority to hold private hearings where such matters are imperilled. The Committee has concluded that such protection should be more fully assured and recommends that all hearings should be conducted in private out of the public gaze. Of course, a person summonsed to appear before the Authority should be entitled to representation by legal counsel.

It is the task of the Authority, inter alia, to gather and assemble admissible evidence and to present such evidence to the appropriate body to decide whether to undertake civil proceedings or prosecutions (such as the Director of Public Prosecutions). The Committee's recommendations on privacy of hearings would emphasise this preliminary role of the Authority, and would render its activities in carrying out investigations and gathering evidence more akin to those of the grand jury and ordinary police investigations rather than the Royal Commission.

In those cases where a public airing of allegations of criminal or corrupt activity seems desirable at both the hearing and reporting stages, the Committee believes that the traditional machinery of the Royal Commission is appropriate. But the Authority should not be structured or empowered to undertake this role.
Public Sittings

Nevertheless, there is a very important role for the Authority in educating and alerting the public to the nature and scope of relevant criminal activity in Australia. This could be undertaken by the issuing of special bulletins, but the Committee also recommends that public sittings of the Authority be held during which the members of the Authority could, for example, detail a fraudulent tax evasion scheme of which it has become aware. Public sittings will also be appropriate and useful for the carrying out of the Authority's function under clause 10 (e) of the Bill, concerning reform of the law relating to relevant offences, reform of administrative practices and reform of administration of the courts in relation to trials of relevant offences.
Defamation

Should the Government not accept this preference of the Committee for a grand jury type role to be assumed by the Authority in conducting its hearings in private, the Committee recommends that the traditional defence available to reports of similar proceedings be available to the media in any action for defamation based on a report of a public hearing.

The Committee does not consider it appropriate that the defence of fair and accurate report of proceedings be stripped from defendants as proposed by the Bill. The Government should await a more comprehensive resolution of the issues as being undertaken by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.
Prior Statements

Whilst all hearings should be held in private, any such evidence can be available for subsequent court proceedings (subject to the privilege against self-incrimination). However, the Authority may give a person an undertaking that evidence given will be held in strictest confidence and not made available in litigation. The Committee clearly perceived the value of such an undertaking in encouraging the disclosure of information. Against this, it had to balance the right of an accused person in a criminal trial to have access to prior statements of a witness in order to probe for inconsistencies, perjury and such like.

If Mr Justice Anderson is a recent unreported judgment in the Supreme Court of Victoria is correct, the common law requires the automatic overriding of any claim that evidence was given to an authority in deepest confidence. The Committee does not agree that the common law situation should be maintained and recommends that when the Authority has ordered that evidence be held in confidence, a trial judge may, in his discretion if he considers that a finding as to the guilt or innocence of the accused may turn on that evidence, direct the Authority to make the evidence available.
Structure of the Authority

It was clear to the Committee that the composition of the Authority will be crucial to its likely efficacy and public acceptance. The integrity of the Authority's members will be the primary safeguard against the abuse of power and , unless the community is convinced of such integrity, it may be expected that support for the Authority will waver.

The Committee accepts the method of appointment of Members of the Authority set out in the Bill. However, it disagrees with the provision for a maximum two year term with the possibility of renewal of a further two years. Whilst acknowledging the opportunity thereby given for ministerial responsibility to be exercised, the Committee is conscious that renewal of the term may become a matter of political influence.

It recommends four-year terms for the members of the National Crime Authority with no provision for renewal. Provision should also be made upon the Authority' s establishment to stagger the terms of office of members so as to enable continuity of experience and leadership.

Finally, if members were to sit alone, the possibility of inconsistencies in method and approach would be very real. This would be accentuated if members were informally alloted different geographical jurisdictions. Such differences could have adverse consequences for those subject to the Authority's coercive powers and could lead to a loss of the Authority's credibility. It is therefore recommended that, when conducting hearings, the Authority should be constituted by at least two members.
Accountability of the Authority

The Bills propose to establish a quite new and exceptional body within the Australian community. In being responsible for its creation, the Parliament will need to be satisfied that the Authority will not stray beyond a limited and acceptable role. There are several provisions in the Bill intended to render the Authority accountable for its actions.
Judicial Audit

The Bill provides for a 3-yearly judicial audit of the operation of the Authority to determine its efficiency and whether it has acted illegally or in a way detrimental to rights and liberties of individuals.

The Committee was not convinced that this review could actually be successfully undertaken. Not only would the task of examining the Authority's activity be enormous, but a more immediate method of remedying grievances should operate. In short, the provision for judicial audit is illusory and should be deleted from the Bill.
Ombudsman

Much the same argument as was put concerning the effective and timely work of the judicial auditor was put concerning the calling in of the Ombudsman by an aggrieved person. But additionally, evidence was given of the likely disruptive role of the Ombudsman in the day-to-day work of the Authority. The Committee concluded that provision for the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman to be extended to the Authority should be deleted.
Parliamentary Scrutiny

The Committee believes that the ordinary operation of the parliamentary system, particularly the consideration of, and deliberation on, the annual report of the Authority, provides adequate opportunity for scrutiny of its activities and the overall achievement of its goal.

The Committee makes several recommendations which would make the annual report a more useful document, for example requiring the compiling of statistics on relevant criminal activity in a manner not heretofore undertaken, and in outlining actions and decisions in the courts, arising out of disputes between the Authority and persons caught up in its activities.

These ordinary operations of the parliamenstary system are to be preferred to a permanent parliamentary committee, not only because it is improbable that it would achieve a level of detailed awareness such as the public might expect of it, but because it could also be drawn into the ethos of the Authority from continuous contact with it.
Ministerial Responsibility

Whilst acknowledging that the relevant Ministers should be able to issue guidelines to, and be informed of the activities of the Authority, the Committee recommends that the Bill should be amended to make it clear that, in furnishing guidelines or giving directions to the Authority, a Minister is precluded from doing so in relation to a particular case. In addition, the Minister should be required to table a copy of any directions or guidelines in Parliament within 15 sitting days of their publication in the Gazette. The Committee further recommends that the Bill should be amended to prevent Commonwealth or State Ministers from requiring to provide information concerning a specific matter in relation to its operations, where the provision of such information could prejudice the safety, or reputation or fair trial of a person, or the operations of law enforcement agencies.
Review by the Courts

The Committee is attracted to the proposal that a means should be provided for a person aggrieved by some action of the Authority, especially in the exercise of coercive powers, to obtain an appropriate remedy by speedy judicial process. Existing procedures, especially under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, were said to be slow and could be abused by those wishing to hinder the Authority's operations.

To enable speedy resolution of a grievance, the Committee recommends that a person be entitled to make summary application for remedy to a judge of the Federal Court or a State Supreme Court. The immediate determination of a matter in issue between the Authority and a person is preferable to the processes provided under the present Bill.
Conclusion

Mr President, I believe that the Committee has discharged the task given it by the Senate in a comprehensive and rigorous manner. It has made sensible recommendations which will enable the Government, if it is so minded, to bring into this Chamber a much improved legislative framework upon which to establish the new body required to aid the suppression of organised crime and official corruption in Australia.

I finally wish to extend my appreciation to my colleagues on the Committee, who have supported me through a difficult task under inordinate time constraints. The report is the outcome of their deliberations, and at times, their forebearance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporated with the tabled report, is a substantial minority report by me. I think that is incorporated in the motion that the report be printed which has already been moved. I seek leave to table and to have incorporated in Hansard a summary statement by me on the tabling of the minority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the investigation into the national crime authority legislation 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

SUMMARY STATEMENT BY SENATOR ALAN MISSEN ON THE TABLING OF THE MINORITY REPORT TO THE SENATE CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS COMMITTEE INVESTIGATION INTO THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY LEGISLATION 1983

There is common agreement between all members of the Committee that the Attorney-General's proposed National Crime Authority Bill 1983, and accompanying legislation, is in various areas highly deficient. As presently drafted it will not achieve the effective fulfilment of ''the objective of investigating organized crime and official corruption'', the subject of this Committee's inquiry.

Substantial evidence before the Committee, contained in public Hansards, has disclosed many weaknesses in the legislation which is the product of disjointed and unsound compromises between many conflicting interests. The growing and alarming ramifications of organized crime in Australia call for stringent efforts and the proposed legislation gives no promise of success in suppressing organized crime and corruption; indeed as a successor to the Costigan Royal Commission, it will clearly fall far short of its successful operation. To proceed to establish a Commission with the present defects, would mislead the public and ill serve this nation. The Australian people, already facing the dangers and costs of organized crime, are entitled to expect their legislators to produce a workable Crime Commission and to accept national responsibilities. They are not bound by the misjudgments of the Commonealth Attorney-General and his abject surrender to the demands of certain State Governments and civil liberties organizations.

The Senate Committee has, in its Majority Report usefully analysed these weaknesses but, in my opinion, has settled for soft options and partial remedies that should not satisfy the Australian people. It would create a ramshackle, ineffective body.

Consequently I have advanced specific additional remedies to cover such deficencies. They relate mainly to the recommended establishment of an Australian Crime Commission which has widely expressed purposes and functions, and operates with sufficient powers of information gathering, surveillance and collecton of evidence to the point of prosecution, and is backed by necessary coercive powers to produce results akin to the Costigan Commission, but over a wider field of organized crime. It must be freed from the obstructions and '' veto'' powers residing in an Inter-Governmental Committee, be able to require answers from witnesses and acquire documents without excessive resort to defences of ''self incrimination'' and rights to indemnity. It must be enabled to inform the public through the right of public hearings where required. The Commission must be appointed by methods that guarantee fearless and highly competent Commissioners and staff and its work should be carefully monitored by a permanent Joint Parliamentary Committee. My recommendations are backed by the best evidence available to the Senate Committee. The existing Act, the National Crimes Commission Act 1982, must not be repealed unless its substitute is legislation of unquestioned utility-and not a sham and delusion.

The details of these proposals are set out clearly in the Minority Report which I have the honour to present today. The conclusions to that Minority Report, which summarise its contents, are annexed to this Press release.
I am available to discuss any aspects of the Committee inquiry and recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Peter Rae proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The deception of the Australian community by the Prime Minister on the prospects he had secured for Australia's steel and beef industries on his recent Asian visit.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance for discussion by the Senate reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The deception of the Australian community by the Prime Minister on the prospects he had secured for Australia's steel and beef industries on his recent Asian visit.

The visit to which I refer took place in February this year. The countries which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visited included Japan and China, along with a number of other countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations. I wish to refer particularly to Japan and China.

The Prime Minister, during his visit to Japan, dramatically announced-my colleague Senator Scott will develop the consequences of this matter in more detail-the agreement which he had been able to obtain from the Japanese Prime Minister guaranteeing the position of Australian beef exports to that country. This is a matter of great importance to the beef industry, which has already been under substantial strain in relation to export markets. It is a matter of considerable importance to a large and significant industry in Australia. This agreement was denied by the Japanese Prime Minister after it was announced by Mr Hawke who, apparently not being prepared to learn from the first mistake of claiming agreements which had not been entered into, went to China. We are told, and have no reason not to believe as it has certainly not been denied, that during the flight to Peking someone-there have even been suggestions as to who it was-brought up the idea that one of the matters that could be discussed by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, with Mr Zhao in China was the resumption of steel imports.

There is a history in relation to that matter. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd had installed and built at very considerable expense a plant at Kwinana in Western Australia which was used for the export of steel to China. That plant was closed in 1981 as a result of the refusal of the Chinese to continue with the purchase of Australian steel, because they had reached the stage of becoming a steel exporter and no longer required to import steel for their purposes. They therefore caused Australia a very substantial loss, because one of its major companies and a major employer was forced to close down the Kwinana plant, forced to lose the value of that investment and place it on hold because no other market was able to be found. It is important to note that no other market was able to be found, because around the world in the past three years there has been a most dramatic oversupply of steel. The world has seen horrific employment problems created as a result of the downturn in the demand for steel and the overproduction as a result of the building of a capacity in various countries which meant that world capacity was way beyond world demand. So, not unnaturally , there have been problems so far as BHP is concerned, not only with its Kwinana plant but with its plants in New South Wales and South Australia.

However, the Prime Minister, with great trumpeting of success, claimed that he had reached this agreement with the Chinese that the Chinese would not only go back on what they had done in 1981 but that they would be taking a very large part of their total requirements from Australia and that there would be a major new development. I quote from the Age newspaper of Friday 10 February, in which it is reported from Peking that:
Mr Hawke's dramatic announcement about the potential for big crude steel exports to China comes at a most unlikely time in the planning of steel production in China.

Rather than promote a rapid expansion in steel making and related heavy industry, the priority of China's economists recently has been trying to rein in unrestrained capital construction and correct a bias of heavy industry over light, consumer-oriented industry.
The report goes on to make other points. It says:
For this reason, the official agreed, it would probably be more than a decade before any substantial sales could be made by Australia.
That is a report of as early as 10 February. We then find Michelle Grattan reporting from China, as reported in the Age of 13 February. She said:

If his Asian trip is any guide, Bob Hawke could be in danger of succumbing as Prime Minister to a weakness he displayed as ACTU president. In those days, he used to outline grand schemes for enterprises and activities that the ACTU could enter. Some of his plans succeeded, but others had to be abandoned or greatly scaled down.
As I shall show shortly, the success rate was abysmal. What Michelle Grattan said was:

When Mr Hawke stood in the foyer of the Fragrant Hills Hotel near Peking last Friday, painting a glowing picture of the potential for the Australian steel industry, one was uncannily reminded of some of those earlier high hopes.
She went on to say:
The Prime Minister has staked a lot more of his credibility on the steel plan. He has talked it up with very little reservation.
Later she said:
But few in the industry or in Government departments believe Mr Hawke's feet are touching the ground when he talks about doubling Australia's raw steel output by the end of the century.

Some of the most significant people who do not believe it are the directors of BHP, as Mr Loton, Mr Laver and Mr Rice have in recent times made so clear. They have pointed to the absurdity of the idea of anyone, at a time of world oversupply, investing the $7 billion in current dollar terms which would be necessary for the doubling, when they have just had to go through a major restructuring, and when one of the few points at which the Government can look with some pride of achievement in the past 12 months has been a plan to restructure the steel industry to overcome some of the problems and to provide some preservation of employment opportunity.

But oh no. Not recognising any of the reality of this, Mr Hawke retorted in a way which could be regarded only as petulant when he said: 'If BHP is not interested, there are other fish in the sea'. None of the other fish has come very far out of the sea so far. There is talk about Conzinc Riotinto of Australia, but I would imagine that CRA has the same sort of view towards investment as do most of those in charge of investment around the boardrooms of Australia today-that is, that this is not a time when major investment is being anticipated. In fact, as the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed just last week, the anticipated investment in the next financial year will show a drop of 15 per cent, which will follow a drop of 15 per cent in the current year.

We find such glowing situations reported further in the Press, as in the Age of 16 February 1984, when the Minister at the table, Senator Button, was photographed welcoming home to Canberra the Prime Minister. I am not quite sure what Senator Button was thinking at the time, but I can imagine that he might have liked to be consulted a little more than perhaps he was and a little earlier than perhaps he was in relation to the matters which were discussed and announced. I would not feel it at all improper if he were to confirm that that was the feeling that he had when he was photographed greeting the Prime Minister . The report stated:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, returned last night from his 18-day visit to Asia with detailed work on his plans for the steel industry and regional trade talks high on the Government's agenda.

If the preparation with the Department responsible, that is, Senator Button's Department, and Senator Button as the responsible Minister had been as detailed as it was with the major company involved-that is, a somewhat casual telephone call the evening before the announcement-one imagines that Senator Button would have some justification for feeling as the Age stated, namely, that although Mr Hawke is obviously pleased with the outcome of the trip, which received good publicity at home Senator Button would wonder how long that good publicity was going to last. Of course what has happened now is that the reality of the situation has fallen down around the ears of this Government. It has been demonstrated to be a government which puts more emphasis upon the glib statement , as Mr Hawke has had a history of doing, than upon checking the facts and making things work.

TALK.START.PARA: —It made this economy work better than you ever did in seven years.

—I thank the Minister for his comment. Let me look at it and see how it goes. What happened? The drought broke, and not even the Prime Minister claims the full credit for the breaking of the drought. The international recovery took place, and not even the Prime Minister can claim the full credit for that. The wages pause had given Australia an opportunity for a break in inflation and some encouragement for investment and, as soon as the drought broke, there was a significant upturn in manufacturing industry and in the use of the capacity of that industry. That has lasted for a temporary period whilst the lull caused by the drought was caught up. However, the fear that has been induced in the board rooms of Australia is what is the real test. That is what is causing the real concern, not the talkup, not the Hawkespeak; but the real investment decisions that have been made show the lack of confidence. It is one thing for the Prime Minister to rate a little below Hoges as a popular television star but it is another thing for people to have confidence in the capacity of his Government to manage the economy of this country in a way which will lead to the successful outcome of investments being undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me demonstrate what sort of Prime Minister we have. When he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in November 1973 he suggested to the Whitlam Government that the Federal Government should break an election promise and increase income taxes. Mr Hawke said that Mr Whitlam's Government had made a mistake in making the promise and should not consider itself bound by it. In other words, if one later finds the promises that one made and upon which one was elected do not appear to be promises that will suit, one breaks them. That, of course, is the record of this Government. It campaigned throughout the period leading to the 5 March election last year on the basis that it would manage the economy in what can be shorthandedly described as a Mitterrand phase one manner. The day after the Government took office if changed to Mitterrand phase two or Hawke phase two, whichever way one likes to put it; however it did not implement the plan on which it campaigned which it stated that it would implement. Let us look at the reputation which Mr Hawke has in some sections of the media. On 20 May 1980 the Melbourne Herald, in an editorial, stated:

Mr Robert Hawke, present ACTU president, future Labor MHR and putative Prime Minister, has been party to the banning of normal newspaper cover of the ACTU's five-day Executive meeting in Hobart. . . .
As one concerned with liberty, truth and freedom of information, it might have been expected that Mr Hawke would have assured the ACTU Executive did not pursue this stupid line.

The truth, which Mr Hawke will not accept, is that today's businessman, as opposed to the gold-watch-chained, morning-coated, top-hatted figure of cartoon fun, is a hard-working (hard-headed too) man who knows the world of money, materials and manpower better than the ACTU.

The Herald then had no faith in Mr Hawke; it would have less faith now. It had no faith in his judgment as opposed to the judgment of the people who make the investment decisions in Australia. It had no faith in his attitude towards rights and liberties of citizens. What has happened with this Government is that every time there is a challenge, every time there is any criticism, there is an almost fanatical response. There is a response which leads to Mr Hawke, as he did in the past couple of weeks, severely criticising the Australian Broadcasting Corporation because it had dared to mention one critical word. How sensitive can one be if that is the problem. I will quote something of the great record of the Prime Minister as a businessman and propounder of great and wonderful ideas. The article stated:
When he was elected to the ACTU presidency in September, of 1969-
I am reading an article from the National Times for the week ending 6 October 1979-

Bob Hawke was painted as the union movement's 'new Messiah.' Yet a comparison of his pace-setting ideas in the 1960s with his actual achievements as union leader suggests that while Hawke is the most popular political figure in the country, he has not achieved all of his aims for the unions.
The article listed the unions. It stated:
The hire-purchase company. In 1969 Hawke said that 'the ACTU' should work for a national trade-union hire purchase company . . .
Early plans were shelved, and no company has been established.

The article mentioned an insurance company which did not get under way. There was going to be a retail store. Everybody knows the story of the retail store and what happened to Bourke's and what sorts of losses it made. What an absolutely disastrous venture that turned out to be for the ACTU. After losing $ 276,000 in the year, it decided that it would close it up and get out. It could not run it because it did not have the capacity to run it. The housing finance company, which Mr Hawke was going to have as a non-profit company, would lighten the burden on people by providing finance at much lower interest rates. That is the same man who, a couple of years later, was trying to tell the Whitlam Government to put up interest rates to cure inflation. He said that in November 1973. No action was taken on the finance company. The consumer credit scheme never got off the ground.

Let us look at what happened with ACTU Solo, with the travel company and the rest of the things the great man was going to introduce. This man is the same man who overstated totally his achievements on his Asian tour, who overstated totally the arrangement, possibility and reality of the agreement with China about steel, who overstated entirely what had been the arrangement and the reality of any discussion with the Japanese Government in relation to beef. In other words, the manic pursuit of popularity, which seems to absolutely overwhelm this man's judgment, is the only objective in his continued holding of the prime ministerial office. This is not for the good of the country, not for the good of the people of Australia, not even for the good of the Party, but for the position of the rating of Bob Hawke, the entertainer.

I think it is disastrous that we should find ourselves in the situation where all that has happened is deferral of decision after decision by the Hawke Government as it ensures that it does not do anything which might upset the plans and wake up the people of Australia to what is really going on or not going on in this country. The cat was let out of the bag very well in the Mercury newspaper of Monday, 30 April, when it stated:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, has told his ministers to avoid, or postpone, controversial matters until after the federal election, tentatively planned for December.

That is what is happening. It is abundantly clear that no decisions are being taken. The hard decisions are being deferred either because the Government has not got the capacity or the will to be able to make the hard decisions or, alternatively, it has not got the intention of making any hard decisions which might cause any recognition of the reality of what this Government's lack of achievement has been. Trouble is impending both in economic terms and in every other way as we look to the year 1985. The Australian Merchant Bankers Association summed it up very well when it estimated that in 1985 this country will see an increase in inflation back to 10 per cent and an increase in unemployment back to a similar figure. What is happening is that we are being crucified as a country in the interests of the man who believes himself to be the great trade negotiator but who is a demonstrable failure-the great businessman who was a demonstrable failure, the great conciliator who has more industrial strife in Australia at the moment than we have had for years, the greatest economic planner who has a disastrous economy predicted for next year and the greatest confidence trickster who is rushing us to an early election. That is what is a matter of public importance. That is what this matter is about . We believe that it should go further than just a matter of public importance. There should be public recognition by all Australians that there was a deliberate deception by this Prime Minister in relation to his claims of achievement during his Asian tour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: — Listening to Senator Peter Rae one gets the impression that he is critical of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), indeed that he perhaps even does not like him and might belong to that 26 per cent who fall into that category. One would have thought that in a matter of public importance dealing with steel and beef negotiations overseas one would not have thought it necessary to support that argument by reference to articles in the National Times of March 1979 and in the Melbourne Herald of 1980 to events which took place in 1969 which have nothing to do with beef or steel which are allegedly the subject of the matter of public importance. One would have thought that if the Opposition spokesman on industry and commerce wanted to make allegations about the question of levels of industrial unrest in Australia in 1984 he might have gone to some trouble to substantiate them. It is quite clear to me why he did not.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Peter Rae goes out on the hustings in the election which he keeps talking about and tells the people of Australia that in his view the level of industrial disputation has increased in the last 12 months they will begin to wonder about the honourable senator because they know what is going on. They know what is going on compared with the year 1982 when the Opposition was in government. It is quite extraordinary to me that the Opposition should seek to make political capital out of issues such as these. Sadly, Senator Peter Rae has not sought to make much political capital out of issues such as steel and beef which his matter of public importance suggests he was going to talk about. The reason why he does not seek to make political capital out of these issues is that the hypocrisy in what has been said is quite breathless when one considers the record of the previous Government in respect of these issues.

Senator Rae did devote a few minutes of his time to the steel industry. Just on this question of performance, let us look at what the Fraser Government did about the steel industry in 1983. Confronted with the problems of the steel industry, as it was, the Fraser Government took the breathtaking action of appointing a Australian Steel Industry Advisory Council to consider the problems . Senator Rae talked a little about the question of investment and the levels of investment which, as we have said as Government Ministers in this place on a number of occasions, are unsatisfactory. But look at the levels of investment which we are seeking to compare in the years 1979-80 and so on when the then Government under Malcolm Fraser spent all its time in this Parliament and elsewhere talking up a resources boom in the mining industry which led to a lot of very important investment. Look what has happened to that now. If we are going to have a serious discussion about investment, we ought to be looking at where investment is likely to be. It is not going to be talked up by this Government in the same sort of way it was in previous years. It is essential that the Australian Government at present pursues exports, particularly in the Association of South East Asian Nations region, or the Pacific rim generally and it is essential that we do that as a matter of priority because it is something which the previous Government notoriously failed to do.

There has been a great deal of misunderstanding and misrepresentation about the Chinese-Australian steel initiative, so-called, and what it was about. Let me just remind the Senate of some of the facts of that matter. The Prime Minister and Premier Zhao of China have agreed to the establishment of a joint working group to examine the prospects for complementary development of the Australia- China steel industry. That working group has been established. Any government in Australia that did not participate in discussions of that kind and participate in the setting up of a working group of that kind would be derelict in its duty and remiss for failure to explore every opportunity on behalf of this country in respect of exports to a country such as China.

The fact of the matter is that the so-called defunct, or dead, Chinese steel initiative is progressing quite well. A joint working group to be known as the Chinese-Australian Iron and Steel Industry Joint Study Group has been established. That is examining specific issues such as exports to China of iron and steel, iron ore, manganese and coal. It is also examining Chinese investment in iron ore mining in Australia and Australian investment in the Chinese steel industry and technical co-operation in upgrading Chinese steel mills. I think there have been four exchanges of groups from both governments to discuss these issues.

A delegation of senior Australian officials recently visited China. The Chinese Minister of Metallurgical Industry, Li Dongye, who is the responsible Minister in China, will visit Australia in May. It does not mean that, because he is visiting Australia in May, there will be some enormous and significant result from that visit. But he is not coming here for the good of his health; he is coming here to look at the Australian iron and steel industry and to have discussions with the Australian Government about the matters which were raised by the Prime Minister in the course of his visit to China.

The Chinese have indicated to officials involved in the joint study group that they are very interested in the proposals that are emerging from that initiative . They are anxious to expand their steel production and indicate aims to achieve a doubling of steel production by the year 2000. They want to gain access to the best available technology. They are having discussions with representatives of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Limited regarding those matters. There will be room for co-operation between Australian and Chinese industries at each stage of iron and steel production. The group of Australian officials who went to China recently came back with a number of proposals to further progress on expanding those areas where co-operation between Chinese and Australian industries could be most beneficial.

I mention these things because I should emphasise-I do not shrink from doing so for a moment-that the final decisions depend on the economic feasibility of all these proposals. Considerable lead times might be involved given the size and nature of some of the proposals. If we succeed, as a result of these discussions , only with a degree of technological exchange with China, in increasing somewhat the iron ore exports to China in a small way, then the whole initiative will have been worth while from the point of view of this country. It is no fly- by-night scheme along the lines of the Malcolm Fraser plans to revitalise world trade on a gradiose basis; it is nothing of that kind. It is a proposal which requires steady work, persistence and so on by both governments. It is a long term, substantial proposal which offers the promise, not the assurance, of long term benefits to Australian industry. It is very sad that the proposal has been misrepresented by an Opposition desperate to find an issue to discuss in this Parliament on the first day back after three weeks away.

There is no suggestion that there will be any overnight doubling of the Australian steel industry. Contrary to what Senator Rae said, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, certainly in the statement made by Mr Loton, said that there would be no doubling of BHP's steel production capacity in connection with this initiative. But BHP has agreed that the initiative has been very helpful and has significantly increased Chinese interest. That company recognises that Chinese long term plans involve large increases in steel production. CRA is also , as I have said, discussing proposals with the Chinese.

Of course time scales are involved in all these matters. In the short term there is the possibility for spot deals in steel and increased technical assistance. In the longer term there is a possibility of contract sales of iron and steel to China and the potential for Chinese investment in Australia. Further down the track it may be possible to give a supply of semi-finished steel to China. At the moment, however, it is important that we are talking about real initiatives which should not have been bypassed or overlooked by the Australian Government. As I said at the beginning of my remarks, the importance of the initiatives is that Australian industry has to get out into the Asian market and be looking at every possibility which is available to it. We must become part of the fastest growing region in the world, especially in relation to our own industrial development.

These are things which the Opposition, the former Government, just failed to recognise in seven lost years. Everybody who was thoughtful about the prospects for the Australian economy, who was aware of the changing patterns of imports and exports with Japan and the Association of South East Asian Nations, as distinct from Europe and the United States of America, over that seven year period knew that those figures all pointed in a particular direction. There were seven dark years of failure to take initiatives, of failure to grasp opportunities, as a result of which it has become harder for each successive government in Australia. We are not about seeing that the last 15 or 18 months is in the same dark category as those seven years to which I referred. We have not been about that since we came into government. In any event, it is extraordinary hypocrisy for this Opposition to be carping about this Government' s handling of the steel industry when one looks at the previous Government's record. The steel plan, as Senator Rae acknowledges, has given a real boost to the industry in this country and has resulted in pulling that industry back from the rim.

I wanted to say something about the beef industry. I assumed, as I have the advantage of a university education and can read what people are going to make a speech about, that Senator Rae would be saying something about beef. He said very little about beef. Let us say something about beef so that those people who want to read the historical record of Hansard will know what this debate was supposed to be about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did explain that my colleague, Senator Scott, would speak primarily about beef. There is a limited time.

—I understand that. It is a pity that the honourable senator wasted so much time talking about what the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions did in 1969 and things like that if he was worried about a shortage of time. The fact of the matter is that one of the topics of this matter of public importance is beef. The posturing of the Opposition on Australia's access to the Japanese beef market is again extraordinarily hypocritical. As the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, said in answer to a question during Question Time today, the percentage share of Australia's access to the Japanese beef market has been declining since 1978. It is only in the last fortnight that the Leader of the National Party of Australia , who was Minister for Primary Industry over much of this period, began to wake up to that fact.
—Who was in government in 1978?

—I do not think I have to explain that. Senator Rae might have had some objection as to who was in government in 1978 but he is not complaining about it now. Again, the fundamental objective of the Government in respect of negotiations with the Japanese authorities on beef has been to try to maximise access to that market. Our public position on that has reflected that concern. This has been put by the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). This stance will be maintained by Mr Kerin when he goes back to Japan on 14 May. What has been going on is well understood by the Australian cattle industry, with which the Government has been in regular consultation. On the other hand, the Opposition has made every effort to weaken and undermine Australia's negotiating stance and to work against our national position in respect of those negotiations.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it quite clear that what is perfectly obvious and an historical lesson for us is that Australia does not have the economic and political leverage of a country such as the United States in negotiations with Japan on these issues. I suppose if we looked back over the history of this matter that should have been realised. For example, if one goes back to 1978 to the time of the Strauss- Ushiba agreement of that year the Japanese beef market was increased by 10,000 tonnes on a global basis. Of course, part of that agreement was that Australian competitors were precluded from an increase in that share as a result of the actions of the United States Government on behalf of United States suppliers. That difficulty has been encountered ever since. At the time of course it was meekly accepted, even applauded, by the then Liberal-National Country Party Government. As I said earlier it is something that subsequent governments have to live with.

The position of our beef industry has been hurt by the recent deals struck between Japan and the United States which were discriminatory and, in important respects, contrary to the spirit of multilateral trade negotiations. It has not however diminished this Government's concern to bring about the best possible results for the Australian beef industry. Those discussions, as I indicated earlier, will be continuing in Japan in a week's time.

I make the point that as a result of these negotiations in 1978 and the subsequent 1979 agreement the Australian share of Japan's global quota fell absolutely from 100,000 tonnes in 1979, to 92,000 tonnes in 1980, to 90,000 tonnes in 1981 and to 90,000 tonnes again in 1982. This was not just market share but represented an absolute decline in tonnage. It is an extraordinary attitude for an Australian Government to have taken at the time but we will not repeat that attitude in the course of the present negotiations. This is reflected in the talks between the Japanese Prime Minister and the Prime Minister of Australia and in correspondence between the two Ministers. The key section of the communique between the two Prime Ministers states that:
The Japanese side confirms that it has no intention of dealing with the trade problems with third countries at the expense of Australia.

Of course, both these matters of beef and steel are in the same basket. The Government will not be deterred from continuing negotiations as hard as possible with the Chinese and the Japanese in relation to both these matters. As I said at the beginning we would be derelect in our duty to this country and in our approach to trade in this region if we were lacking in diligence in pursuit of those matters. We will not be deterred by Opposition matters of public importance which have so little substance about them that half of them are devoted to personal abuse of the former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to support the matter of public importance which alleges 'The deception of the Australian community by the Prime Minister on the prospects he had secured for Australia's steel and beef industries on his recent Asian visit.' The word 'secured' is the operative word because there really has been no suggestion that the maintaining of the share of the Japanese market was anything other than something that was a virtual guarantee, barring only problems that related to Australia's capacity to supply or which, indeed, related to the quality of the product. Of course, they are natural provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: In listening to Senator Button I was impressed with his statement that he had a university education and was able to understand the problems relating to the debate this afternoon. Even though perhaps a year or two after Senator Button I also had a university education and I probably have a closer actual association with primary industry than the learned Leader of the Government in the Senate. Senator Button impressed me in that he displayed a real measure of caution. In doing that he was significantly different from his leader, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. If he had not displayed that sort of caution and commonsense then perhaps he would be another Mr 74 per cent. Senator Button at least has an indication of how he might rise to those giddy heights. I do not think it would be good advice because in the longer term the Australian people will prove to be extraordinarily intelligent and will not be fooled by ecstatic views or by pipe dreams. At this stage I am reminded of Michele Grattan's observation in the Age newspaper of 24 April. She said:
Bob Hawke's excess of enthusiasm during his Asian trip has caught up with him. Yesterday he was the emperor clutching for the bathrobe.

Perhaps that will be proven to be even truer as time goes by. From the point of view of the Australian beef industry one certainly hopes that it is not true. One would have thought from the ecstatic reports of 3 February that there would really be no need for tripping backwards and forwards to Tokyo and that there would be no need to confirm matters that were made clear at that time. This was to the extent that the Australian people and the Australian industry in particular were delighted with the proposition that the Prime Minister had put forward whilst he was in Tokyo. Ever since then there seems to have been a negating of those glittering reports and those great hopes for this most important industry.

Senator Button in his remarks referred-as honourable senators on the Government side in this chamber so often refer-to the seven lost years or the dark years, call them what you will. I think in passing that Senator Button should be reminded that six of those years to 1981 saw some remarkable successes. It is worth remembering that inflation in that period from the end of the Whitlam era dropped from 17 per cent to 8.8 per cent. It is worth remembering that the Australian deficit in that period dropped from nearly $5 billion to practically level pegging. They were very significant achievements during the years that Senator Button chooses to describe as dark years. Indeed it was only the rapid onset of a world recession, the wages spiral in this country and the onslaught of the worst drought recorded that finally brought the disastrous economic circumstances not only to Australia but also to a major part of the trading world. I think there is a lesson to be learned from the subject matter of this debate. Indeed, there is a lesson which all Australians and indeed all people living in democracies around the world could well look at and think about.

This debate has been brought about by the pipe dreams of a Prime Minister who, through media presentation and various other measures, has been seen to be something deserving of great popularity. He has been seen to be developing-I hope he has been seen to be developing-the politics of personality. It is therein that lies the great danger to the Australian people and to people who treasure democracy anywhere around the world. I am quite sure that many of the things that the Prime Minister says from time to time which I might from time to time find acceptable do not sit terribly well in a theoretical sense with his own socialist supporters. So we have to be careful that we do not find ourselves swamped by what can most easily be called the politics of personality, whereby the level or curve of an eyebrow or the mannerism of a brushing of the hair is more important than economic policy or political philosophy. That is something that even the learned leader of the Government in this chamber probably believes . I am sure he will devote some thought to it.

The glowing stories that have emanated from the trip to South East Asia and in particular to the Japanese area concerning steel and beef have been dampened very significantly. From the point of view of the steel and beef industries and from the point of view of the Australian people at large that is a great shame. It would seem those stories were the product of significantly over enthusiastic statements. The view of Mr Loton of the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd was that he could see no way in which an expenditure of $7 billion to establish the sort of steel production that Prime Minister Hawke was talking about could even be contemplated, particularly in a situation in which Japan, next door to China, stood there with some 40,000 tonnes of surplus steel and a massive vacant capacity to produce even more. One would think that BHP and its directors had virtually no knowledge of the steel industry or of potential markets for their product around the world. One would think that after almost a century's association with the great land of China they had no idea that she wanted to be involved in some sort of steel deal. Of course they are very well aware of trading circumstances in their industry, be it in the Far East, in Europe or wherever.

I turn to consider for a moment the beef industry in Australia because that is the industry that bore the greatest brunt of this unfortunate enthusiasm. Indeed , it will be unfortunate only if it proves to be significantly untrue. We hope that is not the case. But if it is untrue it is most unfortunate indeed. I am sure it has stirred in an industry which is of great significance to this country-an industry which has enormous potential and an industry which has suffered from a whole range of problems in the last five to ten years-a significant hope that here probably was the capacity for a real increase in the market for its product. The Australian beef industry is an industry which represents in total some $2.2 billion. It is a massive industry. Just over 10 years ago it lost its entry into the whole of the European market. It was faced with an enormous challenge, a challenge to find markets for something like 75 per cent of Australian beef production. It accepted that challenge and, indeed, found new markets. It found new markets in the Middle East, in South East Asia, in Japan of course, in South Korea and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty five per cent of Taiwan.

—It found markets also in Taiwan. Now, somewhat ironically, those markets, carefully established over the years, are being threatened by the surplus of the European Economic Community. The beef industry in Europe has grown so dramatically under the subsidised system that it adopted in the common agricultural policy that European subsidised surpluses are entering the markets of Egypt and indeed other areas in the Middle East, and are now even spilling over into South East Asia. In the short period of movement by the Prime Minister in South East Asia, Japan and China we have lost very significant markets. Indeed, we have lost the total Singapore market. We have lost a very significant share of the Korean market. Now it would appear that we may well have lost a proportion of the Japanese market.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it absolutely clear that the industry was concerned on very sound grounds. I think I should quote just briefly from what Mr Hawke said in Japan to indicate why this problem has arisen. In a joint communique with the Japanese Prime Minister this was said:

The Japanese side believes that the position of Australia as a supplier of primary products including minerals will not decline so long as these Australian products maintain their competitiveness and the stable supply is assured.
Further, at a Press conference in Osaka the Prime Minister said:

First we have had discussions with leaders of government and industry to ensure that Australia maintains its share in the traditional areas of supply which, of course includes mineral products and primary products-particularly beef.

So there can be no doubt that on the basis of those words there was a real reason for some measure of enthusiasm in the industry. One can only hope that the ultimate result of racing to and from Tokyo is that that sort of extended market will become a fact. As I said at the beginning of my speech, there can be no doubt that this is just one other exercise in the politics of personality. It is one other desperate attempt to vindicate and to run off some of the problems that are confronting this economy as a result of this Government's policies in recent months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In mid-January this year the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, Mr Bryce, and the Minister for Minerals and Energy in that State, Mr Parker, went to Peking. They were met at a television reception by the Premier of China, Premier Zhao. On that mission they also met the Minister of Metallurgical Industry, the gentleman who is shortly to come to Australia, Mr Li Dongye. Shortly after they met the Premier they went several thousand miles by aircraft to a province near Tibet and were greeted overwhelmingly by the citizens of that small community. It turned out that the joy with which they were received was caused by the fact that those citizens had seen them on television meeting their venerated Premier, Premier Zhao. That served to remind them, as they recounted to me on their return, that there are over 1,000 million people in China. As they remarked, in the 30-second grab on Peking television broadcast nationwide they were probably seen by more people than they would ever be seen by if they continued to appear on Western Australian or Australian television. If we could sell only a pair of bicycle clips to each of those 1,000 million people, the future of the Australian steel industry would be secure.

SPEECH.PARA: I start with that anecdotal evidence to underline the point that the size of the market we are talking about in China is gigantic; it is huge. The size of the market in Asia is beyond the dreams of a domestic Australian producer, but the Chinese market has been closed since the Chinese Revolution to most countries as that country has tried to develop its own economic philosophy of self-sufficiency. Due, in part, to the early recognition of China by Gough Whitlam when he was Leader of the Opposition in 1971, due to the development of the China-Australia Association by the Australian Government under Whitlam and now under Hawke and due as well significantly to major internal developments in China, the Bamboo Curtain has now been lifted and other countries are being invited to share in supplying the Chinese domestic market. It is vitally important that Australia, a near neighbour of that giant, achieve a foothold in that huge market and develop an association, not just for the short term but over a long term perspective, which will stand domestic producers, be they steel , iron ore, beef or any other aspect of the Australian economy, in good stead for years to come. I would have thought that would be debated in this discussion of a matter of public importance. I have to confess that I am somewhat flabbergasted that the prospects for Asian trade, specifically Japanese- Australian trade, have been taken so negatively in this debate and not looked at realistically with an eye to what possible optimistic scenarios can be developed so that we can rise in our imaginations to crack that gigantic market to the benefit of the living standards and employment prospects of Australians and obviously, through the trading relationship, for the living standards of our trading partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let some officials visit Taiwan and develop the trade there.

—I apprehend some interjection. I cannot understand what it is about, but it causes me to comment that under the new rules of the Senate matters of public importance can be lodged until 12.30 and debated at 3 o'clock. I would have thought that, given the limited time for preparation by the Government to respond to matters of public importance from the Opposition, which has unlimited time to prepare the substance of matters of public importance, we would have been met in this debate by cogent, reasoned and rational argument. In fact I am surprised to find that the contributions from the Opposition in this debate are boring me to death. All that Senator Rae did was to rail against the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his role as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. If I get some time at the end of my remarks I will take the opportunity to repudiate point by point what Senator Rae said, because the Prime Minister's contribution to the ACTU is so significant that the cynical and journalistic approach adopted by Senator Rae and others is such that they can never even begin to understand it. But I do not want to be thrown off the course of talking about something that is vitally important to the people of Australia, namely, the Prime Minister's tour of the near Asian area and specifically what he has achieved in Japan and China.

SPEECH.PARA: I should make another comment about the boring nature of the Opposition's case. Senator Scott started by saying that deception or, as he put it, alleged deception is not the operative word but that 'secure' is the operative word. He then explained in a long litany of hardly intelligible argument why it was important, part of which was some concern about the politics of personality, the curve of the eyebrow or the brushing of the hair. We were told by Senaor Rae, cueing the contribution of Senator Scott, that Senator Scott was going to talk to us about beef. Senator Scott, in his 15-minute address, spent 10 minutes on the curve of the eyebrow and the brush of the hair and five minutes on the beef industry, leading any observer of this Parliament to conclude that there was precious little that Senator Scott or Senator Rae could say about beef.

I turn to the matter of public importance itself because it invites from the Government a very cogent case which ought to be proudly expounded by it. The matter of public importance begs the question: What is the role of government in trade? I think that quite clearly the role of a government is to make at diplomatic and international level the openings and the opportunities for the commercial interests to follow in the government's footsteps and take up those opportunities. To compare my view of the purpose of government initiatives in the trade area and with what Mr Hawke did in February let me quote from the ' Canberra Observed' column of the 27 April edition of the Australian Financial Review in which Gregory Hywood, commenting on what the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, had achieved on the steel issue, said:
Mr Hawke's role was to provide the commercial opportunity through effective diplomacy. This he did.

That is the significant role of government as contained in the impartial comment of a journalist observing the actions of government in these circumstances. That achievement stands tall against the laxity, ineptitude and apathy of the previous Government which was not bothered to disturb itself too much about promoting an effective role for government in creating trade opportunities.

It is important I think in this debate to put into context the purpose of Mr Hawke's Asian tour. His purpose was to diversify Australian industry towards its most competitive areas, concentrating increasingly on expanding the Asian market for Australian products. The role of government was proactive and positive, to get employment, investment, development and growth opportunities in Australia. It was a role which the Government was playing in the context of a general economic recovery in Australia and an increasing confidence in the Government by industry and business. It is ironic that this is the first vaguely economic matter of public importance raised in this place since as long ago as I can remember. That perhaps says a lot about the Opposition's refusal to take on the Government on economic issues, thus suggesting that the Opposition recognises the reality that the people of Australia clearly understand that this Government is a government of economic improvement. The initiative taken by the Prime Minister has to be seen in that context.

Because Senator Button has done more than justice to the argument about beef, I turn only briefly to the beef issue. The significant achievement of the Prime Minister's negotiations in Japan on beef hinges on the Hawke-Nakasone joint statement. This was an agreed communique, not a Press statement of comment by the Prime Minister on what he saw as significant. It was a joint declaration from two heads of state setting out commitments one to the other. The relevant passage in the comment is:

The Japanese side believes that the position of Australia as a supplier of primary products including minerals will not decline so long as these Australian products maintain their comeptitiveness and their stable supply is ensured.
