The Japanese side confirms that it has no intention of dealing with trade problems with third countries at the expense of Australia.

That commitment has been the basis for the following through of the beef negotiations in which an Australian Labor government is trying to pull out of the fire the fat that was allowed to fall into it by the previous Government which presided over a decline in our beef trading fortunes with Japan. This Government has followed through persistently at various levels of ministerial responsibility to try to negotiate a better deal for Australian beef producers, given the profound and excessive leverage that the United States has on the Japanese market in that area. It is not a matter that we are walking away from. It is a matter that we are strongly and aggressively pursuing in the interests of all associated with the beef industry and with Australia generally. It is something that the Australian Cattlemens Union has been kept briefed on and has been informed of as we have gone through. The significant attainment will be to achieve the commitment which makes the ongoing pressing of those negotiations possible.

I turn briefly to steel. It is uncomfortable for this matter of public importance that the Chinese Minister for Metallurgy, Mr Li Dongye, is coming to Australia this month. He is coming, not because he likes the weather, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) said, but to follow up the initiatives undertaken by the Prime Minister. His presence here will be tangible proof that the Hawke initiative is producing results in terms of moving towards a position of improving our trade relationship with respect to iron ore and steel, a multi-tiered relationship, given short, medium and long term time scales in which a comprehensive integration of our steel industry and the supply of pig iron and steel is hoped to be achieved for Australia. I do not want to go into a long justification, but let me again quote the Hywood article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review to put into context what, in fact, is being argued against us. It states:
The initiative--
let me interpose that this is the steel initiative-
he sold so hard while in China could be portrayed by his political opponents as having come virtually to nothing.
If this were to occur, it would be largely untrue.
The fact is that the China steel initiative is progressing quite well.

When the Chinese Minister for Metallurgy, Mr Li Dongye, visits Australia next month, BHP will be presenting him with a hard proposal relating to the reopening of Kwinana and the possible expansion of crude steel production from the East Coast.

Having been advised by China that it wants to import from Australia enough pig iron and crude steel to enable the reopening of Kwinana, BHP is to put to Mr Li a formula involving an interest in its Koolyanobbing iron ore mine and the possible leasing of Kwinana.
China is understood to have indicated a willingness to deal on the basis of 5- year contracts.

The article goes on to talk about what is in it for Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd and what is in it as well for employment and other prospects. If that is deception, if the achievement of the possibility of securing those goals is deception, I do not think the Opposition has any case to raise at all and its matter of public importance falls on the boring arguments of attacking the personality of the Prime Minister and his performance regarding the ACTU. I do not think it is necessary for me to go into any great defence but, as someone who witnessed the Prime Minister's presidency of the ACTU at first hand, I say that the ACTU and the Australian trade union movement is vastly better for the decade of Hawke with the ACTU as is Australian industrial relations and the Australian business community than it would have been had that not been so.

I have no further time to continue. This matter of public importance is a farce . It raises no substantive argument. It seeks to attack the Prime Minister on his personality, thus doing great damage to the national achievement in terms of opening up a major market with a great potential for Australia. The fact that the Opposition has diminished itself by seeking to deal with personalities and not issues is, I think, the most damaging and eloquent remark that can be made about its case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be fair to say that I have just as much hope as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or Senator Cook has of improving trade with the great country of China. What I want to know is whether the passage of information that we have received from the Prime Minister is totally true, whether it is totally realistic, whether it represents the facts, whether it will serve Australia well or whether it was, in fact, the size of the potential market that has gone so far as to mesmerise the reality of the situation. I believe quite clearly that this is the point we are debating here today. In former days China, of course, was noted for its activities involving the taking of substances of a nature so as to produce euphoric, even if ultimately fatal, conditions. I am inclined to think that the Prime Minister is still in one of those euphoric dreamlands. He holds the belief that he is in the real world, that commerce and trade are for him, that the world is just a slightly bigger Australia and that the vast experience and knowledge that he has accumulated can be shared with others for the general world good.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister is also, of course, renowned for his great skills in many other areas, but I will leave most of the better known ones alone. Amongst other areas, of course, he is great in sport. We remember only too well the triumphs of the America's Cup, the Davis Cup, the Melbourne Cup and so on. But I wonder how he will fit in with the homecoming of the test cricketers. I am starting to wonder whether the great curve is starting to subside. Then there is the weather , of course, He did great things in drought breaking. We had big increases in grains and great savings of livestock. But what about next year? Perhaps the success curve may decline there also. What about the success of the United States economy? What about interest rates? What about employment? What about development? What about accord?

Yes, what about accord. I have before me a report by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on industrial disputes for the week ending 13 April 1984. In this great year of accord, 19 1/2 pages for that week are devoted to strikes around Australia. This is at a time when the Government members are so proud of the industrial situation. Nineteen and a half pages of disputes are in that document, a considerable proportion of which disputes are totally outside the accord and the consensus, or whatever the word is. Yet still they go on. What about the mines in western Tasmania? What about the wharves in Melbourne? I see that $200m worth of cargo is stranded by wharfies on a go slow campaign in this year of accord. What about the new Parliament House in Canberra ? What about telegram deliveries? What about the seats for life in the Melbourne Entertainment Centre? What about non-contributory superannuation? What about consensus, the great word which means getting what one wants at the expense of calling everybody else a fool if they do not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Archer, I do not want to interrupt your argument, but I would like you to work around to the subject of the matter of public importance.

—I am saying that this is the man who decided that he had the great skills of the world. I am trying to work out what his skills are and how he uses them best. In fact, I am wondering whether he does not support the statement of Mr Willis who says that we might be the poor white trash of Asia. Why? It is simply because we are taking more than we are giving. We are now in the hands of the deliberate disruption and destruction of the basis and system of our whole way of life. We have only to look at who controls the arteries of Australia-communications, energy, transport and trade. One does not need to be smart to see who is in there and why. How much consensus is there?

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has a reputation of being Mr Fixit. It is a pity that he lost it somewhere between when he left the Australian Council of Trade Unions and when he became Prime Minister because he has certainly done nothing towards fixing any of these problems, unless one would call demolishing sections 45D and 45E fixing anything. I would like to know what happened to the people whom sections 45D and 45E used to protect. What will protect them now? The workers who used to look to those sections to keep them in work, to keep them in their jobs generally and to keep their families secure are now unprotected. What are we to do to replace that protection? What sort of protection will they get? Is it more important that we should look after the requirements of a few of the major unions than to look after the workers of those unions? I think it is time that Mr Fixit, the man who can fix everything around the world, started to look at that matter. Where has all this prowess gone?

His commercial experience is also absolutely impeccable! Senator Peter Rae made mention of some of his more opportunistic approaches to the commercial field. As Senator Cook said, he had a great record before he entered parliament with regard to all of the things that he did or nearly did. In 1969 we nearly had a hire purchase company. We nearly had an insurance company. We did get Bourke's. We nearly had a housing finance company. We nearly had a consumer credit scheme. We did wind up with Bourke's. On 16 August 1980 an article headed 'The Shop Shuts for ACTU' stated:
The store manager, Mr George Revelman, said yesterday the operation would revert to its original ownership after a four-week clearance sale.
That was the great dream. A Press article of 29 January 1980 stated:
The long cherished dream of ACTU President Bob Hawke to develop a network of union controlled and patronised retail outlets founded on Bourke's Melbourne Pty Ltd is in tatters.

That is the trading experience, the business experience, of the man who decided that he could go abroad and teach the rest of the world how to trade and how to deal; we should not worry about the professionals in the area, but leave it to him because he could fix it. Was it the great commercial experience that he had that encouraged him to take on both China and Japan in the one trip? My goodness , what an ambition! What a performance! I totally agree with Senator Button when he says that it is absolutely essential that we pursue exports. But we must be realistic about it and we must face the facts. We need to have in the negotiations the best and highest skills that Australia has to offer.

Where does this notion of the Prime Minister to succeed in the international field come from? No one on this side of the House or the other side of the House could but agree that the Prime Minister has the front and self-opinion to believe that he has all the answers, and he probably has the egotism to believe that he could teach the hardest and most experienced bargainers in the world about negotiating in regard to probably the two most difficult products in the world. Nothing that I know about the man would pull him back from entering these sorts of negotiations.

The beef business of the world is a rough and tough operation. It is operated by people whose existence is pretty tough. Australian beef producers should be applauded for making a living in certain areas of Australia. Negotiations in the beef business take years to set up and they are based very much on trust, understanding, performance, reliability and government friendship. In this regard the Prime Minister came back and clearly created expectations that were wrong. The statements that he made were incorrect. He knows so much about trading in international fields that he did not even understand what the people overseas had said! He made a complete misinterpretation of the careful wording of what they had said. He walked right into the trap and came out congratulating himself. He then said what a great job he had done when, in fact, all he had done was to agree totally to the cut that they had imposed upon us.

How many of the criteria for all the things that I listed that go with negotiations and with trading with these sorts of countries would this total novice in international trading have been able to provide? Do we have an arrangement that is based on trust, understanding, performance, reliability and government friendship? On what basis would he, or could he, have really expected to do any better? I would have preferred to have placed my trust in true professionals in the field. It is all very well for the front man to go along and wave a flag, but when it comes down to negotiating we need to have people who are proven to be successful in the area. If we had done something like that, the results may well have been better. I hope that now the professionals may be able to pick up the remains and restore the relationship and the sales that are involved.

Eighty per cent of our exports come from agricultural products and minerals. The potential markets, most of all, fully understand the unreliability of this country's delivery record. This was covered by Des Keegan in the Australian of 23 April. In part, he stated:

About 80 per cent of our export income is earned by agriculture and mining, particularly coal, iron ore, aluminium oxides and base minerals. The former is under threat from European surplus farm output and the latter from strikes and dismal metal prices.

Unless we improve our performance we will not stand any chance of getting any more of those markets, and we know it. The Prime Minister may well have dreamed up this steel deal when he was heading north in the rarified atmosphere of 35, 000 feet. But how did he cover the question of delivery? I wonder what sort of undertakings he gave concerning the unrelenting ambush tactics of that element of the mining unions involved? I think I know why the Chinese gentleman to whom I have referred is coming to Australia. I think he wants to have a look at the record of some of the mines to see the total unreliability that we have in supplying our contracts. He will see for himself the work that should be done in trying to get Mr Fixit to get the bandits to turn the ships around and get them moving to fulfil the orders that we have, so that we can be in a much better position.

I doubt that the Chinese would be unaware of the apparently unresolved problem that Mr Fixit seems unwilling to clean up. That is, of course, unless we take the action on sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act as being the clean -up. Maybe that was one of those things that the Prime Minister was referring to , as reported in yesterday's Hobart Mercury, when he told Ministers to steer clear of the difficult decisions and, in effect, not to talk about the things that might hurt. Not one of the potential problems of the deal with the Chinese is a problem of the Chinese. Every single thing that may go wrong is a problem of us in Australia. I, like all hardworking, taxpaying, loyal Australians, respect this. I appeal to those whose desire it is to destroy Australia to reconsider their aims and to help get this and other Australian ventures moving.

My desire is to see development of Australian resources and employment of Australian skills and capital. I believe that in this regard we are second to none in the world and we should be able to get it working. I would like to understand why the Prime Minister, on his return, or at any time since, has failed to discuss the matter in the Parliament. He has not made a statement of any type. He has not put anything down. I believe it is quite extraordinary that he should have regarded the trip as not worth reporting. All Australians would regret that the implementation-even if it is well intended-of his trip was so abysmal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been subjected to a dismal portrayal of what the Opposition says is a matter of public importance.
—'Realistic' is the word.

—It is not realistic; it is very dismal. Much has been said today about people needing to be academics to understand this matter. I am not an academic, but I believe that in regard to anything Australia produces, whether it is in the secondary or the primary industries, it is essential to export a part of the process of that manufacture. If we do not do that, that particular industry will be doomed to failure. I believe that that would be accepted by all sides. Today all that the Opposition is thinking about is knocking the industries, whether it be manufacturing industries, such as the steel trade, or the primary industries, such as beef. If it were sincere about improving the Australian trading position in the world, it would be offering its help to the Government. If it has a point of view to put, it would not be in here taking the attitude it has taken today. I do not believe that Senator Archer believed what he said. From what he was saying, it seems that he would be almost pleased to see the trade negotiations with China fall down over more imports of iron ore or of beef.
—Nothing of the sort.

—If Senator Archer reads what he said, I think he will find that is correct. He was hoping for more strikes. He was hoping that when the Chinese Trade Minister came to Australia he would see that we would not be in a position to export competitively to China. With that sort of attitude Australia cannot expect to improve her trading position in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Australian beef is as competitive as any beef in the world. Australian grass fed beef can be competitive. It has a higher quality taste. There is less fat on it than on grain fed beef. We should be in the market-place as Australian nationals. Whether belonging to the Government or to the Opposition, it would do every politician a world of good to get in there and spout the benefits of Australian beef. That is what we should be doing-instead of getting the silly attitude of the Opposition and its knocking. The 74 per cent figure seems to obsess the Opposition. It has no answer to this. But it will not be recognised while it takes the negative attitude that it does to our trading situation. I assure honourable senators opposite that people do take notice of these matters. Why are business people saying to this Hawke Labor Government, 'Thank goodness we have a government that will listen to us, a government to which we can talk and from which we can get some sensible answers' ? That is the attitude of business today, but the Opposition has lost that corner of the vote because it has neglected to service the needs of those people .

When Mr Hawke went to Japan and China he looked for the benefits which would flow to this nation. He is a loyal, dedicated, honest Australian trying to improve the conditions in this country. We have to improve our export trading facilities. That is no reflection on Mr Hawke. We should be looking not just to those nations but wider. For too long we have relied on so-called traditional markets. We must get out in the trading areas and do better. I agree that the Hawke Labor Government has a consensus here, and this hurts the Opposition. We now have a government that is reducing the number of strikes-whatever the Opposition says. That is paying off. Honourable senators should talk to business people. The situation is improving.

TALK.START.PARA: —The number of strikes was doubled in the mining industry in January.
—It was doubled? But what was the position during the years in which the honourable senator's Government was in power?
—It was double what it was during the years in which we were in power.

—What the Opposition always did was to bring in legislation to hammer the workers into the ground. The workers would not have accepted that. Had the Fraser Government continued in office, there would have been almost a revolution. That is no way to carry on. One has to live in a democratic society, and that is what the Opposition forgets. In a democratic society one has to convince people. In the end that is far better because, by convincing people, they will participate. They want to help. They are a team, and that is what is happening in this country. Today, Australia is becoming a more united nation. We understand the problems as people. It hurts the Opposition that that is happening. When the Fraser Government was in power all the Australian people were disunited. They all wanted to go various ways. Now, we understand the difficulties that we face.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Opposition has put up today is very un-Australian. Look at what it has said. It does not do the beef industry any good for the Opposition to say what it has stated. It would improve matters if the Opposition offered its services. Certainly, there are people in the Liberal Party of Australia and in other political parties that form the Opposition who can help. But they do not help. The Hawke Government will see that our exports increase. As I said, any industry that is not prepared to export cannot survive. It is impossible. We do not have the numbers of people or the capacity for use of goods in this country. Today, industries must have the benefit of economies of scale. Unless that is achieved, they just cannot survive. Exports are essential to any Australian industry. That lesson must be learnt very quickly.

We understand the importance of exports. The steel trade with Japan is very important. As my colleague Senator Cook said, there are 1,000 million people in China. We started the negotiations under the Whitlam Government. I admit that the Fraser Goverment carried on and became friendly with China. But it is important for a Prime Minister to go to China and Japan and talk to the heads of government and bring about a better understanding. Then it is up to the business communities to finalise agreements. We must get down to the working parties. Australia is a great supplier of raw material. We are a great supplier of foodstuffs. It will be essential for Australia to export in our region especially. Other countries will want to improve relationships with Australia. The Australian attitude is accepted very well in the region. In the region of the Association of South East Asian Nations we have a very good name. We should go out and exploit that, although not in a devious way. We should improve our understanding and our trading facilities. We can help in innumerable ways.

It does no good to this nation for the Opposition to just knock. It was a very silly attack. This is not a matter of public importance in that sense. The Opposition has failed miserably. When representatives of the meat industry read what Opposition members have said today, they will say, 'We have no hope with them. They have no positive thing to put forward'. When the manufacturing industry looks at it, it will find nothing positive. All that the Opposition can think about is knocking, and worrying about Mr Hawke with his 74 per cent and all the credibility. That is what the Opposition is thinking about, and it is destroying it. There is no effective Opposition in this country today. That is a great shame. In many countries, people will unite, whether they are in government or opposition, over various things, especially trade. It is about time that honourable senators started to think about that. It is not we, as the Government, members of the Labor Party, or honourable senators opposite, as Liberals, who should be solving this problem; we should be solving it together as Australians.

All that the Opposition is worried about is Hawke. Today it has no credibility whatsoever in the electorate simply because it has neglected over many years to look after the interests of this nation. As I have said, we must increase our exports. All that Liberal governments have done is to rely on England. When England joined the Common Market we had no markets. A large percentage of our exports now go to Japan. If the Japanese suddenly said 'we do not want your exports' that would be no good. We should spread our exports; we should be looking for wider fields than we are looking at.

This Government has very friendly relations with both the Japanese and the Chinese. We will improve our relations with Indonesia with whom we have good relations and with the Association of South East Asian Nations. Trade is a real possibility. All of those nations are gaining in importance. They have money to spend and they will spend it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not too happy with your Government.

—All Senator Rae wants to do is knock Australia. He is anti- Australian and that is a tragedy. He should be in there battling for Australia. We are a great country; we are the lucky country and the honourable senator should realise that. The matter of public importance which has been raised today has no credit whatsoever.
—You go out and tell it to some of the wharfies holding up the ships in Melbourne and the BLF holding up the construction of the new Parliament House.

—The honourable senator talks about wharfies holding up the ships . He wants to bring in more legislation against them. That is not the way. This Government will talk to them. The number of strikes are being reduced and will be reduced. The trade union movement is united. It is of no use Senator Rae saying that because some disputations are taking place the whole situation is out of control. It was out of control when the Fraser Government was in power; there was disruption all over this country. I refer to the reduction in the consumer price index which is improving all the time. That is happening only because management and labour are getting together. I know there is some distance to go but there will be further improvement. More than ever people realise the importance of getting together. Certainly we have some problems; there will always be some problems. We would not want them to be handled in the same way as they are handled in Poland. The Opposition would not want that sort of condition to prevail.
—That is the way your Prime Minister attacks the ABC. That is the way he treats the ABC.

—That is absolute rubbish. People should be free to criticise. Criticism, in the terms in which it was made, of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation was justified. The Opposition in its matter of public importance has made no case whatsoever.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This inquiry is linked with the present Government's inquiry into cost recovery for the aviation industry in Australia. The whole concept of cost recovery, under the user pays doctrine, is a creature of a previous Australian Labor Party administration and is founded on the specious argument that the user should pay for the services provided. That might be very relevant with respect to medical fees or something like that but where the community derives a large benefit, as it does quite clearly from the aviation industry, it is very wrong to charge the user 100 per cent of the costs involved in providing those services. The cost of providing those services is enormous. When it is put on a small tax base one limits the life or growth of that industry and reaches a situation, as one has in Australia today, in which costs for the passenger airline industry are so high that people are not travelling. While that is partly due to the two-airline policy, which inhibits any form of commercial competition between Trans- Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia on the internal airlines, it is also true that the huge cost burden of maintaining the airways services in Australia under the cost recovery doctrine puts an unfair impost on the users of the airlines in Australia.

There are two points to consider. The first is the use and relevance of the airlines to the whole trade of the country, to the commercial development of the country and, of course, to tourism. There is a great multiplier effect in both fields, commercial development and tourism. The community benefits from strong tourist traffic. The community benefits from facilitating communications between the various elements of commerce in the country. The community therefore derives a real commercial benefit and an employment benefit.

The second point to consider about the aviation industry that we have within the country is its reserve potential from a defence point of view. We have no strategic freighting or logistic capability in the Royal Australian Air Force, with the possible exception of the two Boeing 707s which we have. We rely very much on the facilities held Qantas Airways Ltd and to a lesser extent TAA and Ansett to provide a strategic airlift capability as a reserve. It is not right to inhibit that by loading all the costs of the operations of the Department of Aviation onto the users.

Another point I make about the cost recovery doctrine is that even if one accepts the validity of the argument that the user should pay-which I do not because I believe there is a tangible community benefit from it-it must follow that the user has a say in what charges are levied against him. At the present time and ever since the policy was introduced by the Whitlam Labor Government nearly 10 years ago the users have never had the opportunity of exercising a veto on what the Department of Aviation allegedly spends on their behalf and for which it then bills them. There is no facility at all for cost effective analyses, whether a required facility is the most cost efficient way to go. If the users are to be charged for a facility they must have a say in what is provided for them.

Whenever one has a go at the Government or the Department of Aviation on this whole matter it is cloaked in the holy circumstance of safety. Once one mentions costs to the Department, it says: 'We have to do that because we have to be safe and, of course, we are the safest operators of aircraft in the world'. Safety is expensive; there is no cheap way to achieve safety in the air. What we have in Australia with the Department of Aviation is a licence for bureaucratic incompetence. This document, the Attributable Aviation Costs from the Bureau of Transport Economics, is an academic treatise which I fear will pave the way for a new explosion in charges. One of the points that I would like to make in the time I have left is the way that the Bureau is recommending that we move from historical cost for assets to replacement cost. Some of the assets for which the Department charges exorbitant rental are hangars. Over 90 per cent of hangars on Australian airfields were built between 1939 and 1942 and were ceded by the Department of Defence to the Department of Aviation at no cost at all. So to charge the users for a replacement cost for those is quite dishonest.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY HOUSE OF ASSEMBLY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

I wish to mention two matters that are referred to in the report. One is the Australian Capital Territory Employment Task Force report which was referred to the House of Assembly by the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren). This report, which I referred to previously, has been given to the Minister by a committee which spent a lot of time preparing it. It had within it some 60 recommendations with respect to employment specifically in the Australian Capital Territory. As yet the Minister has not responded to that report. It is a matter that ought to have his attention and he ought to give a high priority to the recommendations of the Committee which deals with employment problems in the Australian Capital Territory.

The other matter that I wish to raise, which again is referred to in this report in several instances, relates to the development of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory and the transitional provision should this go ahead. Of course the House of Assembly has a considerable interest in this matter. The report of the Committee set up by the Government to report on self- government chaired by Mr Gordon Craig was given to the Government apparently in February of this year. There can scarcely be a document in this Territory at present that has more significance for the residents of the Australian Capital Territory. I ask the Minister whether he has any comprehension of the fact that the people of Canberra are very concerned about the proposals for self- government. There can be no doubt whatever that a large proportion of this community is opposed to any developments towards self-government. There can be no doubt that only a few years ago this community voted very forcibly and said no, it did not want self-government brought in. I wonder whether the Minister has any intention whatever of making this report public so that this community can have some opportunity to consider its recommendations and to debate the implementation if it is to be put into effect and the implications on the community. There are so many areas that are significant that have not been discussed. I wonder whether the Government has considered the report and its position in relation to it, whether it intends to accept the recommendations that have been made and when it will make an announcement. Does it intend just to tell the community what will happen without any consultation about the report ? The Government has had the report since February, which is a long time. I think the report ought to have been made public and we ought to have the opportunity to consider it.

The other report which is outstanding is the White report of the Committee of Review of the Role and Functions of the National Capital Development Commission. Again, the House of Assembly has referred to this several times in the report before us today. It certainly has examined it. Most organisations in the community have examined it. It is now well over six months that the Government has had that report and has not yet made its comments on it. These are important matters to which the Minister for Territories and Local Government ought to apply himself and make decisions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The decision by the Wool Council of Australia to alter its position on freight charges is a cruel blow to the industry in Tasmania but of course there is no doubt that the industry in Tasmania is still held in very high regard. That industry can ill afford a further addition to its costs at this time. This will in fact occur as a direct result of the proposed changes being implemented. At present the freight on Tasmanian wool is calculated from the nearest overseas container port, usually Melbourne. The cost of getting the wool to Melbourne is included in the freight charge and thereby shared by all wool growers.

It is surprising that the Wool Council has adopted this attitude because it is not its normal policy. It has been its policy to balance things out and to put growers around Australia on pretty much an equal footing. I wonder whether this is the forerunner to what could be different floor prices for different parts of Australia. It does mark an important precedent and change in this sort of operation. This decision also applies to other mainland outports. It is estimated that the freight costs of Tasmanian wool producers would increase by up to $14 a bale if the present scheme were replaced. Clearly, this is an intolerable impost penalising, as it does, wool producers who do not live or operate in close proximity to an overseas container port.

Although freight charges are incurred after the wool is sold there can be little doubt that buyers will manage to pass the increased cost back to the various producers. It is conceivable that producers in Tasmania will opt to sell their wool in Melbourne and thus be able to take advantage of subsidised freight rates for interstate cargoes. If this were to occur there would inevitably be widespread repercussions within the wool industry in Tasmania which, in my view, would be disastrous for my home State. I urge the Wool Council of Australia to reconsider seriously its position and move to maintain the status quo.

The other problem relates to the purchase by mainland scourers of Tasmanian wool. If this were to occur they would certainly buy on the mainland rather than come to the preferred Tasmanian scouring types which are in such demand in Tasmania because local Australian mills would not be able to participate in the market as the freight costs would make them uncompetitive. Figures that have been given to me today indicate that the cost per bale differential would be as high as $25.

I make these comments on the Wool Council on the occasion of the presentation of the report of the Australian Wool Corporation because the Wool Council has enormous influence on the Wool Corporation. One has to see only the wool grower representatives as members of that Corporation. Although the members representing the wool growers-who are listed in the 1982-83 report-have undertaken substantial changes, the bulk of the members represent grower interests. As I indicated in my earlier speech on the wool industry, growing problems face the Australian industry. One problem is that the Australian wool exports to Japan, which is Australia's largest wool customer, have been decreasing for some years as a result of heavy inter-fibre competition, changing consumer life styles and structural strategies. It is refreshing that, to some extent, that has been offset by the People's Republic of China becoming a major importer of wool. I think we must acknowledge that there are some changes. The demand for apparel wool in the current year is expected to increase as a result of the continued recovery of the world economy. I think this is indeed good news for the wool industry. Also textile activity in member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is expected to increase at a rate greater than for synthetic fibres. Again, this is good news for the industry. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

—Leave is not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I will address my remarks briefly to the 1982-83 report of the Australian Wool Corporation. I am glad to see that it has come down well and truly within the extended time limit. The Corporation sought an extension because the Auditor- General's report was not available and it undertook to bring its report down within six weeks of the availability of that report. That has been done. This is an opportunity to say just a word or two about the Australian Wool Corporation which has really strode from strength to strength over the last ten years or so and about the Australian wool industry which has the significance of being one of the few Australian industries which stand totally on their own feet. The Wool Corporation and the industry have come through a particularly difficult period in the 1982-83 season, to which this report refers. There was a depressed economic circumstance virtually around the world which made significant inroads into the demand pattern for raw wool and, more particularly or more relevant to that, the demand for woollen products. Added to that problem, the 1982 drought in this country took a very great toll of the industry, from the point of view of both stock numbers and the nature and character of the wool. As a result of both those things the Australian Wool Corporation, in implementing the reserve price system, was forced to purchase very significant amounts of wool. At the end of June 1983, the stockpile was 930,000 bales. The stockpile is greater today, although fortunately the demand for wool is improving quite a bit now.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Wool Corporation has proven to be a successful operator of the reserve price system. It has succeeded in stabilising the wool industry and all the wool textile and manufacturing industries around the world that are dependent on it. It is worth remembering something of the functions of the Corporation, which has the virtual total control of the marketing of raw wool. It administers the reserve price system and negotiates overseas freight rates in the industry. It has the added duty of organising promotion, both within Australia and globally, in conjunction with the International Wool Secretariat. It co-ordinates wool research around the world and encourages innovation in the wool marketing industry, in research and presentation. The Australian Wool Corporation has seen this industry through some pretty serious downturns. It has been able to maintain a relatively viable industry as a result of its reserve price operation. At one stage some years ago it was forced to take in reserve some 1.9 million bales of wool and it has successfully been able to distribute or sell most of that wool.

Finally, it is perhaps in the field of promotion almost more than in any other field that we need to look for increasing amounts of money. In the five years that follow, $9m a year is to be spent in expanding, extending and developing the United States of America market for woollen products. It is my hope that the industry will receive support from outside if it needs it. After all, 8 per cent of the gross return from wool is directed towards market funds, research and promotion. It is to be hoped that the industry receives the sort of additional help it may be in need of if promotion causes the sort of expenditure that may be expected in the next three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
The report before us for the year 1982-83 did little more than touch on what I believe is the important factor. On the first page of the report the last four lines of the summary state:
1983/84 in prospect looks bleak for the Australian dairying industry with a further increase in production of at least 5%, tight marketing opportunities and declining returns.

That was the Australian Dairy Corporation's expectation for 1983-84, which has nearly finished. The year 1984-85 becomes what I think we could refer to in colloquial terms as the crunch year. I say this because in the United States of America and the European Economic Community production is virtually unchanged. In spite of some noises that they have been making about a reduction it really has not come about and I do not think it is likely to in the short time frame. New Zealand, like Australia, is fighting for markets and it also is really not reducing. The relationships of Australia with free enterprise governments such as those of Japan, Korea, Singapore and Malaysia are not improving. I doubt that they will in the short term future when those governments have opportunities to deal with countries other than Australia.

We have to remember that the costs of wages, taxes and inputs generally in Australia are almost out of control. The prices of the products must inevitably be up for cutting. The oversupply of milk has to be curbed. The States in their own rights have not as yet agreed on how this is to be done. There are two distinct, opposite points of view from the high-producing States as against the low-producing States. I fully understand and appreciate both those points of view but I only come up with the inevitable answer that, one way or another, agreement has to be reached. If we continue to produce in excess of the market requirement there will be either a total price collapse or a total market collapse or, at worse, both. At present, a system of levies on production is under discussion to buoy up the export market. This will also eat into the return at a time when the price payable to the producer is likely to be cut. Incidentally, I was very heartened to hear a Mr Halfpenny in Victoria talking about ensuring that the price of food is reasonable and fair. I only trust and believe that he is broad-minded enough and sufficiently a man of the world to ensure that the producers of the food get adequately paid as well as that the consumers pay only what is adequate. I assume that that will happen.

One of the big problems in the future is the contigent $14m loss in Pt Indomilk . I would say that this is getting more and more certain as the days pass. The methods of covering this are still not determined in any way. I am quite satisfied that there needs to be considerable restructuring in the various organisations concerned with the industry. I believe that we cannot any longer have any of these organisations operating within one another. An arm's length deal between any of the industry groups has to be attained. I believe that there is still room for much more research into the industry in the areas of management, manufacturing, new products, better marketing and so on as the time goes on. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The 1982-83 annual report of the Australia Council is a little different from many of the reports that appear before us in the Senate. Quite a number of the reports that we receive are very general statements of activities of either a department or an authority. The report contains quite an amount of debating material on the subject of the arts. I congratulate the Australia Council in the sense that it has given to us a report which contains useful and interesting points of view on the subject of the arts. However, I raise a query in relation to one section of the report. The matter of the funding of the arts in Australia , so far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned, is, of course, an arm's length situation. Therefore, we do not see very often before us Bills or any other matters that give us the opportunity to debate the arts. Nevertheless, I think it is relevant that we express opinions on the arts and the expression of that opinion should not be taken as meaning that we are trying to interfere with the arts.

The subject of community arts is something that is a matter of some debate in the community, particularly amongst politically involved people. There are those people who say: 'What on earth are the community arts?' For people who feel puzzled by this I recommend a statement starting on page 38 of the report. I think this is a very fair and good statement of what the community arts are, the role of the Community Arts Board and what is the valid role of the Board. However, I am a little intrigued by one section of that statement. I draw the Senate's attention to it. The report states:

Other activities, ranging from the experimental or innovative edges of the arts to a great deal of apparently mundane activity, long ignored (even despised) and denied the credibility of belonging to the genus 'Art' are equally disadvantaged because they do not fall into recognised categories. Quite often the ignorance and denial of these activities has its roots in class, gender and race-in attitudes which effectively maintain the status quo. Stability and continuity may be appropriate in other areas of human activity but arts practice must be continually encouraged to go beyond what is known and accepted.

I think the last sentence in this statement is a very good one. However, I am disturbed by the preceding sentence that refers to a denial of certain activity, a denial which 'has its roots in class, gender and race-in attitudes which effectively maintain the status quo'. I think this is an extraordinarily political statement to have in a report supposed to deal with the nature of the arts. I wonder whether the author of that statement-whoever that author was- means to suggest that the status quo in the arts is somehow upper class. To me it implies that the so-called established arts, that is, orchestral concerts, opera, ballet, theatre, literature, poetry and so on, are parts of the status quo and are part of the establishment. The report seems to imply that people who are from a different class-one assumes the lower classes in this sense-are people whose views and artistic expression are denied. I hope I am wrong, but I do not think I am.

The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984

The purpose of this Bill is to amend certain of the arrangements under which financial assistance is made available to the States and Northern Territory under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act 1982.

I should point out to the Senate that this Government when in Opposition supported the objectives of the program when the Act was introduced by our predecessors. Because of the declining level of Commonwealth expenditure on roads the need for such an initiative was obvious. However, we were concerned about some of the provisions of the legislation, particularly the compulsory tendering requirement, and during last year's election campaign we undertook to review it.
Upon coming to Government we have accordingly reviewed a number of provisions of the ABRD Trust Fund Act, in addition to those relating to the calling of tenders.

In giving this undertaking this Government was concerned to have provisions that were reasonable to all parties. Consistent with our approach to conciliation and consultation detailed discussions were held with the States, local government, industry and relevant unions. This process identified three areas where changes to the provisions of the legislation were necessary. The first, as identified earlier, related to the provisions which required that all construction work on national, urban arterial and rural arterial roads must go to tender.

The second related to the provisions requiring the States to maintain in real terms their expenditure on roads for the duration of the ABRD program. We do not disagree with the broad objective. We were concerned, however, that there was no recognition of circumstances where a State had substantially exceeded its real terms maintenance of expenditure, possibly for a number of years, but that the excess could not be taken into account in subsequent years should the State fall behind the necessary rate of expenditure.

Thirdly, a number of States pointed out that, where a State wished to take the option of directing part of its urban arterial roads allocation to urban public transport projects, additional conditions were imposed without the State receiving one additional cent of funding. Having regard to the much greater rates of investment that most States are making in urban public transport than the funds that would be available under the ABRD program, this Government is satisfied that the requirement that the State also maintain its urban public transport real terms expenditure is unreasonable.
The amendments to the ABRD Trust Fund Act therefore make the changes which this Government considers are desirable in order to improve the operation of the ABRD program.

Turning to the provisions of the legislation, firstly the Bill varies the requirement that tenders must be called by a State for all construction works associated with national and arterial road projects. Under the legislation developed by our predecessors this was an absolute requirement with no provision whatsoever for it to be waived.

While this Government recognises the merits of the general principle of calling tenders for road construction, there is a need for some flexibility to cover situations where the process of calling tenders is either impractical or not cost effective.
The Bill therefore allows the Minister to approve an exemption from the requirement to call tenders for specific works where a State can demonstrate to the Minister's satisfaction that:
there is an emergency requirement for the works to be performed, or
the works are of such a minor nature that calling tenders would involve undue additional cost, or
it is not practical to prepare adequate tender specifications for the works, or
the works are of such a kind that competitive tenders are unlikely to be received, or

the works involve adjustments to utility services which would normally be undertaken by a government department, a government authority or a corporation not primarily responsible for the construction of roads, or
the performance of the work under contract would cause unavoidable retrenchment or inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees.
This last provision also requires the State or local government to demonstrate that it has taken all practicable action to avoid this problem.

The Bill provides for this amendment to come into effect from 12 February 1984, the date on which the Government's intention to revise these provisions was announced. This will enable to States, upon enactment of this legislation, to seek exemption in respect of any works which have been commenced subsequent to that date.

I must emphasise that each of these provisions for exemption has been carefully considered. They have been included as there are obvious circumstances where time or costs make the tendering process inappropriate. It is the Government's intention that the ministerial discretion will be used very infrequently, and then only after the most rigorous and detailed examination of all the factors involved.
The second area of amendment relates to the requirement that States maintain their own roads expenditure in real terms during the life of the ABRD program.

The Act currently provides that, where a State fails to maintain its roads expenditure in real terms in a given year, it is required to make up the shortfall in the following year. Should it fail to do this then its allocation under the ABRD program may be reduced.
However, there is no provision to allow a State which exceeds the real terms requirement in a year to carry forward that excess as a credit against a later year.

While the Government firmly intends that States should be required to maintain their own expenditure effort, it considers that the current legislative provisions are, from the States' standpoint, both inconsistent and inequitable.

Accordingly, the Bill provides that excess expenditure by a State in any year shall be taken into account in determining the level of expenditure by that State in a subsequent year. This provision is comparable with arrangements which have previously applied under Federal roads assistance legislation.

The third area of amendment relates to the requirement that, where a State proposes that part of its urban road allocation be directed to urban public transport capital works projects, it must maintain in real terms its own capital expenditure on urban public transport.

As it stands, a State which decides to apply part of its ABRD entitlement to urban public transport projects receives no more in total assistance than if it were to direct all of its funds to road projects. On the other hand, the State becomes liable to a requirement to maintain a specified level of State expenditure on both roads and urban public transport in each year of the program .

This Government's transport policy is to assist the States to improve and maintain urban public transport systems. It is clearly inconsistent with this objective to maintain an arrangement which disadvantages States which wish to apply part of their ABRD funds to worthwhile urban public transport improvements .
The Bill therefore removes the requirement that State urban public transport expenditure be maintained in real terms where this option is taken up.

These amendments, developed in close consultation with all the parties concerned, further reinforce the Government's commitment to improve the effectiveness of Australia's road system. This commitment is nowhere more clearly evident than in the increase of 45 per cent to $1,233m in our allocation to the States for roads this year. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
ROAD GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL

The purpose of this Bill is to amend section 24 of the Roads Grants Act 1981, under which provision of financial assistance to a State for a national road construction project is conditional upon the State inviting tenders for all works associated with the project.

The amendments for which this Bill provides are fully consistent with the corresponding amendments for which provision is made in the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill.
My previous remarks in relation to the tendering aspects of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill apply equally to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue debate on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which is now before this chamber. It is a report in relation to the National Crime Authority Bill and accompanying legislation. It is a report on which the Committee has given, as the Chairman's tabling statement indicates, a great deal of consideration. Of course, the Committee had a fixed term of reference which was short and, in my opinion and in the opinion I think of all members of the Committee, probably did not enable adequate time to discuss fully all aspects of the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: But I believe the report which has come forward does examine a great number of very important defects in the National Crime Authority Bill. I trust that the dissenting reports, including the minority report which I have presented, and which disagrees in a very substantial way with a number of the important aspects of the Committee's report, will enable the Senate to have an excellent debate on the issue and that the Senate will be able to determine that, if any legislation on this subject is to pass this Senate, then it is effective and is able to be implemented.

I think that the Committee investigation once more justifies the way in which the Senate operates through its committees. It has given to very important witnesses, including a number of royal commissioners, special prosecutors and counsel who appeared in dealing with the problem of organised crime for some years, an opportunity to come before it and submit documents before it. Much of that material is represented and is explained in the report and in my dissenting report. Therefore, I think that the Government's opposition to sending this National Crime Authority Bill to the Committee is shown to be a false attitude. I think the Chairman of the Committee, as a fair man, recognises now that the investigation was well worth while. I say that even though I find some of the recommendations extremely inadequate for the purposes of dealing with this problem.

Before I deal with the major matters involved unfortunately I must make one remark. One of the signatories to the report is Senator Cook, a member of the Australian Labor Party. I have already challenged the fact that he has signed the report because, as I recall, he did not attend any of the hearings of the Committee when witnesses were called. He did not attend any of the discussion and debate on the report when the Committee was examining the matter and was making up its mind. It is my opinion that that was very unsatisfactory. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has a proud record . Its members should be active or should resign from it. In my opinion it was unwise for Senator Cook to give his name to the report in which he has actually played no active role. I leave the matter at that.

In the words of the Chairman in the report, the Committee 'finds grave defects or omissions' in the Bill which is before us. That is certainly a true statement . Honourable senators will find from the 49 recommendations, a number of which are double or triple recommendations, that a great deal of improvement is required if the Bill is to be effective. From 10 of those recommendations I dissent in a number of important areas, but it is quite clear that the Bill, as it stands, is totally inadequate to deal with organised crime which, as evidence before our Committee indicated, is a growing menace in our community. It is an enormous enterprise whereby people are becoming wealthy and from which the risk of corruption of our society and our institutions is very great. We cannot afford to compromise just for purposes of agreement in the Parliament if we are making compromises that are not effective.

The Bill itself, as the report and minority report show, is indeed an impossible compromise between what I consider are irreconcilable elements that have been interested in the debate on this subject. Views are expressed by civil liberty organisations and individuals who by and large do not want a national crime authority or commission at all. I understand and appreciate the honesty of their views, but they have then accepted that, if there is going to be an authority, the one that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has produced legislation for is good enough. It is what they call a reasonable balance. On the other hand, if it is a balance which produces an authority that has no teeth , if it is an organisation which has no effectiveness, it would be better to have nothing at all and not confuse the public.

At the same time, the compromises which the Attorney-General and the present Government achieved with the States in regard to these Bills are quite deplorable. Of course, the States have not endeavoured to move away from those compromises, which have enabled them, through an intergovernmental committee, the opportunity of hamstringing the proposed National Crime Authority in its essential work. As honourable senators will see, both from the recommendations of the Committee which would greatly reduce the extent of that ability of the intergovernmental committee and from my recommendations which would take away much of that power altogether, it is necessary to act in that way.

I think the report which the majority of the Committee has supported has a number of soft options in it. It has come to major problems, which I will mention, not in great detail but which, as I have indicated already in my minority report and in the Press statement which I issued today, are of fundamental importance if this is to be an effective proposal. But I regret that some members of the Committee who in the examination of witnesses I thought were lions have turned out to be lambs when it has come to the recommendations in the body of the report. I regret that even if the Committee's recommendations were accepted what would be created in this country would be a ramshackle body. I think Senator Sir John Carrick described the authority proposed in the original Bill as a Heath Robinson institution and I think that is still applicable-one which perhaps produces a lot of steam and a lot of effort but produces very little result in the end. Unfortunately, the years would pass before we realised how defective was that machinery and the damage would be done in this society.

We have had members who have taken a very active role in the issue of organised crime over the years. Senator Chipp is one of those. I find it inexplicable that Senator Chipp at this stage could be satisfied with the recommendations which the Committee is making to deal with this problem. I want to read from just a few statements of Senator Chipp when, on 17 November 1983, we were referring this Bill to the Committee and he was taking a hot and strong attitude on the subject, as he has for years. In the early part of his speech, in quoting Mr Frank Costigan, QC, he said the following:

Organised crime thrives on corruption. Any proper investigation of its activities will inevitably find evidence of corruption. If a State Government or the Federal Government has the right to forbid a particular line of investigation then the independence and integrity of the commission is destroyed .
I am afraid that under the Committee's recommendations that would still be possible, not to the same degree but still possible. Senator Chipp went on to say:
This Bill gives a State Government the right to forbid a particular line of investigation. On those grounds alone I believe it is unsatisfactory in the present circumstances.

I say too that in fact rather than do that we would do better to operate under the Commonwealth powers, getting the same sort of co-operation no doubt as that which Mr Costigan obtained from the States but not thwarting the organisation in the way in which this Bill would. Senator Chipp went on to say, in dealing with the debate at that time and an earlier debate on the 1982 National Crimes Commission Bill, the following:

In fact all Australian Democrats are in favour of an effective national crimes commission and we all voted for it, for a model that maybe had some shortcomings , but a model which I thought was first class-the so-called Fraser-Durack model. If we are accused of holding up legislation to fight organised crime I simply say to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that he has a Bill right at this moment that has been passed by both Houses of the Parliament and all it needs to implement that particular crime authority is for him to get in a car and go out to Yarralumla.
I wish Senator Chipp had that same sense of urgency now. In that speech at that time he went on to speak about the powerless way in which this National Crime Authority Bill was constructed. He said:

I acknowledge the urgency of this matter but I would rather wait another five months and have an effective body to fight organised crime than come in with something-I do not want to be unkind to the Attorney-General-which one journalist has described as an authority which does not have in some instances as much power as a policeman on a beat. I say, without going to the extremes of Senator Archer, that it is a toothless tiger. I believe it would not make any significant contribution to eroding the $700m or $800m profits per year that are now going to organised crime.

We must be satisfied from the evidence received by this Committee that that was a grossly inadequate estimate of the amount. The amount of profit from organised crime was put to us as between $5,000m and $10,000m a year, which makes the need for an authority even greater. I will quote further from Senator Chipp's speech. He referred to an article by Marian Wilkinson, whom he applauded. He quoted her article as follows:
Under the new National Crime Authority, it is unlikely that crucial aspects of the bottom of the harbour tax frauds would have ever come to light.

Mr Costigan and other witnesses made it clear to us that, under the proposals in the Bill or even under the Committee's Bill, these matters would not come to light. In fact the crazy arrangement whereby there would be ordinary powers and special powers, with the authority denied the opportunity of investigating, calling witnesses and demanding answers at an early stage of an investigation, makes it clear that that would happen.

Senator Chipp, in that speech, referred with approval, as I do, to the five royal commissioners-Mr Justice Moffitt, Mr Justice Williams, Mr Justice Woodward , Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Costigan-and pointed out that each of them said that we needed a national commission. Senator Durack interjected: 'An effective one'. Senator Chipp said:

Yes, an effective crime authority. These people had all the facilities of royal commissions at their disposal. . . . If my memory serves me correctly, they certainly were in favour of one of the two models that the Attorney-General put forward, and they would have been appalled at the present Bill before the Senate .

From the evidence we had from them, I say that they must now be appalled that the recommendations, even those approved by this Committee, are not adequate. One view is that the powers of this organisation should be akin to those of a royal commission-different in some ways, but very similar. I take that view. On the other hand, there is a view that it should be a form of extended police inquiry meeting in secret, with all the public criticisms that it would receive as a result.

Among the soft options, the Committee has introduced two weaknesses which go beyond the present Bill. One is in regard to private hearings. In the Bill there are provisions which hypocritically make it almost certain that no public evidence will be called. The commissioners and others who gave evidence before the Committee made it clear that there is allegedly a right to call public hearings but that it will not happen. The Committee has said that this is hypocritical and that we must get rid of it. What did it do? It threw the baby out with the bath water. It said that there would be no public hearings at which evidence could be produced to show the ramifications of crime in this country but that it would all be done in secret. I set out in my minority report how dangerous that would be and how critical it would be to the operations of these organisations.

Secondly, the Committee suggested that we go further than the indemnity clause, which gives people the opportunity to take the self-incrimination point, which the Attorney-General put into his Bill, and allow people what is called the derivative-use indemnity so that the statements of witnesses before the authority cannot be used not only in criminal trials. That is fair enough, and the Attorney-General has provided for that. But the majority report of the Committee goes further than that in that it recommends that any information derived from that and any lines of inquiry coming from that are not used against that person, thereby nobbling the authority in the very use of its powers. Those are the two weaknesses introduced in the majority report of the Committee.

What in brief are the major matters on which I dissent? They are based on the best evidence before the Committee-the evidence of the royal commissioners and their earlier reports, the special prosecutors, counsel before such commissions, and people such as Mr Bob Bottom, who has been in the thick of this problem of crime for years. On those basic issues I dissent along a number of lines. Firstly, I believe that this report does not make an effective attack on the problem of organised crime. It would not enable a body like the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to exercise the same sorts of powers and effectiveness as that Royal Commission. Mr Redlich, QC, who is of course a special prosecutor, used strong language in his evidence before the Committee when he said that the authority's actions and powers would be 'gravely deficient in this regard'. In comparing it with the Costigan Royal Commission he said:

The Bill thus deprives the Authority of a vital initiative which has been developed by the Costigan Royal Commission. That Royal Commission has been able to gather, collate and analyse vast amounts of information in a manner hitherto unknown resulting in the identification of criminal activities previously undetected. The identification of the Hamidan scheme is a striking illustration of the success which can be achieved if the Crimes Authority is able to maintain this initiative. Section 10 (d) of the Bill will not enable this to occur.

Therefore, in the first place, if we go along this line, the authority will not have the same effect as the Costigan Royal Commission. In the second place, the purposes of the authority set out in the Bill are inadequate. The Committee recognised this but did not go to the length of saying that there should be no catalogue of various offences. It removed the ludicrous proposal that the authority should be concerned only with offences which attract terms of imprisonment of three years or more, but it did not go far enough in defining these matters.

Furthermore, I have referred to the absurdity of the distinction developed by the Committee between ordinary powers and special powers which make it very clear that it would not be possible for the authority to get a power from an intergovernment committee as it would have to go before such a committee to get a reference. How would it prove need? Would it do so on the scanty information that Mr Costigan had from the Victorian Police about the painters and dockers? It would never satisfy such an intergovernment committee and clearly, therefore, the authority would be prevented from exercising important powers at the beginning. I mentioned the intergovernment committee, a monster. I agree that it is necessary to have something supervising this because the States are involved. I set out the detail of this in my minority report, but the way in which the Attorney-General has moved from his past full-blooded attitude for a commission based on federal powers is extraordinary. Most of the people concerned in these criminal operations act across State borders and deal in Federal and State crimes. This inter-governmental committee would be given powers which would enable it to hobble the operations of a crime commission. As Mr Costigan says, that would be a sin. One can imagine that any attempt to go before it to obtain specific powers would be known well in advance by those who wanted to destroy records and to protect themselves. So, it is necessary to avoid that and to take away the veto powers given to governments, even the veto power given to the Commonwealth Attorney-General under this Bill.

I have said in my minority report that the public hearings must be maintained. This authority must have the right to warn the people of Australia of the type of activities going on. It is no good having public hearings just to discuss law reform or matters in general or to issue what I think the Committee called bulletins on public statements. That is not adequate unless there is the right to call, in necessary cases, public evidence of the nature of the conspiracies.

I say also that the appointment of commissioners under this Bill is inadequate. The chairman is to be appointed by the Commonwealth, but the others are to have their own 'constituencies'. One is to be appointed by the police Ministers of the Commonwealth and States-mostly the States, of course-and the other by the Attorneys-General. If the Ministers do not unanimously agree within three months , the Federal Government will make the appointment. Even the Queensland Government has seen through that and has said that this really gives it no power . It is fraught with the certainty of disagreement. Indeed, it means that commissioners will be inoffensive to everybody but will not have courage and determination to do the best job. I think this provision should be changed because, vital to this whole exercise, is the fact that we must have excellent commissioners. All the other methods of protecting and defending civil liberties will fail if the commissioners are bad. They are the vital issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a wonderful discipline for you to get into government one day; it really would.

—Talking of getting into government, the Committee unfortunately discarded joint parliamentary monitoring and said that ordinary parliamentary committees can deal with the reports that come from this body. We all know that ordinary parliamentary committees cannot deal effectively with matters at the moment. My own Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, has a number of references before it. The reports of various bodies are sent to us every year. There is not enough time and not enough staff to deal with them. We know that if the ordinary parliamentary methods are used and if there is not a special committee of both Houses-because both houses are concerned with this problem-we will not have proper monitoring of the system. That is another matter about which Senator Chipp and I are in agreement. We agree that a joint committee of the Parliament should be set up.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I say that we already have the National Crimes Commission Act 1982. That Act was passed by Parliament two years ago. The more one looks at that Act, the better it seems. In fact, it should have been proclaimed and put into operation. After it was proclaimed and after the change of government, the Hawke Government received a report from the proposed Chairman of the new Authority, Sir Edward Williams. In a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 22 December 1983, together with accompanying documents which he has made available to our Committee-extracts of which I regret I did not incorporate in my minority report -he analysed what is necessary to get the operation under way. Nowhere did he suggest that there are not reasonable powers and proper powers being applied. In his statement to the Prime Minister he said:

What is required is a concerted co-ordinated effort. There must be effective co -ordinated use of State and Federal resources, particularly skilled manpower, which are already being asked to meet very heavy demands, and the effective usage of which is under increasing threat by a proliferation of effort. A National Crimes Commission offers an opportunity to advance this. It ought to be a first priority. A second priority which emerges is that there ought to be emphasis on the effective prosecution of those engaged in organised crime. There is already information concerning those engaged in it and their activities-more is emerging. The time has come for the emphasis to be on turning that information into evidence founding convictions. This is envisaged by the Crimes Commission Act.

Of course, Sir Edward Williams was not allowed to act. He was not allowed to continue. The matter went into a state of discussion, in which it has been for some considerable time. Mr Justice Williams, in his many recommendations at the end of the document, in which he was suggesting how the Authority would operate in the way he described, proceeded to make very sensible proposals. In clause 12 he said:

The Crimes Commission Act will have to be proclaimed. At least one further commissioner will need to be appointed. There is a logic in this being Costigan, QC, if that were to prove acceptable to him. If he is to be appointed, it will have to tailor with his Royal Commission appointment.

We know that Mr Costigan will not consider the appointment. He thinks as the Committee does, that four years is long enough for one person to be involved in this matter. It is a disgrace to this country that we have not gone ahead with the legislation we already have. The Committee's inquiries do not indicate that the ramshackle arrangement which the Attorney-General has presented, after compromising with everyone under the sun, will work.
