I believe, as a member of this Parliament and of the Senate, that I would be failing in my duty if I did not point out, as I have in my minority report, not only the defects which are in the Bill, the defects that are still in the report of the Committee and the important and useful things which the Committee does but also the fact that unless we get an effective, strong commission that is prepared to tackle, and has the facilities and the ability to tackle these matters, we would be better not to mislead the public by going ahead with the legislation that is before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be quite premature at this stage to purport to give any kind of detailed Government response to this report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Obviously, the Government has not had time to fully absorb it, particularly its detail, nor to have the necessary consultations that are a precondition to a final position. But I can say a little today by way of initial response to the report. I believe that it is appropriate that I should, on behalf of the Government, indicate at least the initial reaction we have to it and how we propose to handle it. Let me begin by saying that the Senate Committee, under the chairmanship of Senator Tate, is to be congratulated for a job outstandingly well done. The report is comprehensive and thoughtful, reflecting an excellent understanding of the problems faced by executive governments in responding to the problem of organised crime.

SPEECH.PARA: At first sight, it would appear that the general thrust of the report is not likely to cause the Government any particular difficulty. There are, however, a number of matters of detail which the Government and the parliamentary party will certainly need to consider closely. A full Government response simply will not be able to be made until, I hope, next week. In particular, it will be necessary for us to consult with State and Territory Attorneys-General and police Ministers. Preliminary arrangements have been made for a conference of relevant Ministers and officials to be held in Canberra this Friday for that purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you think they will react to the report?
—I should think reasonably warmly.
—The Committee has done a better job than you can do.

—That is perfectly possible. I will say some more about that in a moment. It is the Government's hope that necessary amendments to the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 can be drafted and approved in time for introduction into the Senate before Parliament rises next week with a view to the final passage, then, of the legislation through both Houses before the end of the autumn session. Because of the complexity of at least some of the drafting that is likely to be involved at first sight in accommodating some of the--
—Do we take it that the end of next week will be the end of the autumn session?

—No, no such luck. I am saying that we will introduce it before the end of next week so that honourable senators may have some notice and an opportunity to chew over the textual details of the proposed amendments and so that we can debate them when we come back in the latter weeks of May. I cannot give any absolute undertaking about that because I have draftsmen in my office at the moment poring over the detail of this legislation in an endeavour to advise the Government as to just what might be involved so far as that timetable is concerned. It may be possible to produce a substantial batch of the proposed amendments-but not all of them-for example, by the time we get up next week. But there is no reason why those of them that are available cannot be made available to the Senate as soon as they are. It would also appear possible on this timetable to allow the Authority to be formally established in accordance with the Government's recently announced intention by around the middle of the year. It remains our intention that an appropriate transition period be provided before the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union is formally wound up to enable the new Authority to fully absorb and take over that Commission's ongoing inquiries.

SPEECH.PARA: On one minor carping note, I do not readily accept that the Bills presented to the Senate had, in the words of Senator Tate's tabling statement, 'grave defects or omissions' or that they require fundamental change.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the Committee recommends, fundamental changes.

—That is the language of its terminology in the tabling statement. But I suggest that, on closer analysis of the matter, which I am sure Senator Durack, with his well known dexterity in these matters has been able to give it this afternoon, it would appear that although there are numerous changes , a number of them of considerable significance, they do not really amount to any fundamental root and branch attack on the concept of the authority as it was originally devised. We readily acknowledge that a number of aspects of the Bill were capable of improvement with the kind of mature reflection the Committee has now given it. I repeat the Government's congratulations to the Committee for a job well done. We will be looking at the matter very closely over the next few days, as will all the participating governments that we have to involve in this process, which, I say to Senator Durack, remains the most fundamental difference between the realistic, real world model that we have adopted and that which appealed to his outfit when in government. We will do our best to complete this process of consultation, both with other governments and internally, to produce the amendments which will be necessary to give effect to the Committee's recommendations to the extent that we can accept them, and I hope that will be to an extremely substantial extent. We look forward to effective and good debate on the Bill when Parliament resumes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must comment on the generosity of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in the comments he has just made. The last thing he will hear from me in regard to his concession that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has done a good job will be those hateful words 'I told you so' or my trying to score points. He has been very generous in his praise of the work of the Committee and, I think, generous in conceding that improvements were possible and could well have been made. I, and I am sure other members of the Committee, welcome that conciliatory, consensus seeking attitude that the Government has expressed through the Attorney-General. I find it, without putting too fine a point on it, quite overwhelming that we could have such a generous response so soon afterwards. I pay tribute to the outstanding job done by Senator Michael Tate as Chairman, who was given an extraordinarily difficult task to do in such a short time, with a group of seven other senators who--
—Not a prima donna among them.

—I cannot agree with that, because there were six lawyers among them. I must thank those six lawyers for being extremely kind to the only two non-lawyers on the Committee, Senator Crowley and me. In that praise I join the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, Senator Robert Hill, for the support and guidance he gave the Chairman and the rest of the Committee, and also the secretariat, headed by Mr Christopher Fogarty.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the features of the Committee was that at our first meeting I think it would be fair to say that of the eight of us present there were probably six or seven different viewpoints as to how various aspects of the legislation might be addressed. Some of us had strong views in opposite directions. But I found it quite exciting. One of the few exciting things that happen in this profession of ours is the different way that politicians behave and think during committee hearings from the way in which they behave when they are on their feet in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. I was quite proud to be associated with this Committee. In fact, during the service that I have given this Parliament this has been the most successful and rewarding committee work that I have ever done, and I thank my colleagues for that.

I was puzzled by the force of Senator Missen's attack on me. To have heard Senator Missen's speech without looking at the report one would have been entitled to conclude that he massively disagreed with the report of the Committee. I think it is fair to say that he agreed with 90 per cent, or maybe 95 per cent, of the recommendations of the Committee. He has some firm ideas on certain things-for example, the formation of the intergovernmental committee, the hearings in private, self-incrimination provisions and vetos. I hope the Government will realise that there was a fairly strong view that the body should be called a commission. We know the natural reluctance, which I share, of members of the Australian Labor Party to call it the NCC, the National Crimes Commission. We are suggesting, and strongly commend, that it be called the ACC, the Australian Crimes Commission. I believe that in balance Senator Missen would agree with 95 per cent of the Committee's recommendations.

He quoted me accurately and in context with regard to what I said about the crime problem in Australia, what should be done about it and the inadequacies, as I saw them, of the National Crimes Authority Bill. I do not resile from one thing that I said during the debate on that Bill nor one thing that he quoted from me today. But I challenge him to say how what I said then is inconsistent with my putting my name to this very excellent report. I believe I have been consistent. I believe that the recommendations of the Committee, if implemented by the Government, will work in suppressing crime-not doing away with it, but in suppressing it-whereas the model put forward by the Attorney in regard to the National Crimes Authority, in my view, would not have done so. We received overwhelming evidence to the effect that it would not have done so.

While serving on the Committee I learned a lesson as a politician about how careful we should be in granting coercive powers to any body. We heard evidence from all sorts of people-civil liberties organisations and lawyers. I was very impressed with the evidence, particularly that of Mr Justice Nicholson, who said : 'Yes, these sorts of bodies need coercive powers, but for heaven's sake, don't let them roam at large without any checks or balances with coercive powers because there are little people who need protection'. I believe that we have struck a fine, delicate and, if I might say so, clever balance between giving the Commission enough power and authority to go after criminals and protecting the rights of little people.

I think it is an ingenious device at the two levels. We recommend that the new Crimes Commission should have authority to roam at large in any area it determines and not have its field of endeavour predetermined by some Attorney- General or vetoed by some State. It can roam at large at the information gathering stage until it is at what could be described as the stage of having established a prima facie case against a target. It will then say: 'We have gone so far in gathering information or intelligence. We now need to go further and hone in on our target. Therefore we now need coercive powers, the powers to be able to go to a bank and say that we want bank records'. Let us remember, while we are on the track of this debate, that every time Mr Costigan and Mr Meagher went to a bank manager-and Mr Costigan and Mr Meagher were deeply conscious of this-and said 'We want to see the bank accounts of Mr Jones' that immediately put Mr Jones in great peril of being bankrupt within a relatively short time. If Mr Jones happened to be an innocent party, that would be a massive injustice. I imagine that after a bank manager hears that a crimes commission is inquiring into a client's affairs he would be less than sanguine about the size of the overdraft of that person the next day and would not be very enthusiastic about granting him or her a business loan. So the granting of coercive powers is a massive step. Mr Justice Nicholson said that it would have a salutary effect on an authority or a commission in asking for them. In other words, it would not ask for them unless it could satisfy somebody else that they were needed.

I believe the Committee has struck a magnificent balance on the question of vetoes by the States of the intergovernmental committee. I sympathise with what Senator Missen said about the clumsiness of such a committee. But those of us who advocated an intergovernmental committee wanted a vehicle that could work. I am blessed if I know how a national crimes commission can work without the co- operation of the States, the State instrumentalities and State Ministers. I know Mr Costigan has received remarkable co-operation from the States. But he had a reference from one State, and the co-operation that Mr Costigan received in a one-off operation might not necessarily be repeated with an Australian crimes commission.

I can understand Senator Missen's misgivings about private hearings. But would it not be better to err on the side of protecting civil liberties, provided that one is still getting at the truth, as is done in grand jury investigations, than to destroy a person's reputation nationwide forever by having a public hearing and having an allegation or an innuendo on page one of all newspapers? I am very happy about the way in which the suggested amendments of the Committee will do away forever with this hideous exercise of Government departments, both State and Federal, protecting their turfdoms. Explicitly, we recommend that the Commission can demand information and not have other authorities withhold it.

I am sure that other members of the Committee would not mind me saying that we are all in a dilemma as to what sort of watchdog we should put on to this new Crimes Commission. Clearly it needs one or should have one. But do we want an ombudsman sort of fiddling around in there, gearing up the works? I do not know. Is it possible to have a judge sit in judgment as to whether the Commission is doing its job? Would that not need a full time judge cloistered in an office of his own somewhere? Perhaps a parliamentary committee? Goodness knows, we have enough other responsibilities. Finally, I have agreed with Senator Missen on the question of a parliamentary committee being a watchdog. That is not to say that I believe that it will be outstandingly successful in preventing any intrusions into civil liberties or whatever; but the mere fact that the Australian Crimes Commission will know that there is someone there looking over its shoulder will have a salutary effect on it.

In conclusion, I thank my colleague members on the Committee again for what was to me a most valuable, exciting and rewarding experience. Once again, I extend warm congratulations to the Chairman, the Deputy Chairman and the staff who served the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion to take note of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs concerning the National Crime Authority Bill 1983. Like Senator Chipp, I too would like to acknowledge the fine leadership of that Committee by Senator Tate. I also acknowledge the support that he got from the staff and the other members of the Committee. I am pleased to have been a member of that Committee and to have been associated with the report before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not say, as did Senator Chipp, that I am overwhelmed by the reaction of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), but I must acknowledge his comment that he recognises the work of the Committee in this report as having been outstanding. I could say that it is a pity that he was so obstinate in his objection to the matter going to the Committee in the first instance, but I suppose that in this new spirit of enthusiasm that would be unfair, so I shall not pursue that matter any further. However, his new attitude clearly vindicates the role of Senate committees in matters of importance such as this Bill and the important contribution that the committee system can make to ensure that the best possible legislation passes through this Senate. I hope that the Attorney- General will have learnt something by this experience and that in future circumstances he will not prove so obstinate.

In that new spirit of enthusiastically embracing the work of the Committee, it might be said that there is little more that need be stated. However, we have a situation in which one member of the Committee, my friend and colleague Senator Missen, has taken a point of view that is very different from that of all other members of the Committee. In the Senate today, he has strongly questioned the balance at which the Committee has arrived. Therefore, because that debate will obviously be extended after today within the parties, within the community at large, possibly within other governments that will have to consider this report and eventually again within this Senate, it is important that I should look at the basis on which the Committee reached the balance that it has achieved. I can certainly put to the Senate the reasons by which I came to conclude that the balance that the Committee has recommended is the correct balance. In doing that in these few comments, therefore, I want to look at the safeguards that are still afforded to the community by our recommendations; I want to look at the reasons by which I conclude that the Authority, the Commission, or whatever it is to be called-and that does not particularly concern me-will, nevertheless, be effective; and I want briefly to look at some of the problem areas that I consider require further attention in the future.

I say at the outset that we have privileges in this country that are very valuable. They include basic civil liberties such as the right of a person not to be compelled to answer questions that may incriminate him, and privileges such as that are founded on sound historical reasons. They also include a privilege of privacy-privacy of our personal affairs, records of our personal affairs, for example, that are kept by government, such as social security records and health records, and some privacy of our business affairs, for example, taxation records. All are subject to reservations, and the trend has been to undermine such liberties, compelling the answering of questions, searches without warrant, and matters of that nature. I simply remind the Senate of the most recent example that comes to my mind, that of the Customs alterations that went through this place a few weeks ago extending the searching power of Customs officers without warrant-powers that I opposed. Furthermore, the trend has been one of continual invasion of personal privacy. I remind the Senate that we have a very significant report on that subject from the Australian Law Reform Commission which we are yet to debate in this place.

These protections and privileges are what distinguishes our society from other types of the society that I regard as less desirable. The more they are abandoned or diminished, the more concerned I shall become. However, on the other hand, I also recognise what has been described as the cancerous nature of organised crime. I recognise that unless it is checked, it will just as effectively destroy the type of society that I desire in this country. For example, traffic in heroin, arson for hire, organised exploitation of the weak and the young for sexual gratification, murder for hire-that was brought to the Committee's attention-and the recent video larceny rackets involving invasion of people's homes and risk of personal and mental injury, frauds of trustee and other savings organisations which shatter the dreams of the innocent-these also do not reflect the society in Australia that I wish to see.

I acknowledge that traditional police methods, with very little right to compel answers and with limited access to peronal records, have been unable to suppress organised crime. If anything, such crime appears to be growing more sophisticated, more organised and more devastating to the society that we desire . I have, therefore, begrudgingly accepted that a body which has such coercive powers and access to records has the potential to be more effective. That is what this debate is all about. In an effort to combat a cancer in our society, the cancer of organised crime, to what extent should traditional personal liberty safeguards and privacy be sacrificed?

I accept that coincidentally by the institution of a commission other shortcomings in our system of law enforcement might be overcome. They have been dealt with in detail on other occasions. They are problems such as that arising from the multitude of jurisdictions that we have in this country, the multitude of criminal codes and law enforcement bodies, the lack of communication and co- ordination, and the limitations of police methodology. For example, it was put to the Committee that if it were possible to cut off the operatives, the petty criminals, organised crime rings would be bled dry. That strategy simply has not proved successful. There is also a lack of intelligence gathering facilities capable of dealing with crime in the days of computers, electronic transfers of funds, satellite communications, et cetera.

However, with political will all of these deficiencies can be overcome and to some extent have already been overcome. There are now task forces interstate and interdisciplinary. The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence is now computerised and on the move. It is getting a better fund of raw data. To me that is not primarily what this debate is about. This debate concerns the desirability of a new body with new powers which will result in a loss of certain privileges and further invasions of privacy. The fact that it may provide an alternative solution to some of the other deficiencies in our law enforcement system is, as I have mentioned, only incidental.

Costigan has shown that with access to information, particularly financial information, one can use sophisticated cross-checking facilities to build a picture of organised crime. This is an intelligence gathering and processing mechanism. It does, however, require invasion of privacy and some coercive powers, for example, to force the production of documents. Costigan and other royal commissioners have found that to test theories or complete a picture some power to compulsorily elicit answers is necessary. The work of these royal commissions, however, although informative, does not appear to have significantly reduced organised crime. They have not often led to successful prosecutions against crime heads and they have not often led to the recovery or illicitly obtained financial gains.

Therefore a crimes commission, to fulfil its role of suppressing organised crime, must have power and responsibility not only to gather intelligence but also to provide that intelligence to a prosecuting authority in an evidentiary form. It should not be forgotten that the power to use in subsequent prosecutions and civil litigations the information which an authority gains by the intrusion into privacy and loss of traditional safeguards is therefore also a critical part of the balance that must be reached in this debate. That balance , as I have indicated, is found in this report. I will look briefly at both sides of the scale in my short contribution, commencing with some of the protections that have been retained by the Committees recommendations. Firstly, coercive powers can be exercised only by the Authority when it is acting pursuant to a specific term of reference, in other words, something similar to a royal commission situation. There must be a decision by government that a particular target should be investigated or pursued. In exercising coercive powers the Authority should not be able to roam free and wide. Senator Chipp mentioned the evidence that was put before the Committee by Mr Justice Nicholson . I know some argue to the contrary, as did my colleague Senator Missen today, that this is too restrictive. However, I remind the Senate that whenever the Authority is pursuing identified organised crime, that is, organised crime that has been identified by the police or perhaps by itself and for which a reference has been given, there is no such restriction in the Committees' recommendations. Where the Authority is simply building intelligence at a pre-reference stage it appears that these coercive powers are unnecessary and as my approach is to give coercive powers which breach traditional freedoms only when necessary, I am satisfied that the right balance has been found.

Secondly, the Authority will not be able to carry on public inquisitions which have the potential detrimentally to affect reputations on hearsay evidence or less. This is an investigatory body, not a court. If it gathers sufficient evidence a person may be put on trial and the importance of public scrutiny of trials should remain. I know there is some opinion to the contrary-it was put by my colleague Senator Missen-but I would have thought that the public exhibitions of some American crimes commissions would have been adequate warning for this Senate to be very cautious about adopting such a methodology. In the hunt, and it is a hunt-that was the language used by counsel assisting the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union- and when there is insufficient evidence to prosecute but when a crimes commission is sure a party is guilty, and no doubt according to human nature that will be the case on some occasions, there is a temptation to warn the public through public examination of the party which is thought to be guilty. To me, that is totally undesirable.

Thirdly, there is protection in that the Authority itself cannot prosecute. It may pursue a matter to the stage of preparing a brief for prosecution or action for recovery but it will be up to the Director of Public Prosecutions, after independent assessment, whether such actions will proceed. Fourthly, there is the protection of the right not to answer incriminatory questions or to provide personal records that will be self-incriminatory. These protections will remain. In fact the Committee's recommendation is that such safeguards as appear in the legislation should be further strengthened. What should be given is a derivative use indemnity so that a person's statement may not only not be used against him but also evidence derived from those statements should not be so used.

Fifthly, as a further protection the Committee has advocated streamlined procedure to a judge where it would be claimed that the Authority is acting illegally or beyond its power or is otherwise abusing its responsibility. I believe that this will offer more real protection than the judicial audit which is proposed in the legislation and which is, I think on the evidence before us, an impossible responsibility for a judge to be given. It could amount to considerable obstruction to the work of the Authority and is also more effective than the protection offered in the legislation by the investigations of the Ombudsman. To have the Ombudsman investigating the activities of the National Crime Authority is inappropriate. The Ombudsman is concerned with administrative irregularities of the bureaucracy, not the operation of the criminal investigatory system. Additionally, there has been some call for a parliamentary committee to scrutinise this matter but again it appears that such a committee would suffer from the same deficiencies as a judicial audit. The best protection , I contend, is that which we advocate, a streamlined procedure to a judge when a breach is alleged.

Sixthly, the Committee calls for a provision in similar terms to that in section 6A (3) of the Royal Commissions Act. If a person is charged with an offence and that offence is not finally disposed of he may refuse to produce a document or answer a question on the grounds of self-incrimination. Seventhly, this will be a Commonwealth funded authority created under Commonwealth law with accountability to the Commonwealth Parliament. Thus there will be a clear line of responsibility, the opportunity to debate reports, the opportunity to use the Estimates committees and the other protections that this Parliament offers which should not be underestimated.

Eighthly, the Authority retains legal professional privilege although some have advocated its abolition. The Committee believes there has been gross exaggeration in claims that the Authority can shield criminal abuses. Ninthly, in the Bill, part of which we do not oppose, is the existence of a sunset provision so that at least, after a specified period, the operation of the Authority and its effectiveness will have to be debated again in this Parliament .
Tenthly, the Committee has made it clear that there must not be interference by Ministers in the operation of particular references and that any general guidelines must be tabled in the Parliament.

Therefore, it is submitted that on the one hand the Committee has been particularly conscious of its responsibilities to protect civil liberties and to protect as much as possible privacy. On the other hand, as I have indicated, the Committee believes it has provided on balance an authority which is able to do its job and which has the potential to be effective. I will run through the reasons why I have reached that conclusion because they will be important in the debate which will follow.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator HILL

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting, I was about to proceed with my balancing exercise to list the powers which the National Crime Authority would be given if our report were to be adopted, powers which I believe would adequately enable it to meet its responsibility of suppressing organised crime in this country. First, it will have access to Government held records and information. It will have the power to gain that information and there will be an obligation on agencies to provide it. Second, it will have access to taxation records to the extent of tax breaches at its ordinary level of operation and other criminal breaches when investigating under a term of reference and it will be able to use those records and information arising therefrom in subsequent prosecutions and civil actions. In passing, I must concede that by preference I would have gone further and not distinguished tax records from other government- held records, but that is just a personal preference and not held sufficiently strongly to dissent on that point.

INTERJECT.PARA: Third, it will have access to all business records on a warrant. To that extent , the right to plead self-incrimination will be abrogated and such information may be used in a prosecution. Fourth, it will be able to compel incriminatory testimony and production of personal records when a use derivative-use indemnity is given. It must be remembered that it is not the principals who are normally called to give evidence, it is a matter of building evidence against the principals and the testimony of the peripheral players becomes vital. Therefore, this point is particularly important. Fifth, it will be able to set up multidisciplinary task forces to assist with its investigations; for example, lawyers, accountants, financiers, computer experts and police officers. Sixth, it will be able to build intelligence and conduct preliminary investigations with task forces without any need for a reference. If a reference is then sought and not given it can report accordingly. Seventh, it will be able to conduct Commonwealth initiated references without the need for the States to consent.

When I first debated this subject in this chamber some 18 months ago in relation to the previous Government's Bill, it appeared obvious to me that for the Authority to work to its maximum capacity and effectiveness the co-operation of the States is desirable. The National Crime Authority Bill does contain a formula for participation by the States in joint references and participation should be encouraged. It is worth noting that Royal Commissioner Costigan claims now to be receiving support from all the States. Eighth, a reference cannot be withdrawn without an affirmative resolution of both Houses of the Federal Parliament so there cannot be Government interference in that regard. Ninth, the definition of organised crime or relevant offences is to be expanded so that a form of organised crime not now recognised would not be excluded. For example, arson did not appear in the Bill that was before the Senate. Furthermore, whereas the intergovernmental committee is to take into account whether ordinary police methods might prove effective, that will not now be a final determinant. Of course, duplication remains undesirable.

Tenth, we have recommended a simplification of the summons to give evidence. The detail to be provided appears to be a practical hindrance-that is, the detail that was provided for in the Government's Bill-serving little purpose. It was said to be protective, but in our judgment it was really only cumbersome. To give simply the terms of reference to a prospective witness appeared to us to be sufficient. Eleventh, a corporation may be compelled to produce a document so that the common law privilege against self-incrimination which appears to extend to companies would be abrogated. Twelfth, we have simplified the procedures for production of documents. Thirteenth, we have provided that the privilege of self -incrimination is not available for civil remedies; that is, we are extending the provisions that presently exist under the Royal Commissions Act. Fourteenth, we have provided for greater flexibility with regard to search warrants. One can seize material wanted for investigations as well as a prosecution and the Authority is given more time and greater flexibility in the execution of such warrants.

Fifteenth, we provide for power to apply to a judicial officer for a warrant to arrest where there are reasonable grounds for believing that the person is about to leave Australia to avoid giving evidence to the Authority. Finally, we allow the Authority public sittings in order that it might, when necessary, educate the public as to a particular form of organised criminal activity. Therefore, it appears to me and it appears to the majority of the Committee, in fact all but my colleague Senator Missen, that we have found the balance, that we have breached fundamental safeguards and privacy no more than is absolutely necessary . Nevertheless, we have advocated a structure for authority, advocated the establishment of a body that has considerable power and authority and responsibility to match. It appears to us that it will have greater potential to offer a real restraint upon organised crime than anything we have seen hitherto in this country.

When I commenced my speech I said that I would make reference to several matters that I think are deserving of further consideration in the future. One is the area of law reform. Law reform is not a major function of the proposed Crimes Authority although it has power under our recommendations to make recommendations itself when it appears desirable to do so. However, it appears to me that there is a need to further assess in that regard the role of the Australian Institute of Criminology which has not been dealt with in our report. There is the need to investigate further the questions of the value of illegality of SP bookmaking. We are advised that this provides the cash flow for much of Australia's organised crime and, to a lesser extent, the criminality of prostitution, marihuana and also our existing pornography laws. I remind the Senate that Mr Justice Kirby, apart from others, has questioned the role played by relatively minor criminality as the feedstock for organised crime. In the report we mention the desirability of investigating new laws, particularly dealing with such matters as interstate trafficking. There are American precedents in this regard that are worth consideration. Laws which permit better recovery of illicit gains should also be considered. We need also to look at ways in which existing legislation facilitates organised crime.

I know Mr Ralph Jacobi, the honourable member for Hawker who was listening to the debate in this chamber before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, has gone so far as to advocate a crime impact study with new Bills. These sorts of matters should receive further consideration. On that subject we have been told that recent changes in the foreign exchange regulations, although they may be soundly based in economic policy, will facilitate organised crime; for example, in the moving of funds overseas for the purchase of heroin.

The second area which I believe is deserving of further consideration over a period is the role, structure and functioning of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. It has taken some time to get going. It is now getting more support from the States and State police forces and is contributing to breaking down the barriers between the various State law enforcement bodies. It is now getting into gear with the use of more sophisticated equipment. I know it is often said that we should compare what Costigan has achieved with what the ABCI has achieved. But for a fair comparison one could also look at the differences in resources, both financial and in personal expertise, that have been made available. I believe for the time being that both bodies should be encouraged to develop in tandem and that they should be encouraged to develop a close working relationship and trust. An assessment should be made in future years as to the role of both. I must confess that I believe in due course some form of amalgamation of the two bodies will probably prove to be the most desirable course open. I want to mention something which is in the report; that is, for the Authority to work totally effectively there will be need for complementary State legislation regarding coercive powers. I hope that will be given early consideration by the States.

I also want to mention one part of the report with which I am not entirely happy; that is, the recommendation in paragraph 6.26 in relation to confidentiality. I know that it caused my colleague Senator Lewis considerable anguish. He has dissented in relation to that provision. I am not sure that I totally agree with his dissent. I tend to the view that evidence given in confidence should be so respected by the commission. If there is to be a proviso to that confidentiality the witness should be so made aware before he answers the questions. If it is desired that he be called to give evidence and to repeat that which he has given in confidence in a subsequent prosecution this should occur only if he is prepared to abrogate that confidence and his statement is made available to the defence. I know that this may be regarded as somewhat restrictive but I believe if the commission is to achieve the stature desirable some sacrifice of efficiency might be necessary. I raise it as a matter which I think is worth further consideration.

Finally, in settng up a crimes commission we should not forget the underlying social issues that have enabled organised crime to thrive-for example, problems that lead the young to drug dependence. High unemployment rates come immediately to mind. The breakdowns that have occurred in the codes of ethical behaviour which lead professionals, lawyers, accountants and bankers to facilitate the activities of criminals require further consideration. If we are to commence a new and more effective attack on organised crime a crimes commission should be complementary to a more enthusiastic and effective attack upon the social circumstances which, in many cases, lead otherwise unlikely participants into criminal activity. Without such participants organised crime will not exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the fact that so many Government senators have answered the call. I do not wish to speak at length on the report on the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 which has just been put down by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. No doubt Government senators will be anxious to hear Senator Crowley, who is to be the next speaker. Everybody taking part in this debate is justifiably very pleased with the results of the exercise which has been conducted by this Committee. Even the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has responded in terms which Senator Chipp described as 'generous' to a report which suggests a very substantial amendment to the Government's Bill. However, I wish to remind the Senate that on 17 November 1983 when the Senate was debating this Bill and the Opposition suggested that the Bill was defective and required committee consideration it received an extremely ungracious reception from the Attorney-General and, indeed, from a number of Government senators. I do not wish to quote from what was a rather unpleasant debate. Senator Chipp will remember, for example, some of the rather unflattering remarks that were made about journalists in the National Times of whom he thinks a great deal. I do not wish to go over a lot of old ground but I want to remind the Senate that, among other things, on 17 November the Attorney-General said, when he was objecting to the Opposition's attempt to send this matter to a committee:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no excuse whatsoever for the change of attitude that has been demonstrated here other than a willingness at all costs, irresponsibly, to score political points and to obstruct for its own sake.

The idea of Senate obstruction is something about which we hear a great deal from the Government when the Opposition, the Australian Democrats or Senator Harradine raise some matters which are not to the Government's liking. When later in that debate we were taken to a vote the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Tate, Senator Crowley, Senator Cook and the Attorney-General himself all voted against the reference to the Senate committee. I believe that they were opposing that because they saw a political point in not having the reference to a Senate committee. They were acting more in accord with the Attorney-General's own criticism than was the Opposition or the Australian Democrats. The important point-

TALK.START.PARA: —They are bound by Caucus.

—As Senator Peter Rae has said, they are bound by Caucus. For all I know Senator Tate, Senator Crowley and others may have thought that the reference to a Senate committee was a very good idea. But the key point is that once again the value of parliamentary consideration has been demonstrated. I have joined the debate in part to congratulate the Senate Committee for the fact that, true to the general traditions which have been established in this place, it has been able sensibly to consider the evidence which has been brought forward and, to a very large extent, arrive at a common view as to what the form of the legislation should be. I want to remind the Senate and the public-to the very limited extent that Hansard gets read by those outside this Parliament-that this was a case of what was described as Senate obstruction. What we have here is a Senate committee report which unanimously says that there should be substantial amendments to this legislation to make it workable. The Attorney- General has indicated that he thinks it likely that the Government will accept, or will not find it difficult to accept, many of the Committee's suggestions. Yet the same suggestions, when they were made by the Opposition, were pooh- poohed and abused by the Attorney-General, who claimed that the Senate was acting in an obstructive manner.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government plays its Senate obstruction card it will be important for the people of Australia to remember that when the Senate challenges the Government's legislation very often there is a benign result. I believe, for example, that the threat that we made in this Senate-a threat between the Australian Democrats and the Opposition-that we would delay the assets test legislation until February was a threat which has served the people of Australia well. That piece of Senate obstruction resulted in the Government having time to have a second look and second thoughts. In February the rather churlish Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who had been so critical of the Senate, admitted that the Government had got it wrong. That was a classic example of the Senate doing its job and doing it properly. This exercise, which has culminated in this report which was put down this afternoon, is another classic example of the Senate doing the job for which it was established. It has established that legislation brought into this place by the Government is defective and in need of substantial amendment. I agree with Senator Hill, who spoke earlier in the debate, that this report once again vindicates the role of the Senate.

The Opposition expects the Senate to continue to exercise its constitutional function in this way. It believes that that is in the interests of Australia. It objects to the categorising of such action as obstruction, which is the usual action of a government when it is faced by this sort of Senate action when in fact the results are so generally benign. In this case we have had the ready admission by the Attorney-General, who was so churlish on 17 November 1983, that this is a report which is valuable and which will be able to improve the legislation.

The legislation hung in the balance for some time. Some honourable senators were concerned about the urgency of the need to establish the crimes authority as against the remedying of the defects that many of us thought existed with respect to the legislation. I am pleased that the doubts which many of us felt and expressed have been vindicated by the very careful work of the Committee, which has acted in a splendid bipartisan fashion and in a way which I believe is typical of the best work which is done in this place. Again I thank and congratulate those honourable senators from the Australian Labor Party, the Democrats and the Liberal Party of Australia who have performed such a signal service. I think it is important to note that organised crime has been exposed as a very significant problem in Australia. The ability of this authority to act independently and effectively was very limited. I hope we will now see effective legislation put in place without delay. I hope we will see an effective crimes authority put in place without delay. I believe if that is done all of those honourable senators who have played such an effective role in this committee will have performed a very great service for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it timely that I should be able to follow Senator Chaney in this debate partly because of the stage he has set. I guess his speech was along the analogous line of, thanks, but no thanks. I will resist the temptation to find some very good analogies in medicine about what is a real obstruction and what is only hot air.
—Ha, ha!

—I welcome Senator Lewis's laughter. On the one hand I think the points that Senator Chaney alluded to are important but on the other hand it could be asked at what stage people are said to be churlish and at what stage we require the Senate to reflect seriously on the matters before it. It is certainly true that this Government introduced its own crimes authority Bill because it was not satisfied with the Bill as proposed, but never commissioned, by the previous Government. It is quite clear that on this terribly important issue there has been considerable thought and rethinking.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose it could be said that Senator Chaney is able to address the Senate with his remarks tonight with the wisdom of hindsight. Of course, he also has the benefit of the quite splendid report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It might be that he anticipated the remarkable contribution that Senator Chipp and myself are going to make to the Standing Committee. This is a point with which I am sure Senator Chipp will not disagree. In fact, the point is well made-if not nicely laboured at this stage-that people 's views of things do change from time to time. I guess the Senate and, no doubt , the people of Australia, will benefit from that consideration. I suppose I could finally ask Senator Chaney which issues the Senate Committee needs to reflect seriously on, and which not. Again, that is a matter of distinctions drawn from time to time in this place. I guess there is no objective requirement . It could be said that when it is felt that one can win the argument then one puts up the arguments for it. However, I still feel that having been part of the Committee and having seen the report there is no doubt there is consensus and agreement in the Senate that the Committee has produced a splendid document and, I think, made a very fine contribution to the debate in this whole area.

Before I proceed with a few comments I too take the opportunity to thank the Chairman of the Committee. I think Senator Tate portrayed a fine grace and tolerance in the chair under considerable time constraints, which were constantly challenged further by the propensity of all Committee members to contribute to the discussion. I also thank the support staff and even draw the attention of the Senate to Senator Tate's thanks to the word processors. I can certainly assure the Senate that the word processors as well as the people operating them have worked overtime in the last few weeks. I thank, too, my Senate colleagues from all sides of this chamber-even the lawyers- for an interesting and effectual committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never quite patronised us.

—We were a very good combination in beating off patronage. The point I wish to raise concerning the debate on the name of the authority has been alluded to by other honourable senators. I certainly raised my opposition to the organisation being called a commission, largely because I think it could carry in the minds of the Australian people some sense of royal commissions and the powers attached to them. I think the Crime Authority needs to be clearly distinguished in its powers and its functions from any sense of the continuation of any royal commission, and in particular in this case the Costigan Royal Commisison on the Activities of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Therefore, for the record, I comment that I would be quite happy for the organisation to remain as an authority, so as to make clear that distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point I wish to remark on concerns the debate around the withdrawal of reference title. I am not unhappy with the amendments and the recommendations that are put in the report in relation to the debate about the withdrawal of reference. It seemed very important, once the Authority had been given a reference and the attached extra special powers that went with such a reference, that any attempt to withdraw that reference from the Authority ought to be done very cautiously. However, I feel that of the two points in the discussion one that has been a little lost in the discussion of this matter in the Committee report should be highlighted. Principally people were concerned that the Authority could in any way be open to parliamentary intrusion and that in any attempt to withdraw a reference it ought to be quite clear that it was not being done by the Government with any intention to interfere in the operations of the Authority. The independence of the Authority was a matter of prime importance. That was agreed to by every member of the Committee. The recommendation requires that for a reference to be withdrawn there needs to be affirmative resolution of both Houses of the Parliament.

However, I think another point needs to be noted. Sometimes the Government may wish to withdraw a reference for entirely appropriate reasons. We had before the Committee much evidence that suggested there was sometimes a temptation, in pursuing criminal behaviour, for the hunter to forget restraint in terms of civil liberties and appropriate behaviour when seeking information. We had evidence given to us too of the importance of being able to withdraw a reference ; in other words, that it would be right and responsible for the Government from time to time to judge that the continuing pursuit of information in certain areas was inappropriate. Entirely properly the Government could do that. I am concerned that that dimension of the withdrawal of reference has been lost in the debate. However, on reflection, I think the proposal that the Government justify a withdrawal of terms of reference before the two Houses of Parliament by an affirmative resolution of both Houses of Parliament, which would only follow if the Government was able to convince both Houses of Parliament, seems to be a satisfactory way of dealing with that difficulty.

I think the report has proposed a number of points of clarification for the operations of the Authority. I feel that this is probably the most important way in which the Committee has contributed to the discussion and to the prospects of this Bill. It has done so not so much by dramatic change but by clearly defining or suggesting that clear definition in certain areas of powers of responsibilities of other definitions is the greatest contribution I think of the Senate report. I do not suppose that that could be more appropriately and clearly spelt out than it was by Senator Hill in his recent contribution.

One further point I wanted to raise was that matter also raised by Senator Hill concerning the law reform function which is limited. It has been proposed that the law reform proposals would be limited to the range of matters arising out of the performance of the Authority and its functions under a reference, or perhaps in its ordinary functions. The Authority is not to be seen as a major law reform organisation. However, I think it is important to highlight the point that has been raised by Mr Jacobi in previous discussions and which was mentioned by Senator Hill. That concerned the prospect of a crime impact study. It may not be an appropriate requirement of the Authority to require crime impact studies. But it may well be that in describing or pointing to the possibilities of law reform in certain areas, particularly where criminal activity has been allowed to range , a crime impact study would bracket well with the proposals for law reform. It may also be that it is a matter that ought to be taken up in other fora because quite clearly under some legislation, if not in the planning at least in its implementation, some white collar crime in particular has been allowed to flourish. So I draw attention to to the need for and the possibility of the crime impact study being something that the Authority might from time to time allude to or make reference to.

I contributed to this report in a small dissenting report because I felt very importantly at difference with the majority report about the importance of accountability of the Authority. I admit the proposals for accountability that were in the original Bill and which I support at least in a modified form are only of limited effect. I feel still that with an authority that will be given the powers of such significance that are being given to this Authority under the proposals in the Bill there needs to be clear statements of public accountability. Unlike I think everybody else on the Committee, I do not regard the Commonwealth Ombudsman as someone who comes in and fiddles about, if I might use something approximating a quotation of what Senator Chipp has said. In fact, I feel the Ombudsman has become widely accepted by the community and has become identified as a supporter or campaigner for the ordinary citizen, particularly against bureaucracies, institutions, or the weight of anachronistic regulations. I think that the Ombudsman having a role in the overview of this Authority would be well received by the community at large.

I would not necessarily expect the Ombudsman to deal with grievances of individuals in the course of an inquiry, but I think the Ombudsman having a role of overview and the possibility of sometimes taking up action on behalf of a citizen is very important. It is certainly a role which I am happy to support and unashamedly have written so in my dissenting report. I feel that in some ways the Ombudsman is still doing battle to be taken seriously in a world populated by lawyers. For that reason I find it quite interesting that Senator Chipp does not approve of the Ombudsman's role in this Authority. I do not take it that Senator Chipp is opposed to the Ombudsman, but rather that he is opposed to the suggestions of how the Ombudsman could operate under the terms of this Bill. For myself, I still feel the Ombudsman's role is a very important one and is principally one of spokesman for the ordinary person in this community.

The other point on accountability refers to the judicial audit. Unlike my colleagues, I have more concern about a judge taking charge or inquiring into any of these matters than I do about the Ombudsman doing so. That may well be due to my non-legal experience or background. But I feel that we cannot establish an authority with such a responsibility as this, with such powers as this, yet not have some dimension of requirement for accountability. Senator Hill highlighted very well the structural proposals that will in fact have an inbuilt accountability throughout the functions of the Authority and I am very much in sympathy with all of that, but I still feel that I would want to support the need for some kind of audit of the Authority external to the Authority itself. There will be the annual report by the Authority, but I feel further to that there should be something approximating an external annual report.

I am not suggesting that the terms of the judicial audit clause in the Bill as it now stands are what I necessarily would argue to the wall for; in fact, I am quite happy that the summary applications process for people who have grievances would deal very nicely with clause 47 (2). But I still feel that there should be an overview of the general activities of the Authority by somebody external or more than one body external to the Authority itself. I feel that that would be well managed by the proposals for the Ombudsman and the judicial audit. I do not believe it is necessary for either of those two people or groups of people to so scrabble around or fiddle around within the Authority as to upset its operations . We did receive evidence from a number of people, including Mr Costigan, that such investigation would hamper the actions of the Authority, but that is no more than what I would expect such people to say. In some ways anybody checking on and inquiring into the program of the operations of an authority is likely in some way to interfere. That is, I think, exactly what we would be requiring of somebody who was to make a statement of accountability to the public.

Finally, I am happy to say that there is not a proposal to establish a parliamentary or Senate committee to oversee or review the work of the Authority . I am pleased that that was not a recommendation of the Committee and spoke against it. I think that the Parliament in its ordinary operations will be able to examine the Authority's annual report and, if my dissenting report should win out, the Ombudsman's report and the judicial audit report. In that way the Parliament would closely follow the performance of the Authority and at the same time be appropriately distant and therefore independent in its appraisal. I think the people through the Parliament would have more than sufficient channels for checking on an authority with the powers and the importance proposed for this Authority. At this stage, Madam Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANNED AND FROZEN VEGETABLES (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1984CANNED AND FROZEN VEGETABLES (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1984HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1984HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1984APPLE AND PEAR LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1984DRIED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 March, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
Madam Deputy President, I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
CANNED AND FROZEN VEGETABLES (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1984
The purpose of this Bill is to impose a charge on canned or frozen fruit or vegetables in respect of which an export permit has been granted under the Export Control (General) Regulations.
The Government's intent in imposing this charge is to recoup, in accordance with announced policy, 50 per cent of the costs associated with the export inspection of these products.

The Bill sets a maximum rate of charge for canned or frozen fruit or vegetables of six-tenths of a cent per kilogram. An operative rate of charge will be set by regulations and, it is intended, will be half this maximum rate, that is, three- tenths of a cent per kilogram.

This rate of charge is substantially lower than that indicated to industry as the likely charge level in the Minister's public announcement last December. The reason for the change is that the Department of Primary Industry which has the direct conduct of inspection of these products will be moving as a matter of priority to modify current inspection practices in this field. One result of these modifications will be a considerable reduction in the inspection costs associated with the products. Departmental estimates are that the cost of the revised inspection regime would have been $519,000 if the regime had applied throughout 1983-84 and the operative rate of charge has been devised on the basis that, if the revised regime and the charge had applied throughout 1983-84, half this cost would have been recouped.
It is the Government's intention to have the charge in operation from 1 April 1984. On this programming, it is expected that actual collections in 1983-84 will amount to approximately $40,000.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
CANNED AND FROZEN VEGETABLES (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1984
The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the collection of the charge to be imposed by the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984.

The Bill follows the usual pattern of such collection legislation and deals with such matters as the due date for payment, recovery of unpaid charge, penalty for non-payment, offences, access to premises, review of decisions and the making of regulations to establish the collection procedures in greater detail.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1984
The purpose of this Bill and the associated Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984 is to impose and collect a charge for the export inspection of honey.
Government policy is to recoup 50 per cent of the cost of providing export inspection of primary produce.

Legislation to impose such a charge on honey was introduced by the previous Government in March 1982. The Senate referred those Bills to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations which reported in May 1982.

The Senate Committee's central recommendation was that the then current honey export inspection procedures be abandoned and replaced by a system of limited random sampling and testing by the Department of Primary Industry.

On the basis of the Committee's report and its recommendations the Bills were not proceeded with. In addition the then Government undertook to reassess the question of honey export inspection as part of a broader review of export inspection activities that was then underway.

As a result of this review, the export inspection of honey is to change from 1 October 1984. The new regime will be substantially in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee in that it involves a system of limited random sampling and testing of honey prior to export.
There is general industry support for continued Commonwealth export inspection of honey. I am aware, however, that some people have reservations on the level of charges that should apply.

It is proposed that each honey export establishment should be given an inspection classification according to its performance in meeting export standards, and that the intensity of export inspection effort be related to the inspection classifications. Initially it is proposed that all export establishments should be accorded normal inspection but that this would be subsequently reviewed and the intensity of inspection then related to the quality of the export product. The level of charge will then be based on the inspection effort involved.
The criteria used in classifying establishments will be published in a set of Honey Orders under the provisions of the Export Control Act 1982.

Pending the full implementation of new inspection arrangements the Government has decided to introduce a uniform charge of $4.70 per tonne with a target date of 1 April 1984. This charge is based on the estimated costs of export inspection under the new regime which are lower than current inspection costs. When the new inspection regime is fully operational, charges are expected to vary from $2 to $12 per tonne of honey depending on the record of performance of individual packers. The Bill provides a maximum rate of $24 per tonne.
The charge is to apply to all honey for which an export permit has been issued.
Other recommendations contained in the Senate Committee's report have been fully considered in the overall review of export inspection.

The question of the need for an export permit has been examined closely by the Department of Primary Industry and has been found to be necessary for the effective administration of the new export inspection system. The requirement for a permit is the only basis on which any form of control over exports can be established and is the means wherby the Customs Service is assured that a particular consignment complies with the regulatory requirements and may be exported.

In relation to the issue of a ''Certificate in Respect of Honey'', the feasibility of issuing this at the same time as the export permit and other export documentation is under examination. It is anticipated, however, that in general it will be the responsibility of the exporter to obtain analytical certificates from a National Association of Testing Authorities accredited laboratory to meet importing country requirements for detailed chemical analyses .
The Department of Primary Industry will continue to inspect and register premises used for the packing and storage of export honey.

Honourable senators will be aware that the Industries Assistance Commission is currently undertaking an inquiry into whether assistance should be granted to the honey industry. It is proposed that a review of the Australian Honey Board be undertaken in the light of the Commission's report.

Honey is one of the few commodities that up until now has avoided a charge for export inspection. This Bill and the associated Collection Bill establish the basis for a fair and equitable system for charging for export inspection and will provide a mechanism for implementing the Government's policy of recovering 50 per cent of the cost of providing an export inspection service for honey.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1984
This Bill is associated with the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984 just introduced. It is designed to provide for the collection of charges proposed in that Bill.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
APPLE AND PEAR LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1984

The purpose of the Bill is to correct certain anomalies relating to the imposition of the apple and pear levy under the Apple and Pear Levy Act 1976. The apple and pear levy is imposed on the production and sale of apples and pears and provides funds for the operation of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation.

Under the present provisions of the Act, apples and pears distilled to produce beverage products such as pear brandy, are liable for levy at the processing rate rather than the considerable lower juicing rate. This is considered inappropriate as the returns paid to growers by processors for fruit used for distillation purposes are well below those paid for processing quality fruit and are more in line with the lower returns paid for juicing quality fruit. This Bill provides for fruit used for distillation purposes to be levied at the juicing rate.

The Bill also provides for fresh pears used for drying to be exempt from the apple and pear levy to take account of amendments proposed as part of the provisions of the concurrent Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill. Under the provisions of this Bill fresh pears used for drying purposes will now be subject to the dried fruits levy. It is not proposed to exempt fresh apples delivered for drying from the apple and pear levy as dried apples, unlike dried pears, are not defined as a dried tree fruit under the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971.
Commencement of the Bill is on 1 January 1985, prior to the beginning of the next apple and pear season.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DRIED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1984

The purpose of the Bill is to correct certain anomalies relating to the imposition of the dried fruit levies imposed by the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971, to increase the maximum permissible rates and to simplify administration. The levies are imposed on dried fruits of a season received for packing, and provide funds for the operation of the dried fruits research scheme established by the Dried Fruits Research Act 1971.

Under the present Levy Act, fresh fruits delivered for drying purposes are in practice not subject to levy. Fresh pears delivered for drying are, however, subject to levy under the Apple and Pear Levy Act 1976, even though moneys raised by the latter levy are not applied for the benefit of dried pears. This Bill provides for fresh fruits delivered for drying purposes to be subject to the dried fruits levy through amendment of the definition of ''received for packing''. This change is complemented by the provisions of the concurrent Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill 1984, which propose exemptions of fresh pears delivered for drying from levy under the Apple and Pear Levy Act 1976.

The Bill provides for an increase in the maximum levy rates for dried vine fruits and dried tree fruits. These increases were recommended by the Australian Dried Fruits Association, which represents 95 per cent of producers, and by the Dried Fruits Research Committee. Doubling the maximum rates of levy is expected to avoid for several years any need for further amendment to the legislation to provide for levy increase.
The opportunity provided by the introduction of this Bill is being taken to make other relatively minor amendments of an administrative nature.

Commencement of this Bill is to be on the day which it receives Royal Assent. Provision is made for the amendment of the definition of ''received for packing' ' to apply first to dried fruits of the season commencing on 1 January 1985.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I address myself to the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill, the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, the Honey ( Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill, the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill and the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill. Madam Deputy President, I should indicate to you that the Opposition intends to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of four of the Bills and asks that consideration of these Bills be divided, with the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill 1984 and the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984 being considered separately from the other four Bills. I have spoken to the Minister and he has agreed that that would be satisfactory.

—Thank you, Senator Scott. Is it the wish of the Senate that the questions be divided and that the question regarding the second reading of the first four Bills be first determined, followed by the question that the remaining two Bills be read a second time? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANNED AND FROZEN VEGETABLES (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1984CANNED AND FROZEN VEGETABLES (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1984HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1984HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1984

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984, the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984, the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984 and the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984 be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out the words after 'That' and insert:

'the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984, Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984, Honey ( Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984, and the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984 be withdrawn until the various Committees enquiring have reported, and the Government has considered these reports and, in consultation with the industry, has come to a final resolution'.

Those committees that have been investigating export inspection in these various industries have reached a certain stage. The Industries Assistance Commission report, which refers chiefly to financing and marketing arrangements, has been out in draft form for some time. Of course, the final report is not yet to hand and consequently cannot be acted upon. It is my information that the inquiry by the Department of Primary Industry into quality assurance has been in the hands of the Export Inspection Service and that its views were sent to the industry in the December-January period. I understand that the industry has sent back its comments, that ministerial orders will be sent to industry for its comments within the next two weeks and that its views have to be received back by 1 July. It seemed to me in this circumstance that the Government would allow this amendment to delay the legislation until it had been able to finalise the position with the industry in the export inspection area, which is a very difficult and somewhat confused area at this stage, and had come to that finality having at its fingertips the views of the committee involved and of the industry's representatives. I note that when the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin) spoke on this matter in the other place on 7 March he said, among other things:
Should the IAC recommend in its final report that some form of assistance to the industry is justified, in accordance with normal procedures this will be considered by the Government.

That clearly indicates to me at least and to the Opposition that the Minister and the Government will seek to take that responsible line when the results of these investigations are finally to hand. We seek this delay only because of the somewhat significant confusion that there seems to be about so many things referable to inspection in these areas. They include the following questions: To what extent is inspection necessary? Which countries require it and which do not ? Should it therefore be available to some or to all? A whole range of matters seem to be somewhat indecisive and if they are acted upon at this stage of knowledge they might well produce unfortunate, costly and perhaps inefficient results.

The legislation seeks to impose an inspection charge on selling for export. But it contains an extraordinary range of costs, from $2 to $3 a tonne for reduced intensity of inspection, to $4 to $5 a tonne for normal inspection and as high as $11 or $12 a tonne for tightened inspections. I understand that at this stage there is to be a single rate of $4.70. But it will be quite as simple as that because I further understand that, if the Government finds that it needs $x from the industry to fulfil its part of the inspection cost, it will be able to rearrange the charges through the packing houses. So the $4.70 may be a somewhat uncertain charge. All this inspection is to happen at this stage. That is to say , these charges are to occur regardless of the quality or efficiency of the job or of the capacity of the industry involved to pay. There is a further anomaly, it seems, in that a flagfall of $10 is to apply. That will apply to the smallest producer as it will apply to the largest. This seems to me to be a not entirely fair arrangement. These are just one or two of the matters that need to be resolved.

There are a number of others. The reports which we have not seen but which will be available to the Minister and to the industry may indicate answers in a number of fields. For instance, how widespread is the demand for an inspection service? Indeed, to what extent can an industry become self-regulating? That may well be an excellent method, because any export industry which is not prepared to regulate its product and to identify and define it accurately will succeed in having a market for only a very short time. Should there be a flagfall or an ad valorem charge? Should packing houses, et cetera, be licensed? Would random testing be successful, efficient and the most economical measure? All these matters, including the number of inspectors that might reasonably be expected to be used on the job, have to be resolved. I assume that the inquiries which have been proceeding and which have now moved very close to finality will contain answers to most of these questions.

Clearly we have to observe certain standards for health reasons. I guess that there has to be an identification of the water content and sugar content in honey, for instance. But as I said a moment ago, these standards may well be met by self-regulation which may not require the impost of $4.70 a tonne which is proposed at the moment. For canned and frozen vegetables the charge is to be 0. 3c per kilogram. As I understand it, the industry is opposed to this sort of charge, at least at that rate.
