It is an industry in considerable difficulties at this moment. It has all sorts of market problems. It has been operating a tree pulling exercise-its position is as severe as that-and, of course, overseas prices are low. There is certainly no export incentive.

In this field the formation of quality assurance schemes has been a hopeful area of development. Indeed, that area has been observed by the Export Inspection Service. The final result of its propositions regarding quality assurance, and of the Minister's and the industry's consideration of it, as I understand it, are to be available by 1 July. At that time a very clear indication of the type of inspection service that is necessary, of its cost, of the best way to finance it and so on will be available. Presumably and hopefully , both the Government and the industry will be satisfied with the result of all these matters. It could well be that random sampling several times a year may be sufficient. But these are determinations. That sort of thing, as I understand, applies in New Zealand to quite some degree and has obviously been found to be effective. Whatever the case may be, it is to be hoped that these industries, which have very significant fights on their hands, both as a result of seasonal conditions and as a result of difficult overseas market circumstances, will find that they can expand, quite significant overseas demand.

The Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill 1984 and the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984 are Bills which the Opposition does not oppose. At present, pears attract, as I understand it, one of three levies payable to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation as well as a levy when they are used for drying. The legislation suggests that the pears for drying attract only one fee, that for drying, and also that apples and pears used for distillation attract a levy for juicing of 90c, instead of the existing $1.80. The Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984 makes all the fruit, fresh or dry, attract a levy. As I understand it, the industry supports the measure and the levy involved. These industries certainly need close examination and a real measure of support in this field because, as I said a moment ago, the position of markets and seasons has been further eroded by the entry of Greece into the European Economic Community and is now subject to its Common Agricultural Policy. I hope that the Government will accept the relatively slight delay that would be involved in adopting the amendment that we propose. The delay would enable the Government and the industry to more effectively solve the problems that confront them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- When the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984 and related Bills first came on for debate I was not in the chamber. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) was not aware that a financial impact statement and a couple of other statements were to be incorporated in Hansard. The second reading speeches for the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984, the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984, the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984 and the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984 indicated that the target date for the implementation of these charges was to be 1 April 1984. The Bills were expressed to come into operation on a day fixed by proclamation. Since the announced intended day has now passed, the Government's intention is to have the charges in operation from the earliest feasible date. In regard to the Government's policy-indeed, I think a motion has been moved previously in the Senate that financial impact statements are to accompany Bills-the financial impact statement for the canned and frozen vegetables Bills was included in the second reading speech. In regard to the honey export inspection charges Bills, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the financial impact statement, which I believe has already been circulated. I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the financial impact statement for the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows-
HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) BILL 1984
HONEY (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) COLLECTION BILL 1984
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT

The introduction of the anticipated export inspection charge of $4.70 per tonne for honey would in a full year be expected to bring in a total of $47,000, assuming an export in that year of 10,000 tonnes of honey. 10,000 tonnes is the current estimate by the Department for exports in 1983-84. Exports over the last five years have ranged from 5,487 tonnes to 14,557 tonnes.

This has been calculated on the basis of recovering 50 per cent of the anticipated costs of inspecting honey for export under the new export inspection regime which are estimated to be $94,000 per annum, a significant reduction of the estimated cost of over $150,000 per annum identified by the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in its report on the Honey ( Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982 in May 1982.
The export inspection charge of $4.70 per tonne is approximately 0.5 per cent of the average minimum export price of honey.
DRIED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1984

As the second reading speech indicated, under the present levy Act fresh fruits delivered for drying are not subject to the levy. The change proposed would make levy payable on the dried vine fruits and dried tree fruits produced in a packing house from such fresh fruits.

The main result would be that about 150 tonnes of tunnel dried grapes would now incur levy at $1.00 per tonne. Occasional small quantities of tree fruits dried by a packer would also incur levy-perhaps 4 tonnes of fruit in dried form, with levy at $5.00 per tonne.

The provision for increases in the maximum permissible levy rates for dried vine fruits and dried tree fruits will not affect operative rates of levy. These operative rates have been determined each season, and have been set by regulation under the levy Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the remaining Bill, the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill 1984, there is no financial impact statement because the levy will be paid directly to the Corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984, the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984, the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984, the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1984, the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill 1984 and the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984, which are before us, have had a chequered history. Indeed, they started out with another couple of Bills which still languish somewhere in the House of Representatives. But the Bills which we have before us have something in common with two Bills, one of which has passed the Senate and one of which has been indeed held over until today. They deal with export charges in relation to meat. The reason that the various Bills before us go together is that they share a similar policy basis in the way that the Government is operating. The policy seeks a 50 per cent recovery of the costs involved in the inspection of exports in the primary industry area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have not accepted that as a reasonable policy basis. I think that when one looks at some of the industries that are involved here, for example the dried fruits industry, one can see that it really is not a basis upon which a primary industry is able to operate and that such enormous fluctuations take place in some industries from time to time. For example, the dried fruits industry has had its worst season ever. The outlook for meat is very bad at the moment, and so on. These things change from year to year. It seems to us to be far better to try to marry the recovery rate that one is to set with the current market operation for our exports. So what we are attempting to develop as a matter of policy is a mechanism by which the levy charges can be much more market oriented. In good years we expect that it will be possible to recover possibly more than 50 per cent. But in bad years we believe that in many cases no recovery at all would be an appropriate stance.

If one looks at the international market for most of these commodities, one cannot be at all sanguine in regard to Australia's possibilities in the next few years. We are indeed confronted with very aggressive marketers from other countries who, in their own internal policies, are great supporters of their primary producers. I refer, for example, to the European Economic Community which has an extraordinarily elaborate mechanism to support its own primary producers in such a way that when one looks, for example, at the sugar industry, one finds that indeed the stockpiles available there are of such a magnitude that they could, if they wished, entirely destroy our export markets in that commodity. The EEC only a short time ago went from being a net importer of beef to a net exporter. In the expansion of the EEC, particularly in relation to Greece, there is a significant change in structure concerning canned fruits and dried fruits. Each of these factors is beyond the control of the Australian primary producer. They are not able in the export market to pass on the additional charges which may be levied within Australia for our domestic purposes.

I believe it is important when we have the opportunity of looking at items such as the ones contained in this legislation, although in many cases the amounts may be relatively small, that it gives the Senate an opportunity of looking at the fundamental policy direction that the Government is taking. I refer, of course, not only to this Government but also to the previous Government. There has been very little change between the policies pursued by the previous Liberal -National Party Government and the Australian Labor Party Government. The Australian Democrats disagree with that particular movement.

It is interesting to look at items contained in the canned and frozen vegetables Bills. We have previously circulated some amendments and, presumably, they will be dealt with in the Committee stages. One such amendment seeks to address the problem that arose in relation to the honey export Bill that occurred during the life of the previous Government. I refer to the rationale that might be able to be provided for having a charge for an export licence when the country which is receiving that particular commodity does not require an export licence. There may be other reasons why Australia may wish to have such an export licence. One such reason that would be fairly commonly put forward would be the maintenance of a good name in exporting. That is not an immaterial consideration when one considers the competitive nature of this area. But I believe that unless one can show a direct link between the export licence for which the producer in Australia is paying and the legislative requirement of the county which is receiving that commodity, the cost of that export inspection ought to be borne by Consolidated Revenue. The Australian Democrats do not accept the philosophy that it should still be borne by the producer. The policy reason we advance for that is that we believe it is in the general nature of the maintenance of a good name for Australia and that is not specifically something for which the producer should have to pay.

I must admit that we were never a great admirer of the 'user pays' principle that the previous Government seemed to apply hither and yon; nor are we attracted by it when it is applied by the Labor Party. We believe there are some good reasons why there is a differentiation between the area where a country which is receiving the goods requires a particular certificate and other areas where the receiving country does not require the certificate. We believe a policy distinction ought to be made between those areas. When we reach the Committee stage we will seek to argue that aspect at greater length.

I turn to the honey Bills. We would apply the same argument in relation to one part of the legislation, but on another part we are again worried that the Government undertook and got past the Senate-although the Democrats opposed it- increasing the amount in the legislation in excess of that which the Government had declared in the second reading speech that it wished to collect. In other words, the Government was intending to increase it at any later stage by regulation rather than by legislation. We do not accept that as a proposition or a way in which to move. Likewise, in relation to the honey Bills we seek to reduce the maximum charge of $24 contained in the legislation to the $4.70 which the Government in its second reading speech says it wants to collect. Indeed, we feel that it may even be seen as inappropriate delegation by the appropriate Senate committee. We will seek to argue that at a later stage.

I turn to another item; that is, the financial impact statement for the Dried Fruits Levy Amemdment Bill 1984 that I requested during the first reading debate on these Bills. The financial impact statement, of course, refers only to clause 3 of the Bill; it does not refer to clause 4 which, of course, is the area in which the additional charges are increased. The reason for that is contained within the financial impact statement. It states that the operative rates are set by regulation under the levy Act and technically, therefore, are not set in the legislation, so are not needed as part of the impact statement. So the only change, of course, is in relation to clause 3 of the Bill. The interesting thing , presuming that the figures are correct, is that the statement reads:

The main result would be that about 150 tonnes of tunnel dried grapes would now incur levy at $1.00 per tonne. Occasional small quantities of tree fruits dried by a packer would also incur levy-perhaps 4 tonnes of fruit in dried form, with levy at $5.00 per tonne.

My calculation is that the amount involved is $170. Quite frankly, I think that when the Senate is reduced to a discussion of $170 perhaps we ought to have a whip round to assist the industry. The absurdity of coming up with that proposition in terms of the time of the Senate is quite extraordinary. The more interesting thing is what will happen when the Government by regulation at a later stage seeks to increase these levy charges. That, of course, will be the subject of debate at another time.

The Opposition has moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bills in which it seeks a delay; a delay which is almost within the hands of the Government in terms of time, except in relation to the Industries Assistance Commission's report on the honey industry. The final report of the IAC was to be delivered on 1 May. I understand that it has not been delivered. But I presume that it may not be long delayed, since the interim report was fairly well discussed within the industry, and I imagine that there would not be any great problem in having the IAC report on the honey industry fairly rapidly dispatched . The Democrats, however, are concerned by the motion as it stands and would seek to amend it to spell out explicitly those committees which are mentioned in that motion. I will move the amendment now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which amendment is that?
—I presume that the amendment has been circulated. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out 'the various Committees enquiring have reported and the Government has considered these reports and, in consultation with the industry, has come to a final resolution', insert:
'- (1) the final report of the Industries Assistance Commission on the honey industry;

(2) a report by the Department of Primary Industry on changes to the export inspection of honey proposed to operate from 1 October 1984, the proposed levy structure to operate from that date, and the costs of inspection involved;
(3) a report by the Department of Primary Industry on the proposed export inspection of canned and frozen fruit and vegetables, the proposed levy structure and the costs of inspection involved;
(4) a report by the Interim Inspection Policy Council on honey export inspection; and
(5) a report by the Interim Inspection Policy Council on canned and frozen fruit and vegetable export inspection;
have been presented to the Government, the Government has considered these reports and consulted with the industry, and has reported its conclusions to the Parliament'.

I believe that that spells out in precise terms what at least the Australian Democrats believe would be a reasonable basis upon which then to make a judgment about these Bills. I leave aside the Bill that we do not have before us, the Bill concerning fresh fruits and vegetables which is still in the House of Representatives, to which other factors are attached. I reiterate that this delay is within the Government's hands in terms of its timing and length. I do not think that it would be an onerous task to make such information available to the Senate before it determines its view on these Bills. As to some of the Bills , it is not so much a matter of absolute cost but rather, I repeat, a matter of the principle involved, which is now sought to be extended right across the board in relation to primary products. The amendment I have moved is an amendment to that which has been moved by the Opposition to the second reading motion. I hope that the Government will accept the amendments and that the material for which the Senate will ask, I hope, can be rapidly provided so that we can move on the passage of these Bills at the appropriate stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Scott in relation to the various Bills that we are debating. It must be very obvious that the Government is going down the same track as it went down on the Meat Inspection Bill, when it tried to bring before the Senate legislation before a committee report was brought down. In the case of the validation Bill, the Senate told the Government that it was not prepared to accept the legislation unless the report of the committee was taken into consideration. That is exactly what we are going to do tonight. We are asking the Government to wait another two months until it gets the report that the Department of Primary Industry has been asked to prepare and then bring it before the Senate and bring down legislation in line with the report. I ask Senator Walsh why he cannot wait for the two months to elapse. It will not make a great deal of difference. The money involved is not that much, as far as I can work it out.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Fresh Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984 was not proceeded with in the House of Representatives would indicate to me that the legislation that the Government has brought down on all these Bills should be retracted and that the Government should have another look at the matter. The fact that one piece of the legislation is seen to be faulty and cannot be proceeded with indicates to me that the Government, if it were honest with the horticulture industry, should have said, 'Let us take them all out and look at them again'.

I now refer to the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill. This piece of legislation seems to be vague. The Bill sets a maximum charge of $24 per tonne, and yet we are told in the Minister's second reading speech that he intends to charge only $4.70 per tonne. I cannot understand why the Minister would want to bring down a charge of $24 per tonne if he is not going to use that charge. Surely he is asking the Senate for a blank cheque. If the Minister wanted to increase the charge from $4.70 per tonne to $24 per tonne he should come and seek an amendment to the legislation.

The Government should also realise that the honey export industry is only very tiny, and it is used mainly to clear excess production of honey on the export market, to reduce gluts and price depressions on the domestic market. I notice in the Honey Board's annual report that the average price of export honey was 87c per kilo. Even a 5c per kilo inspection levy would represent a fairly sizable proportion of the net price. I have worked it out at about 7 per cent of the net amount received by the honey producer. A charge of 24c per kilo would represent a quarter of the honey producers' payment-and I do not mean a quarter of their net profit; I mean a quarter of their net payment. Australia has to meet world competition and already we export honey at under the cost of production. Any extra charge would reduce our sales to overseas countries.

I refer now to the Canned and Frozen Vegetables (Export Inspection Charge) Bill . There are a number of questions that must be asked. Firstly, is an inspection charge necessary when a number of south-east Asian countries do not require inspection certificates? All canning and freezing plants have their own quality controllers who have very high qualifications and would be probably better able to administer the quality control than most government inspectors. Could some form of licensing be introduced to allow the factories to produce their own certificates? The Government legislation does not tell us how the inspections are to be carried out. I understand that all these things are to be brought down by the Department of Primary Industry in its committee's findings. I ask the Government again to wait for another two months until the findings are brought down, and then it can introduce proper legislation based on committee findings.

I have been in touch with a number of exporters in the canned and frozen vegetable industry, and one of the larger frozen vegetable exporters has informed me that the inspection charges would reduce its profit by the equivalent of one per cent on sales. It also informs me that it is making only 3 per cent to 4 per cent profit. The representative pointed out to me that the industry was just about at the stage at which there was not much point in staying in business any longer. With regard to the export of canned fruit and vegetables, and canned fruit in particular, I understand that the Government is propping up by means of loans and guarantees a number of canneries in some of the southern States, and now, with the same canneries that it is propping up-

TALK.START.PARA: —Propping up a few sugar mills, too.

—We will stick to the canneries. On the same canneries that the Government is propping up with loans and guarantees it is now imposing extra charges, when it has already been indicated that they need government help now.

SPEECH.PARA: Probably the best form of inspection that the producers can bring down is that of self-protection. Every producer knows that if he puts faulty produce on to the market and has to compete with international producers, he will not be in the market for long. All canneries are fully aware of this. They know that the market is very competitive both in price and quality and it is not in their interests to send faulty products on to the market.

This legislation will not take into account the problems and benefits that a healthy export industry can give to Australia. At present Australia is experiencing an inflation rate of between 9 per cent and 10 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wrote that yesterday.

—That includes Medicare. However, if the inflation rate were measured fairly across the board it would be up around 9 per cent or 10 per cent . The exchange rate is moving against exporters. Our rural export competitors receive help from their governments in the form of subsidies and extended credit facilities and in a number of other ways. Australia must compete in world markets against all countries that receive help from their governments. Rural industries in particular in these countries have very low costs, low exchange rates and yet our Government keeps on bleeding our rural industries white with the added costs of not only inspection levies but also a number of other imposts . I urge the Senate tonight to accept the Opposition's amendment and withdraw the Bills until the various committees can look at them and then the Government can bring down legislation in line with those findings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too support the amendment moved by Senator Scott. I accept that the Government can tax and has a right to tax as it sees fit. However, the tax should be reasonable and the Opposition has a responsibility to ensure that the costs of that tax should be appropriate to the circumstances. For instance, let us look at the context in which we are dealing with this matter. Only a month ago these industries suffered yet another 4.1 per cent pay rise. There is nothing in any of this legislation that will tell them how they can start to compensate for these sorts of extra costs. We have to remember that in Australia we are price takers on all of these products. We are producers and suppliers on a world market. For items that come on the domestic market one pays a domestic cost and receives a domestic return. To export one pays the domestic cost and gets a world return. Every time we do something to stupefy our own costs it is at the expense of the producer, not the purchaser. If we wish to drive these various industries into extinction this is exactly the way to go about it. We continue to load them with costs that they cannot pass on and costs that are non-comparative with other competing countries. This legislation is the perfect example of that.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at what even a wage rise amounts to one must multiply it a few times to allow for the costs incurred by the time the goods eventually reach the wharf. Can the producers pass them on? No, of course they cannot. It is all at the cost of the producer. As I have said, on the world market we are price takers competing with a group of countries which are cost conscious competitors. We are competing with countries which seek to build exports, which want the development and employment that go with it and which act accordingly. We are involved in world trade and in primary industry areas we are competing with countries such as the European Economic Community, New Zealand, Canada and the United States of America. Do they tax their exports? No, of course they do not. We are the silliest country in the world when it comes to this sort of thing. Why would we do a thing like this now?

The Australians who are now getting the huge pay rise, which is out of line with that received by people in other countries, neither understand the export tax nor realise what it will do to their own jobs and the national productivity and prosperity that go with it. As we were discussing earlier today, without export income Australia cannot survive. As we know, our coal and iron industries are in trouble as are our beef and dairy producers. Apparently it is necessary that we add honey, fresh, frozen, canned and dried fruits and vegetables as well . What an appalling state of affairs. I do not see why, because we have got most of our industries in trouble, we should ensure that we put the rest of them in that position too. I and I suppose most of the producers of these commodities are terribly impressed with the publicity given to rural booms. I have talked with vegetable processors, onion exporters, honey producers and fruit growers and regrettably they all seem to have missed out on any boom. In the last 12 months costs generally have ballooned. One needs only to consider the rises in fuel, wages and taxes generally to see what has happened to all these price taking industries. I do not know how many times the Government believes that it is possible to keep squeezing the lemon dry.

I think the Government is also of the opinion that primary producers are wealthy barons of the soil. That sort of attitude constantly lets them down. The vast knowledge of the productive sector that is so noticeably absent in honourable senators opposite is again upon us and the exporters involved. We do have a system of export incentives under the export market development grants. As such we have apparently decided to give the export market development grant on the one hand and take it back on the other with an export tax. I ask: Is that economical, particularly when one considers the added costs on both sides of such a transaction? Do we want exports? Does our economy depend on exports?

Let me look briefly at the products involved in these Bills. At the moment legislation regarding fresh vegetables has been withdrawn. However, I was not impressed when I talked to an onion producer and found that at a time when he was exporting 200 tonnes of onions a day he was charged $1,000 a day for the wages of one man, plus overtime of $5,000 or $6,000 a year into the bargain. I cannot see that that is reasonable in any way, shape or form. I think he is entitled to be charged only what is reasonable.

As far as processed vegetables are concerned, either frozen or canned, the vegetable producers whom I know produce only a relatively small quantity of their production for export. However, it is very difficult to go through the processing mechanism and to decide which tins will be exported and which ones will not when one is in a normal production run. They have no option but to pay to have them all inspected for export purposes. A person from one factory to whom I spoke reported that it would cost something like $20,000, to the producer of course, not to the processor. Processors are operating marginally at the moment and their profitability is very doubtful. But this factory will pay another $20,000 for export inspections, yet another producer tax.

Another point that was raised was what an absolute farce it was to pay $20,000 a year for an export inspection charge to Department of Primary Industry qualified inspectors when the factories have inspectors and quality controls that are far higher and far more scientific than those required by the Department. Yet these factories have to pay the additional cost from which they stand to receive absolutely nothing in any way, shape or form. I have a telex from the Edgell-Birds Eye division which covers the matter fairly adequately. I seek leave to incorporate a copy of that telex in Hansard at this point.
Leave granted.
The telex read as follows-
The Honourable,
R. J. L. Hawke, A.C., M.P.,
Prime Minister
Parliament House,
Canberra 2600
Dear Prime Minister,
REFERENCE: RECOUPMENT OF EXPORT INSPECTIONS COSTS OF HORTICULTURAL PRODUCTS.

We write to acknowledge receipt of the media release, emanating from the office of the Minister for Primary Industry, dated 22nd December, 1983, advising of the intention of the Australian Government to introduce a scheme to recoup, allegedly, 50% of the cost of the Department of Primary Industry export inspection costs from the horticultural industry.
We lodge a strong protest at the imposition of these charges and have written to the Department in the past giving voice to our disagreement to such a move but to no avail.
We have not even received the courtesy of an acknowledgment.

We believe the costs of running a government department are the responsibility of that department and the Federal Government at large. All such costs should be shared equitably across the community and those costs, if at all necessary, should be borne by those who legislate the rules and regulations within Australia and should be paid for by the department concerned from taxes gathered to run that department.
The levy and inspection charges are in fact another method of ''double taxation ''.

In our particular industry, i.e. canned and frozen vegetables etc., we employ our own quality control food technologists in every production centre. The majority of these technologists would have far superior qualifications than any D.P.I. inspector we have ever encountered and would be in a far better position to judge whether raw material and finished product were to the standard required for export.
We therefore suggest that, in most instances in our industry, D.P.I. inspectors are an unnecessary luxury.

If New Zealand can export similar commodities (as we do from our New Zealand plant) without the encumbrance of D.P.I. inspectors, then there appears no reason why we in Australia could not do likewise.

At a time when the Federal Government and politicians are proclaiming the necessity to foster the manufactured goods segment of our export trade we find sections of this trade are being lumbered with additional costs-costs that were previously and should still be borne by the Federal Government.

Having carried out costing exercises covering the months of November, December, 1983 and January, 1984 we have assessed that the additional costs work out at a value of 1% of our dollar value sales-a hefty charge in a field where nett profits are minimal.
Further, the levy on canned and frozen fruit and vegetables is $10.00 per consignment plus 0.85 cents per kilo of the nett weight.
Consider that a can of 440g nett weight has an average drained weight of 285g, this then means we are paying 0.85 cents on the export of 155g of water.

The way this imposition on an already bled white industry has been introduced is but a further example of beaurocratic bungling by public servants who are completely out of touch with the realities of the marketplace.

Not only is it a further nail in the coffin of exports of manufactured goods but one can no doubt look forward to being charged a subscription to the Department of trade's Publication, 'Overseas Trading' or the introduction of a levy to maintain Department of Trade Posts Overseas.

May we suggest the simplest method to cut the costs of the Department of Primary Industry would be to do away with the inspectors and rely on those in the canned and frozen fruits vegetable and juice, and fresh vegetable and fruit industry to use their common sense in ensuring only top quality production is exported.
We welcome your reply on this subject and an indication of what the Government intends doing to assist the industry rather than hamper it.
Yours faithfully,
Edgell-Birds Eye Division of
Petersville Industries Limited

TALK.START.PARA: —What has really upset the primary producers in all these areas is the inability of the Department of Primary Industry to come up with a complete analysis of the costs and detailed information as to how these levies are to be spent. A few months ago and after some delays, the Department was able to provide me with details of the export meat inspection service. I certainly hope that by the time we finally deal with this legislation the other costs will be available. The dried fruits producers especially are unable to stand any additional charges of any sort. Recently I was quite impressed to receive a very practical solution from one of my correspondents. The solution was a recipe on how to make an empire Christmas pudding. It appeared in the Daily News newspaper of 6 June 1925. I also seek leave to incorporate this recipe for Christmas pudding in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The recipe reads as follows-
HOW TO MAKE AN EMPIRE XMAS PUDDING
(as taken from the Daily News Newspaper of 6.6.1925)
Take one cupful of each of the following ingredients:
Flour
And also add-
Raisins
1 cooking apple
Sultanas
4-6 eggs
Currants
1 teaspoon pudding spice
Brown sugar
1 wineglass of rum
Chopped mixed peel
Sufficient milk to mix
Beef suet, or butter
Bread crumbs
Grated rind & juice of lemon
Mix well
Place in greased basin
Cover with greaseproof paper, and
tie on cloth
Steam or boil for 6 to 8 hours
* Delicious when served with cream or ice cream.

TALK.START.PARA: —If this pudding is made, as is suggested, by every household in Australia every couple of months it would not only be beneficial to the health of Australians but also would solve the dried fruits problem at the same time. I commend that as being a very worthy aim indeed. As has been stated, the honey producers are having considerable difficulty in trying to determine just exactly what sort of range their costs are likely to be. I have had discussions with the producers and they advised me that in the past they just used to wait for an inspector to come in and pick up a jar of honey off the desk and disappear. It now seems as if they are going to be charged something between $4 and $24 a tonne for exactly the same service. Again, these are small industries. They require fostering. They can do with all the help that they can get. To have an open ended charge that they do not understand in any way, shape or form, that nobody can explain to them, is absolutely ridiculous. We are told that the $4.70 is temporary, but we are not told whether it will be more or less and when that is likely to happen. I do believe that an industry that is going to be called upon to pay is entitled to be told just that. I would like to make it clear that exporters generally support and approve of export inspection. However, they object to the totally senseless, expensive and counter productive aspects. I feel exactly the same. If I thought I could understand more of what we are trying to achieve and what the results of these charges will be I would be much happier about it. Do we, as a nation, seek to expand exports? If we do we know that while items like the 4.1 per cent can be added to domestic industries and domestic products for exporters it will be absolutely disastrous. Do we seek to expand or contract? Does the Government want to be remembered only by the primary and export industries it has closed down and put out of business? I ask: Where is it expected that the national income will come from? All the industries we are talking about use local capital, local labour, buy from local shops and are essential to the whole national economy. Profitable operation and policies clearly demonstrating security and future progress are prerequisites for industrial and export expansion. As is so clearly demonstrated in these Bills, policies of higher taxes will achieve only the opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: I appeal to the Government to rethink the effects and the appropriateness of these charges. The effects on small producers and small exporters in particular has obviously had no thought at all. The other half of the argument is that we increase our costs by levy, taxes, charges or whatever so the threat of imported produce increases. The dearer we make our own goods, the more likely we are to be invaded by imports. Are we trying to import more processed vegetables or honey, or are we not? I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will comment briefly on the points that have been raised by several of the Opposition speakers. At the outset I should state that the Government will not support either of the amendments, although I think the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats is probably a little bit tidier than the other amendment. The Government will not do this for these reasons: There is reference to consultation with the industries concerned. There has already been extensive consultation with the industries. There is reference in the Opposition amendment to the Bills being withdrawn until the various committees inquiring have reported. Only two committees are relevant, one within the Department of Primary Industry and another one, strictly speaking, not relevant to the Bills which we are currently discussing. The IAC draft report has recommended that no assistance be provided. Anyway, it does not canvass this issue at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Archer has waffled on at some length about the alleged crippling burden that these charges will impose on the industry. I have two comments to make. As a rule of thumb, the charges equal about one half per cent of f.o.b. values, but more importantly perhaps if Senator Archer held those views he kept them silent for a very long time and kept them to himself for a very long time because in fact the policy being pursued through these Bills is to recover 50 per cent of the costs of export inspection services, a policy initially set by the previous Government I think in the late 1970s and continued by the present Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never supported it.

—I do not think the honourable senator had so much to say about it before. As for the reference in the amendments to detailed operation for the Government to make a statement as to the minutiae of the way in which these levies will be applied and administered, that is not required in any other Bill and I do not see any reason why it should be applied in this one. Senator Macklin did make the point, which he has made before, that it should be practice or a standard rule that whenever charges of this type are altered, additional legislation should go through the Parliament whereas the practice for as long as I can remember anyway under governments of all persuasion has been that when amending legislation or new legislation is put in place a ceiling charge is written into the legislation and some charge at or below that level is actually applied by way of regulation. I suppose that is a point of view, but I would not like to think that every time it was necessary to adjust a charge we had to waste as much time in the Parliament as we have wasted on these Bills tonight and on similar Bills in the past. The other point Senator Macklin made is that where the purpose of applying export inspection procedures is to maintain the good name of Australia as an exporter and a supplier of quality products, he argued that that responsibility should be carried by the taxpayers instead of the industry which is actually exporting the product. That is a point of view, but it is not a point of view with which the Government concurs.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Macklin's) to Senator Scott's proposed amendment agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Macklin's) agreed to.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Scott's amendment), as amended, be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Scott's), as amended, agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
APPLE AND PEAR LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1984
DRIED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1984
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move the Australian Democrats amendments to the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill and the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill together as they are related.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the Dried Fruits Levy Amendent Bill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, clause 3, before paragraph (1) (a), insert the following paragraph:
(aa) by inserting after 'apricots' in the definition of 'dried tree fruits', the words 'dried apples,'.
In respect of the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill, I move:
Page 2, clause 4, proposed new sub-section 7 (3A), line 4, after 'in respect of ', insert 'apples or'.

In his second reading speech the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said that the purpose of the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill was to correct certain anomalies relating to the imposition of an apple and pear levy under the Apple and Pear Levy Act 1976. The Australian Democrats have supported the second reading of the Bill. I must admit, however, that we are puzzled by the statement of the Minister in his second reading speech when he said:

It is not proposed to exempt fresh apples delivered for drying from the apple and pear levy and dried apples, unlike dried pears, are not defined as dried tree fruit under the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971.

The extraordinary thing about this is that the Government should go to the trouble of actually fixing the levy rates proposed for pears and then presenting this extremely feeble excuse for not fixing up the levy for apples. I think that if we apply a bit of ordinary lateral thinking to this-presumably an exercise that could be undertaken by almost anybody-it can be seen that if we cannot exempt fresh apples delivered for drying because apples are not defined as dried tree fruits under the relevant Act we then define apples as dried tree fruit under the Act. That is precisely what our amendment proposes to do. It so happens that the Government brought an amending Bill in for both Acts at the same time. The amendment I have moved to the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill reads:
Page 2, clause 4, proposed new sub-section 7 (3A), line 4, after 'in respect of ', insert 'apples or'.
It would then read 'apples or pears'. The amendment to the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill reads:
Page 1, clause 3, before paragraph (1) (a), insert the following paragraph:
(aa) by inserting after 'apricots' in the definition of 'dried tree fruits', the words 'dried apples,'.
The definition would now read:
Dried tree fruits means dried apricots, dried pears, dried nectarines, dried plums or dried apples.

I would be happy if the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) could explain why in fact dried apples are not dried tree fruits. It may be that apples grow elsewhere than on trees. I am unaware of that. I have asked extensively of experts in this area; they assure me that apples do indeed grow on trees. It seems to the Democrats appropriate that we ought to define them in this way rather than engage in the rather silly excuse that is used in the Minister's second reading speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not accept the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. I am advised that after substantial consultation with the industry the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the people concerned agreed that the dried tree fruits named in the legislation were the ones on which the research levy ought to be paid. I do not want to pass an opinion on whether there is or is not a case for applying the same levy to apples. That possibility was evidently not canvassed when the Minister discussed the question with the industry. After agreement having been reached between the Government and the industry it does not seem to be appropriate that the Government should accept the Democrats' amendments at this late stage.

— The reason given in the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) was only that apples were not so defined as dried tree fruits under the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971. Is the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) now saying that there is a reason other than that which appeared in the second reading speech both in the other place and here when it was incorporated in Hansard?

—I think the reason is complementary. As I understand it, the present Bill has the same scope and coverage as the previous Act. The two pieces of legislation are in fact related. In the discussion the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) held with the industry there was agreement that the product specified in the 1971 Act should remain in the present Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -It appears to me that there is some confusion about the use of the word 'apple' . If, as the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) says, the industry is satisfied that the Bills cover all the appropriate areas and the appropriate fruit involved, I think it is satisfactory that it should remain that way. Consequently I see no need to support an amendment which is perhaps in conflict with a view of the industry. We supported the Bills because, as I understand it, the industry supported them. That is how the position remains.

—The Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) has said that the industry is happy enough to accept this proposition. Can he give me the reasons why the industry accepted it? What were the propositions put to members of the industry by the Government to lead the Government to accept such an absurd proposition?

—I have had some experience in the Riverland district. Dried apples have never been distributed through the Dried Fruit Board. Dried apples have always been separate. There are other fruits, for example some of the wine grapes, that were dried, which have also not been included. For example, doradellas, which went to the manufacturing trade, were never included. Dried apples were never included. I think that is the reason for the exclusion of dried apples. That is my understanding of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly respond to Senator Macklin. I was not present at the discussion which the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) had with industry representatives. The position appears to have been that the list of products that were agreed as being appropriate back in 1971 are still agreed to be appropriate now. Nobody raised the question of whether apples should be included . It could be argued that not including dried apples is an arbitrary decision but it is one that is acceptable to all parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on clause 4 (1 ), paragraphs (a), (b), (c) and (d), and on clause 4 (2). First of all, clause 4 (1), paragraphs (a) and (b), seek to raise the levy rates from $1 to $2 and from $5 to $10 respectively, which would double the current maximum rates for the levy. While admittedly those rates have not been raised since 1975, it seems to be a fairly enormous increase without any commitment from the Government as to how much of that increase will take place in the current season. I believe that if we were looking at the situation from, say, 1 January next year my remarks would be quite different, but when one looks at the situation of the dried fruits industry and the absolute devastation it has gone through in the last season it seems to me to be inappropriate for any rise to take place during the current season. The Bill might be able to provide for a rise at a later stage. There are reasonable prospects at least for the ensuing season. I seek the comments of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) on what the intention of the Government is in relation to clause 4 (1), paragraphs (a) and ( b). We believe that it may very well be that the industry will not be capable of bearing an increased levy at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4 (1), paragraphs (c) and (d), refer to changes in policy in the way in which the levy is specified. Clause 4 (1) (c) reads: 'by omitting from sub- section (2) ''of a specified season'' '. If that is adopted the Government will no longer be required to strike a new levy rate each year. At the moment, even if the Government wants to keep the rate the same as it was for the year before it has to make a positive decision that the rate in fact will remain the same. I must admit that as a general rule of thumb the Australian Democrats believes that the process of not forcing the Government into looking at these rates every year is an acceptable mechanism, particularly if it does not wish to change the rates. However, given the very high volatility of this industry-that is why I am making an exception-I believe that there are grounds for forcing the Government to reassess the situation each year. Therefore, we are unwilling to support the policy change proposed in clause 4 (1) (c).

Clause 4(1)(d) reads: 'by omitting from sub-section (3) all the words after '' Committee'' (first occurring)'. That would remove a restriction on the amount by which the levy can be increased. At the moment the Government cannot increase the levy to any amount higher than that which is recommended by the relevant committee. The Democrats feel that this is an extremely important area of the legislation and a legitimate approach given that the funds raised are for the use of the industry itself in terms of its promotion. We believe that it is important as a matter of policy principle that the industry retain control over that money. If the Committee wishes to adopt clause 4 (1) (d) it will hand over to the Government entirely control of those funds which are raised. I think that is inappropriate. I seek from the Minister an indication of whether this policy decision is one which the Government intends to pursue in other relevant Acts. If it does intend to pursue it in other relevant Acts we ought to alert all the other primary industry areas that the Government is about to do this. I think the Government might then very well find that it has a much larger fight on its hands than obviously it would have with a small, relatively weak industry in the throes of very serious economic difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Bill are we talking about?

—We are talking about the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill. I have gone through clause 4 (1), paragraphs (a), (b), (c) and (d), and have indicated basically the problems as we see them. The first couple of paragraphs of that clause involve problems in relation to application in the current season . The problem in relation to paragraphs (c) and (d) is with the change of policy that the Government is pursuing. I seek from the Minister an indication of whether that is a policy decision that is likely to apply to other areas.

—On the first couple of points Senator Macklin raised, I am advised that a levy must be set every season regardless of whether it is to be changed. That is correct. I am advised also that it is highly unlikely to increase this year. I think it is set at $1 now and it is to remain at $1. The other point he made related to the ceiling of $1 which was set in 1975. A ceiling of $2 does not seem to me to be unreasonable for 1984 under those circumstances. I am afraid I did not entirely follow the point Senator Macklin was making with respect to clause 4 (1 ), paragraphs (c) and (d), of, I presume, the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill.

—Yes, I was referring to the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill. The suggestion the Minister just made was that indeed there would still be an obligation actually to specify an amount every year, but if one goes back to the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971 and looks at it in relation to the proposed amendment it would be an extraordinary reading of section 6 of that Act to interpret it the way the Minister has. By leaving out the words 'of a specified season' from the 1971 Act it would then simply provide that one would strike a levy which would remain until in fact the Government chose to change it . Having taken out the words 'of a specified season', as I see it there would be no reason in the Act for the Government to be under any statutory obligation to do anything of the kind he suggested.

—I apologise to Senator Macklin. I confused the advice which I had been given. In fact, what I said should be reversed. The Dried Fruits Levy Act as it stands requires the Government to bring out a regulation every year, regardless of whether the levy is to be changed. Under the proposed amendment that would no longer be required. A regulation would not be required if there was to be no change in the rate of levy.

—That is precisely what I was objecting to. I presume that what the Government now is saying is that that is a policy decision it has taken. I move on then to clause 4 (1) (d) and ask whether it is a general policy commitment on the part of the Government to take over control of the rate as it is struck rather than to act on a recommendation from the relevant committee in the particular industry with which we are concerned.
— Senator Macklin probably understands that the only Act which would be affected by the amendment in clause 4 (1) (d) would be the Dried Fruits Levy Act.
—Yes.

—As far as I am aware and as far as the departmental representatives here are aware there is no general policy decision by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to extend that provision to all other Acts. If Senator Macklin likes, I will contact the Minister on that and seek a response from him in writing as to whether it is contemplated that that be extended to other Acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that reply. I certainly would be very interested to receive that in writing from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin).

SPEECH.PARA: Bills reported without requests; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 5 April, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill 1983, now under review. The main issues in the Bill are relatively simple and minor. They cover such matters as the licensing of crew members. Crew members need no longer be individually licenced and the master fisherman alone will hold the licences involved. Secondly, the legislation provides for the entry of unlicensed fishing boats for the purposes of mechanical repairs or non-routine procedures. Thirdly, permits for scientific purposes will now be issued and there will be an increased level of control over scientific fishing boats. Fourthly, the amendments provide for the control of Australian fishermen on the high seas and for the utilisation of the Fisheries Act to control Australian fishermen outside the Australian fishing zone. This provision anticipates the need to control Australian fishermen on the high seas where international agreement on the need for additional management of migratory species is secured. Of course, in particular this involves such things as the southern blue fin tuna.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifthly, the legislation provides for an increased level of management control utilising changes in administrative procedures. In relation to licensing, additional powers will be granted which provide for alterations in licence conditions, cancellation of licence endorsements and exemptions from prohibition by notice. Sixthly, provision is made for increased parliamentary scrutiny whereby either House may disallow certain fisheries notices. Seventhly, there is to be a review of licensing matters. Personal decisions by the Minister for Primary Industry or the Secretary to the Department are to be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This has not been so in the past. Eighthly, the legislation amends the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act. The purpose of this amendment is to increase the level of jurisdiction to include the seabed below the territorial sea of the Coral Sea Islands Territory. This amendment complements existing regulations with the aim of preventing the illegal harvesting of sedentary organisms, particularly the giant clams.

That is all that this Bill before us provides. In view of the fact that the second reading speech incorporated by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) mentioned that the main purposes of these amendments were to take up matters raised in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce tabled on 10 January 1983, as a Chairman of that Committee and as a member of it from its inception all I would say is that I was disappointed that this was the extent of the amendments produced at this stage. Many other matters raised in that report are far more vital to the fishing industry than the items picked up in this legislation for no more nor less than the convenience of the Government and its Department. I believe that the matters of real issue have been ignored so far. I would make some sort of plea to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) that he and his Department either produce an entirely new Act, as was recommended in the report, or at least bring forward some amendments which are meaningful and in line with some of the major recommendations made.

It is important that we bear in mind that the fishing industry is no longer a backyard, peasant industry. In 1981-82, the year covered by the latest report, the value of the Australian catch was over $330m and earnings from exports of fish and fish products in their ultimate state were in the order of $306.5m. To compare this with other industries, it is more than double the value of cotton exports, it is $50m more than total mutton exports and it is $100m more than total butter and cheese exports. The fishing industry is a very big industry. There are varying figures on the number of boats, but there are certainly in excess of 10,000 licensed fishing boats in Australian waters worth approximately $400m. It is important to get that as a basis to realise the size of the industry we are dealing with and to see where we are going as far as the development and maintenance of the stock are concerned.

Fishermen everywhere at present are very concerned about the state of the fish supply. In recent weeks there have been visits to Canberra and deputations to various State and Federal authorities concerning the management of the resource. For instance, I know that a deputation is coming from Tasmania on Monday next for an interview here concerning proposals for increased fishing in Tasmanian waters. Over the last 10 years we have seen a considerable tightening up of fishing arrangements, but it has been done in a spasmodic way. Although I naturally prefer to see things sort themselves out without the Government intervening, I believe that some regulations are necessary and that, if the right circumstances are provided and the Government does what is necessary, the industry itself can make the necessary recommendations to ensure that the stocks of fish are kept at a reasonable level in perpetuity.

Today in Canberra there was a meeting with the trawl advisory committee. At that meeting the biologists and the fishermen had considerable disagreement in some areas. They both believe they have the information, but they are not necessarily dealing with the same information. It is important that there be a concurrent mixture of the various skills that go into the assessment of stocks. We know that there has been considerable difference of opinion as far as the southern blue fin tuna is concerned. The latest recommendation from an inquiry is that the actual taking of southern blue fin tuna should be almost halved in the forthcoming season. Such a program creates a lot of disruption among those who make their living from this type of fishing. I think it is most unfortunate that this has been allowed to expand to the current level and then people are suddenly told that they have to contract. We have seen that same sort of thing with lobster fishing in Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania. We have seen it with shark fishing in Bass Strait and the southern waters. We have seen it with prawns in the Investigator Strait, the Gulf of Carpentaria and Shark Bay . We are now finding that the problems arising from the southern trawl area have necessitated the formation of the southern trawl committee for investigation into what is going to happen there in the years ahead.

Unless we are able to establish a regime in which all people with an interest can participate, I do not think we will make much progress. One of the recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce was that there should be provision for the fishermen to be able to be represented at the decision making level, that they should have participation so that when decisions are made that affect them, they should be able to be part of them. I have great faith in the fishermen. I believe that, given a reasonable measure of control, they would exercise it very jealously and wisely. The fishermen that I talk to are very conservation conscious. They are concerned that there are insufficient regulations to stop over-fishing. Only a few days ago, I was talking to a shark fisherman from Bass Strait who said that they are now catching about an eighth to a tenth of the quantity of fish in the same time and with the same gear that they were using only four years ago. Sharks, of course, are a slow growing and slow regenerating fish. They have to be fished very carefully. The prawns in the Gulf of Carpentaria have been fished very badly and very spasmodically over a period. But now the fishermen have taken it upon themselves to engage in some supervision and management. They are making more of a contribution. I believe that that problem has now been overcome.

While I am talking about the northern fishing areas, I think it would be appropriate to mention the foreign fishing in the area and the various arrangements that we have made concerning particularly the Taiwanese, and to a lesser extent other countries. I believe that the regulations that we now have covering this type of fishing need considerable overhauling. For instance, on the occasions when errors or misdemeanours are committed by foreign fishermen, I believe it is absolutely ridiculous to confiscate their boats. No one in Australia wants any of those battered old Taiwanese junks which, to dispose of, we then have to pay someone. I find that in the world of trade and commerce only one commodity is universally understood, and that is money. If people commit the sorts of misdemeanours that require penalties, the best penalty is money. The second best penalty is the cancellation of their licences. The removal of their livelihoods in that way is far better than the removal of their livelihoods by taking boats that no one wants. I had hoped that by the time we got around to dealing with some of the amendments-this matter has been going on since we tabled the report on 10 January 1983-we would be tidying up some of these matters such as the one I have just mentioned.

In the past we have depended quite considerably on the information we have obtained from various foreign fishermen. The Japanese, with their long line tuna fishing, have had access to our waters for many years. They have given us quite a lot of information and they have taken quite a lot of fish. It is only in the last three, four or five years that various Australian fishermen, particularly those fishing out of Port Lincoln, have taken it upon themselves to fish in a manner that is now probably almost as good, if not as good, as the methods used by the Japanese. If we are to maximise the responsibilities that go with taking the 200 mile zone we will need to further brush up on our methods in these areas .

I believe that there is room for more Australian fishing of the southern bluefin tuna. I believe that there is a need for us to further extend the scope of what has been allocated to the Japanese. I believe that by so doing we would be able to relieve the pressure on the fishing for some of the small southern bluefin tuna that are caught further west. I have grave reservations that we should be continuing in the manner in which we are, because I believe that it is rather senseless to be catching the immature fish when by waiting we could have them grow to a better size in easier waters and get a far better price for them. I believe that we should expect to get more assistance from foreign fishermen. I believe that they can make an even greater contribution towards research and development. I believe that the records they have can be extended very greatly to our benefit. I feel that some of the species that they now catch which would be low-priced products on the Australian market may well be able to be processed in Australia and exported in some form. With proper treatment they may also be import replaceable. I think that it would be quite desirable to encourage further trials and research into these matters.

I find it is highly desirable every now and then to have an opportunity to discuss matters such as fishing and fishermen. In a chamber such as this and a Parliament such as this we seem to spend an inordinate amount of time talking about freedom of information, social security, Age tapes or the new Parliament House strikes. It is a pleasure to deal with real people who take real risks with their own money and who do something for the development and prosperity of the country. These people who work and who provide jobs make a very substantial contribution to the gross domestic product and help our export markets. They produce foreign capital by way of export income. They help develop our natural resources, both at sea and on land. They invest in the country. I believe that the fishermen deserve considerable encouragement, respect and gratitude for the part they play in adding to the economy as they do.

Over a period of years, the Government has done a lot to encourage the building of boats through the ship building bounty. While it was intended as a benefit to the ship building industry, I believe that it became quite wrongly a matter of considerable importance to the fishing industry. We found that fishermen started building boats of a size that fitted in with the bounty and that may not ever have been the most appropriate vessels for use in the types of fishing in which they engaged. This has meant that a lot of fishermen upgraded their boats to a standard that they would not otherwise have done. They then sold the boats they previously owned. We now have an enormous surplus that is a real embarrassment, particularly down the eastern coast of Australia.
Debate interrupted.
