DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory-Telecom Australia: Availability of Public Telephones-Australian Coins

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., in accordance with sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to embark upon an attempt to find out what happened to $1m which was given to the Australian Capital Territory and which now seems to have disappeared or has been taken away. The story started in 1981 when, out of an allocation of $25m in the international standards sports facility fund $1m-not a large amount, but important to the Australian Capital Territory-was given to the Territory. Honourable senators may recall that the $25m was to be matched dollar for dollar by State allocations towards the same fund. We were to receive another $1m which was to have come from the National Capital Development Commission budget. Originally it was suggested that this would be towards an international motor racing circuit in Canberra. Subsequently, Victoria apparently decided that it wanted to use its money for an international motor racing circuit. In any event, it was unlikely that two such circuits would be viable in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Without going into all the details of why that was not the outcome, it was clear at the time of the change of government that it was not likely that that proposal would be proceeded with. But I do not think anyone doubted that the money would still be available for the purpose of upgrading certain sporting facilities in the Australian Capital Territory to international standard. The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) had from early March of 1983 to get on with the job of dealing with this sum which had not otherwise been used. The matter was certainly raised in June. I wrote to him on 17 June, having not heard from him what he was doing. I reminded him of what had gone on and made some suggestions as to what might be done with the money if he were not minded to pursue the international motor racing circuit. I received a letter from his office which indicated that he had received my letter, was examining the matters and would write to me shortly. At the same time I also spoke to the departmental officers concerned to reassure myself that there was no risk of the money being lost to us. I subsequently received a letter from the Minister for Territories and Local Government in which he said in part:
My Department is considering a number of proposals as a matter of urgency. I can assure you that the options suggested in your letter will be fully considered before a decision is made.

That letter is dated 19 August. At that stage he still had the $1m and there was no suggestion whatever that the money would not be available in the Australian Capital Territory for the purpose for which it had been allocated similarly to the States. A Press release was put out by the Department dated 12 September 1983 which indirectly dealt with this matter. It referred to some suggestion that moneys being expended at the National Exhibition Centre were these same moneys. The statement from the Department explained what was going on at the National Exhibition Centre. It stated:
The Department was, at present, studying a number of possible uses for the money and expects to put a recommendation to the Minister soon.

Subsequent to that, I do not know what happened to the proposals being considered by the Department. But what happened next was that the House of Assembly was invited to consider the spending of this money. It was 7 October 1983 before the Minister got around to pursuing that course, so presumably he still had the money on 2 October 1983. He asked the House of Assembly to consider the matter. It did so and it worked particularly hard. I remind the Senate that the House of Assembly members are all people who have other jobs and are not full time politicians. They have to find time to sit on committees. Twenty-nine submissions were received from sporting organisations in the Australian Capital Territory. They, too, of course, are voluntary organisations. I am sure that everybody who has ever been involved in preparing submissions of this nature knows exactly how much work is involved and how much cost is involved in putting together and preparing a submission and speaking with the committee.

Notwithstanding the volume of 29 submissions, the committee did report on 13 December 1983. It recommended that five sporting bodies should benefit by means of this money in order to upgrade their facilities to international standard. They are the National Capital Horse Trials Association, the Southern Districts Hill Climb Association, the Australian Capital Territory Water Ski Association, the Australian Capital Territory Softball Association and the Australian Capital Territory Squash Racquets Association. It was not unreasonable to expect that the Minister, having asked the House of Assembly for its recommendations, would accept the recommendations and that very early in this year those sporting bodies would be able to go ahead with the necessary developments which would enable them to have international sporting facilities in this Territory.

A report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure was tabled in November 1983 which suggested that this money should not be spent in the Australian Capital Territory. Recommendation No. 25 stated:
The ACT should not be eligible for assistance under the present or expanded ISSF program while major construction work at the National Sports Centre is in progress.

I could not disagree more with that recommendation. It discriminates against the Australian Capital Territory in favour of the States. No justifiable reason was given for that in the report, but it was a report to the Government which the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) was bound to notice. However, the Minister for Territories and Local Government, in my opinion, ought to have had some regard for the welfare of the Territory with which he was involved and he should have done something about seeing that this money was not lost to the Territory. That report was tabled in November, only a short time after he had asked the House of Assembly to consider the expenditure of the money. It reported to him in December. To my knowledge nothing has been heard from him.

I received a letter from the chairman of the committee involved at the end of November in which he assured me that the $2m was still available. The matter has proceeded into this year, with the sporting bodies concerned not getting any answer and not knowing where they stood. The Australian Capital Territory Water Ski Association will hold the national championships on the Molonglo River early next year. The facilities, as far as the water is concerned, are excellent for water skiing. The facilities on the bank for spectators and in every other respect are very poor. A great deal of money is not needed to improve the facilities to a good standard. What it would have received from this fund would have enabled it to do so-to put in adequate ramps for the boats to go in, to put in a properly pegged jump board, to have electricity connected to the site and to have toilets installed. It is not very much but it would make a great difference to the way it is able to conduct the sport.

I sent telegrams to both Ministers on 10 April asking what was to happen to the money. I also put out a Press statement raising the issues that seemed to be relevant at the time. I received a letter from the office of the Minister for Territories and Local Government dated 18 April in which his staff assured me that the Minister had my telegram, that he had noted my comments and would write as soon as possible. I have had no response from the other Minister.

However, on 5 April this year, the Minister tabled a statement, from which it was clear that he knew that he had received this other report. He refers to it as covering a diffuse and complex area. He also notes that there are matters relevant to other departments, and that consultation with these Ministers and departments is required, and he, in a sense, is explaining why it is that he was not able to give a government response in early March. I wonder what consultations he had with the Minister for Territories and Local Government, and to what extent that Minister pushed the case of the Australian Capital Territory having these funds and being spent in accordance with the recommendations that had been given to him and not just taken away.

But it seems that the money has gone, and I wonder where it has gone, who has got it, and why. That fact emerges from an article in the Canberra Times of 29 April 1984. I had inquiries made today of the office of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism as to what Press statements he had put out about this, and was told that he had not put out a Press statement and that his comments were made to a journalist. I want to refer to some of the remarks as reported. The article starts by saying:
The ACT will not receive the $2 million-half from the Federal Government and half from the National Capital Development Commission-for provision of international-standard sporting facilities.
Sporting organisations in the ACT will be disappointed--
to say the least-

at this announcement by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr Brown , especially in light of the involvement by the ACT House of Assembly in considering 29 proposals and making relevant recommendations during October and November and again this month when it brought pressure to bear on the Minister for Territories and Local Government, Mr Uren, to make a decision.
Mr Brown said time had run out for the ACT and for that matter--
there is reference to the balance of some funds under this scheme-
South Australia and Western Australia . . . He had wound up this fund in order to establish a similar fund in the forthcoming Budget and had advised Mr Uren accordingly.
I should like to know what the Minister for Territories and Local Government has done about this during all this time that he has had. Going on, the article states:
Mr Brown spoke:
Of the ACT's $1 million share of the grant for international-standard sports facilities.
'There is no money. The present scheme has been cut off: it is finished, no longer available. They can apply next year'.

It was not anything that we applied for in the first place; it was a grant that was given to the Australian Capital Territory that he, presumably on a whim of his own, has taken back. The article says that Mr Brown said:
'I wrote to Mr Uren telling him what I proposed to do'.
I should like to know when that took place and what the date of the letter is. The article states that Mr Brown said:
'I'm trying to get a new one (fund) in the next Budget. There is no way I could get another one in while I had this one hanging around my neck'.

I think that those words and expressions will tell honourable senators a little about the way that Mr Brown regards the Australian Capital Territory. According to the article, Mr Brown said that we had not put up a solid proposition. I would wonder why that was so, given the fact that, in November, the Minister had asked the House of Assembly for a proposal which was available in December. There is no reason why there should not have been a proposal and why this money should not have been allocated. The article states that Mr Brown said:

'I'd say Canberra is the best provided city in Australia, the best provided community in Australia, not just for top-class facilities but the average facilities, the hockey fields, football fields, public gardens-just superb'.

In the article, Mr Brown deals also with the Australian Institute of Sport. No one is doubting that that is a very fine facility, but it does not belong to the people of Canberra. It is what its title says-an Australian institute of sport. We are certainly proud of it, but there is no way that it is available just to our athletes. In any event, the sporting bodies that were to receive this money were the groups which have no relationship with the Institute of Sport and no similar facilities of an international standard of competition at the Institute of Sport. They are local bodies which would be able then to compete to hold international sporting events in Canberra. Also, bringing tourists to Canberra is one of the most important things for our economy, and big sporting events are very high amongst the things that bring a lot of people to Canberra. To have five more groups which would have brought such large numbers of people here, holding these big events, was very important to our tourist industry. Considering what happened to the tourist budget last year, under the 1983 Budget , when we got not a cent more than we did the previous year for the promotion of tourism, it really makes me wonder whether anyone is caring what happens in the Australian Capital Territory. In the article the Minister went on to say:
'I'm hard-pressed to find a facility we lack here . . .

They have been stated and identified by the five groups which were to share in this $2m. What has the Minister done with the money? Why can it not still be available? Why are we being victimised in this way by one or other of two Ministers not giving any care or attention to these matters in regard to the Australian Capital Territory. I should like to know the answers to some of the matters that I have raised this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to raise a couple of matters on the adjournment this evening. One of the reasons that they have to be raised on the adjournment is that these days it seems fairly difficult to get answered the number of questions that used to be answered. Once upon a time every honourable senator in this chamber used to get a reply to about one question per day, but that seems to have gone by the board over the last few months. That has been to the detriment of the Senate.
—Oh!

—The Minister at the table is one of those who speaks at much too great a length in reply to some questions. Some of his replies are just filibusters, although I must admit that, in his replies, he gives a lot of information that is very forthright and honest, but the fact is that it should be done by way of ministerial statement rather than replying to a question.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it was a couple of years ago when Senator Chaney was a Minister in this place representing the then Minister for Communications that he said that my mother had been frightened by a telephone-perhaps whilst I was in gestation. So tonight I shall perhaps add to that rumour by talking once more about phones. This is brought about for two reasons. Recently in Hobart there was a convention at the new convention centre at Wrest Point, which is very important to our tourist industry. As Senator Reid has just said, tourism is very important to Canberra. So tourism is very important to Tasmania. Anything that makes matters more difficult for tourists or gives them the impression that they are not being looked after in the way in which I would want them to be looked after in Tasmania is something against which I take this opportunity to speak out. Although this might seem a fairly simple matter, it is something that must be drawn to the attention of Telecom Australia at this stage.

Over the years, I have tried to point out to the members of the Senate and to the public that there are not nearly the number of public telephones in this country that there should be. When one compares Australia with a place such as the United States of America, I would say that we have perhaps one-twentieth of the number of telephones in city areas such as Sydney as does the United States. That may not be an accurate comparison; it is just by my observation. But certainly the number of public telephones, or pay phones as they are called, that seem to be available, and easily available in big cities in the United States, is way in excess of what it is here. There are certainly not enough public phones in this country.

We are now seeing Telecom unwittingly embarking upon a course that will make the number of telephones available to a lot of people who rely on pay phones even less than it is now. We are now seeing the introduction of a very good telephone, called the gold phone. There was an advertisement in one of the newspapers this morning. It was inserted by Telecom. At the bottom of it, it says 'Gold phone-no one knows more about phones than we do'. That must have been written by an advertising agent, because it is my belief that some of the Telecom personnel are becoming out of touch with reality with regard to what people want with telephones. I would hesitate to say that they are out of touch because I believe that so many of the top personnel in Telecom who may make decisions about telephones have free phones. They do not realise how important a public telephone is to those people who live in areas where the average income is not as high as it might be in the areas where they live and perhaps where a lot of members of parliament live.

As I have said, the gold phone at first sight appears to me to be very good, but it has several weaknesses. They are all weaknesses that I believed can be changed if Telecom thinks about it. It is a good telephone in that it accepts 10c, 20c and 50c pieces. I hope that it can be easily modified to accept the $1 coin when it becomes available. However, the pulses that it receives are based upon 20c pulses. If somebody puts in a 50c coin because it is the only coin that he has he does not get 50c worth of call; he gets only 40c worth of call, which is not all that important. Why should Telecom or the people who are operating that phone get 1c profit, let alone 20 per cent more than they deserve? It would not be very difficult for phones of this type to be pulsed so that they operated not in 20c units but in 10c units.

For the benefit of the Senate, what happens is that the period of conversation is determined according to the rate of what is chargeable for local calls, subscriber trunk dialling calls or international subscriber dialling calls. A pulse is sent down the line which switches the phone on or off depending on whether or not there is any money in it. If it is a 20c pulse somebody who thinks he will get 2 1/2 times a 20c call for his 50c will be making an error. I do not think this is robbing the public, but a few years ago 10c was all that a person had to pay for any local telephone call. Even these days, when the value of money has gone down over the years, it is still something to which I do not think the owner or renter of that call box is entitled.

In some areas of Australia it is impossible to get through to the exchange on a gold telephone. That was the case recently at a convention centre in Hobart where there were people from virtually all over the world. Many of them had a credit card which I imagine Telecom wants to issue. However, they could not get through to the exchange to make either a reverse charge call or to use the credit card that had been issued. Those of us who are away from our offices and have need occasionally to use public phones will recognise that it is important to be able to get through to the exchange so that the call can be connected. Until recently, except on some of the red phones, that has not been possible either. This is different.

We are now moving into an area where I think a lot of the red phones will be replaced by gold ones. I believe the gold phones will become very popular. They are good, as I said a moment ago, in most of their attributes, but as they become more popular the number of green phones or ordinary public phones available will be fewer. Telecom has the attitude that unless a particular telephone would get a certain amount of money, on no account would it be installed. As gold phones on which one can make STD and ISD calls become available in restaurants and places of that kind the number of real public phones that have nearly all of the facilities that should be available in a public phone will be fewer and, I think, that is going the wrong way.

In this country we seem to be moving toward a time when the numbers of credit cards of one kind or another are on the increase. To remove from use by credit card holders a huge number of public telephones over the next few years I believe is very much a step in the wrong direction. If a person wants to phone home to get some money sent to him for some reason or another-he may have lost his wallet or something of that nature-he may have very few coins but he cannot even quickly dial his home and say: 'Can you ring me back on this number?'. As I understand it, the number that is printed on any public phone is not the actual number which if dialled will connect the caller. I believe there is a list at the exchange that has a cross-reference to those telephones. However, places such as England do have public phones which, if the number is dialled, connect the caller. I have had the opportunity to speak to people in England who have called me from a public telephone box and asked me to ring that number back. I believe that system should apply here. I can see absolutely no reason why, if we are going to use this system where gold phones will become quite extensive throughout the community, we cannot have that kind of system.

Gold phones are good because they have a decent push button system. They do not have a redial; I think they should have. They should certainly have the facilities that I have just mentioned. They should be pulsed so that they operate on 10c pulses; they should accept $1 coins when they become available; they should have the actual phone numbers printed on the outside and they should be made available for reverse charge and credit card calls. As I understand it, at the moment in most cases none of those facilities are available.

I have tried dialling 0176 on several of these phones. It is the usual number that one uses in a public phone to get through to make a long distance call. In different States they seem to work, but they certainly do not work at the casino in Tasmania and they do not work in certain other areas where I have tried them. However, it is my belief that any telephone that takes money should have as many services available as is possible. Why are we limiting these services instead of making them as extensive as possible? I know that the difference between a red phone or a gold phone and a green phone is that the red and gold phones are hired by people for use in their premises. However, I think it should be a rule of Telecom that the people who want to install a red or gold phone have to make these other facilities available for the community of Australia. As I said earlier, a lot of people rely on pay phones. As more gold phones become available I believe that the number of green phones will decrease even way below their already low number, and that is something that I believe Telecom should and most probably will look at in the near future.

One other matter I would like to deal with this evening relates to something I have mentioned in the Senate on other occasions; that is, the size of the coins that we use. We are just about to see the start of the use of a $1 coin. I am not blaming this Government at all. This is not a political matter. It is a practical matter. It is time that the whole coin system of this country was looked at once again. There seems to be no reason why we cannot get by now with just a 1c coin, a 5c coin, a 10c coin, a 25c coin and a $1 coin. I am sure there are some people here tonight who would say that is a pretty good system of money that is used in other areas of the world. Not only should we get by with those denominations, but we should also reduce the size of the coins that we have at the moment. I am not sure if honourable senators collect as many coins in a day as I do. I tend to put them in one pocket and quite often at the end of the day one side of my suit ends up looking longer than the other side.

I believe the size of our coins is outdated. It is a carryover from when we had coins that were a copy of the English size. It is time that they were all made smaller. Perhaps the 1c coin is all right, but all the others are ridiculously large. An inordinate amount of metal is being used. I ask the Government once more to consider this matter of changing the size and the value of some of the coins that are used in this country. We have at last got round to a $1 coin. This is about 10 years after I first started asking for a $1 coin in this place. With inflation it is time we started looking now at a $5 or even a $10 coin. I would like to see a $5 coin if it can be produced soon and a $10 coin from a government of whichever flavour. The Government has already produced the $1 coin and should now move to the next size up. This is obviously what we need in this country.
Senate adjourned at 11.03 p.m.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will STD services be available to remote rural property owners in all States and Territories of the Commonwealth at normal subscriber costs after the positioning in space of the communications satellite.

(2) Will rural landowners be required to set up and maintain at their own expense the necessary radio reception dishes; if so, what is the estimated cost of this equipment when the satellite becomes functional.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Telecom's rural and remote areas program which has been developed to provide automatic STD telephone services to people in these areas is expected to be largely completed by 1990. Telecom plans to provide these services in the remote areas mainly by utilising the terrestrial digital radio concentrator system (DRCS) commencing in 1984. The connection fees payable under Telecom's rural fees policy would apply for services provided by the use of the DRCS.

Telecom has not yet developed customer charges for the provision of telephone services via the satellite. However, because of the very high costs involved it sees the primary market for satellite telephone services in remote areas being for commercial ventures such as mining sites, exploration sites and tourist developments but services may be provided also to smaller communities and landowners. The installed costs of a remote rural station and associated terminal equipment required to provide service begin at an amount of $60,000. To this must be added annual costs for the use of the satellite transponder, the main rural station and special exchange equipment. Telecom has advised that the charges for services provided by the satellite system, including contributions to the connection costs will take into account the much higher costs of the satellite system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What tax benefits are available to religions, in view of the High Court decision which proclaimed that the Church of Scientology was a religion and was therefore entitled to exemption from payroll tax.
(2) Which religions are currently eligible for tax benefits.
(3) What is the estimated amount of revenue forgone from tax benefits available to these religions.
(4) What proportion of these tax benefits are related to the charitable activities as opposed to the religious activities in each religion.
(5) Would it be practicable to separate, for tax concession purposes, the charitable activities of a religious body from its other activities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Income Tax Assessment Act exempts from income tax income derived by a religious institution. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act exempts from sales tax equipment for use in churches and church services and articles for use in religious devotion. The Pay-roll Tax (Territories) Assessment Act exempts from pay-roll tax wages paid by religious institutions. The Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Act exempts from stamp duty documents signed by religious institutions. The Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Act exempts religious institutions from bank account debits tax.
(2) All institutions or bodies which meet the legally accepted tests for a religion and, where applicable, fulfil other legislative criteria would be eligible for the tax benefits above.

(3) and (4) Because, for example, income tax returns are not lodged by tax- exempt religious institutions, information which would enable a reliable estimate to be made of the revenue forgone by the exemptions is not available.

(5) I believe there would be considerable practical difficulty in separating the charitable activities of a religious body from its other activities. Legally , the advancement of religion is a charitable activity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details on a State by State and Territory basis of those prisoners who were released on licence during 1981, 1982 and 1983, including in each case, the name of the prisoner, the prisoner's total sentence and the duration of the sentence which had expired at the time of release, in relation to prisoners who were serving sentences for offences against Federal legislation .

(2) What was the average percentage of time of total sentence which had been served before the release of the prisoners mentioned in (1) for each State and Territory and for Australia as a whole, over the period 1981 to 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Information in the form sought in the honourable member's question is not readily available. Administratively it would not be practical to undertake the research necessary to provide the information sought. Furthermore, even if the information was available, on the grounds of privacy, I do not consider that it would be appropriate to provide the information sought in the form requested. However, the following general information is provided:

(a) A Federal offender may be conditionally released, either on parole under section 5 of the Commonwealth Prisoners Act 1967 or, on licence under section 19A of the Crimes Act 1914. Section 4 of the Commonwealth Prisoners Act provides that where a court sentences a Federal offender to a term of imprisonment and the law of the State where the offender is convicted requires a court of the State when sentencing a State offender to a like term of imprisonment, to fix a non-parole period, the court is required to fix a non-parole period in the case of a Federal offender. Where such an order is made by the court a prisoner may be released on parole under section 5 of the Commonwealth Prisoners Act 1967 at the expiration of his non-parole period by the Governor-General acting on my advice.

(b) In the case of Federal offenders sentenced in Queensland, for example, section 4 of the Commonwealth Prisoners Act does not apply as non-parole periods are automatically determined by legislation rather than by the court order. Under the relevant Queensland law a State offender, who is serving a sentence greater than 6 months is considered for release on parole at the expiration of half the head sentence without remission. While Federal offenders in Queensland cannot therefore be released on parole, as the Court has not determined the non- parole period, Federal offenders are considered for release on licence under section 19A of the Crimes Act 1914 at the same time that a State offender serving a similar sentence would be considered for release on State parole. In addition in Queensland a court may make a recommendation as to the period a prisoner should serve before being eligible for consideration for release and where such a recommendation is made I am guided by it. Thus a Federal offender in Queensland is treated in a similar way to his State counterpart.

(c) Federal prisoners in other jurisdictions are only released on licence in limited circumstances for example where they are deportees, where the court, because of technical legal requirements of the Commonwealth Prisoners Act, has failed to validly specify a non-parole period or where a prisoner has established exceptional circumstances and is being released prior to the expiration of his non-parole period. Only on rare occasions are prisoners released prior to the expiration of their non-parole periods. Prisoners released on parole or licence are required to comply with similar conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a procedure for selection of accommodation for Australian officials, including parliamentarians, visiting overseas countries.
(2) Who is responsible for such selection.
(3) How is such selection made.
(4) Do officers have to visit overseas posts in order to develop the selection process.
(5) What is the salary and status of persons involved in this selection process .
(6) What has been the cost to revenue for overseas trips of these persons whilst they are conducting this accommodation selection process in each of the last four years.

(7) Will the Government review this selection process in view of the costs involved and in view of the fact that persons going overseas would often appreciate being accommodated in hotels that are more accessible to local communities and are more reflective of the communities and their cultural backgrounds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1, 2 and 3) Accommodation for Australian officials, including parliamentarians , visiting overseas countries is normally selected by the appropriate Australian Government overseas post in accordance with the accommodation requirements and itinerary of the traveller in question. In those cases where the traveller expresses no preference regarding accommodation, the post would make a selection based on local knowledge, and take into consideration the travel allowance of the visitor, the standards of facilities available, their cost, their proximity to venues to be visited and security aspects. Many posts have negotiated favourable tariff agreements with local hotels and it is to these hotels that the majority of official travellers would be directed.

(4, 5 and 6) No overseas visits are made by officials specifically to develop this selection process. However information on costs and standard of hotels in overseas countries is forwarded to Australia by posts to facilitate regular reviews of travelling allowance rates for public servants. In addition, all posts are visited by inspectors of the Public Service Board during the course of a cyclical inspection program. During these visits, which involve a wide ranging review of allowances and other conditions of service, the opportunity is taken to review the appropriateness of the standard of hotels used for travelling allowance purposes. The Board's inspectors who undertake this work are classified at Class 8, Class 9 and Class 11 in the clerical/administrative pay group.

(7) The Government does not plan to alter the existing procedure for the making of accommodation arrangements. Under the present system it is, of course, open to parliamentarians travelling overseas to inform the Department of Foreign Affairs in Canberra, or the relevant post, of the type and location of the accommodation they wish to use.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice , on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have allegations concerning the handling of repatriation claims from Mr M. Boland been drawn to the attention of the Prime Minister; if so, what investigations have been undertaken in relation to these allegations.
(2) Has the Repatriation Commission investigated a medical report on this case which is claimed to contravene section 53 of the Repatriation Act.
(3) Has the Department of Veterans' Affairs fulfilled its statutory obligations under the provisions of sub-section 24AB (1) of the Repatriation Act with regard to this case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The allegations were referred to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

(2) The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has advised me as follows: A challenge to the veracity of a medical report in Mr Boland's case has been investigated by the Repatriation Commission and by the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The report was received by the Department from a psychiatrist in private practice who expressed his professional opinion following treatment of Mr Boland. The Ombudsman has declined to investigate this matter further, indicating that it would serve no useful purpose. No breach of section 53 of the Repatriation Act, which relates to the making and furnishing of false statements, has been established. At Mr Boland's request, a copy of the report on Mr Boland's file has been noted to indicate the complaints which Mr Boland has lodged in respect of it. No further action is warranted.

(3) The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has advised me as follows: Section 24AB of the Repatriation Act requires the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs to investigate matters to which a claim relates, although it does not specify the manner or extent of those investigations. The Ombudsman's recent investigations did not establish that a breach of section 24AB had occurred.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has any amount been spent under Division 312 Special Fund for Expenditure in relation to Government programs at the direction of the Minister for Finance by the Department of Veterans' Affairs; if so, how much and what are the details of those expenditures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: To date, no funds have been issued to my Department by the Minister for Finance from Division 312 and thus no actual expenditure of such funds has been incurred .

However, the Department of Finance has advised that, pursuant to Section 7 of the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84, any funds issued from Division 312 will be charged to normal departmental appropriations, the effect being to augment those appropriations.

As the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has approved additional staffing for my Department in respect of the income/assets test, the Department of Finance has approved additional levels of obligation of $1.8m up to which my Department can commit additional expenditure against the normal appropriations. Allocations for proposed asset testing are now under review.

Expenditure incurred to date in respect of the proposed assets test has been met from the Department's normal appropriations. As at 23 February 1984 expenditure recorded against normal departmental appropriations items was approximately $0.94m, comprising $0.74m for salaries and $0.2m for administrative expenses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Defence involve itself in security clearances of civilians in State administrations involved in key installations or otherwise; if so, what is the degree of such interest.
(2) Will the Minister for Defence revise his answer to my Question on Notice No . 577 in view of the answer to the above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) State authorities are responsible for ensuring that Commonwealth classified information in their own organisations is safeguarded, and for arranging security measures, as necessary. The Department of Defence has in the past acted as a channel for arranging clearance of people nominated by State authorities in respect of installations of importance to defence, but on those occasions did not itself determine whether or not there should be access to classified material.

The Department of Defence currently has an industrial security program, which allows for employees of State instrumentalities to be cleared for access to security classified information if necessary. For example, in 1980 20 employees of the State Dockyard Newcastle-a New South Wales State Government instrumentality-were cleared so that they could work on naval vessels.
(2) Question No. 577 sought information in respect of the Defence Force. The activities mentioned in (1) above are or were carried out by Department of Defence civilians.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware of a recent report of the International Atomic Energy Agency on the state of the uranium industry, reported in the Australian Financial Review on 28 February 1984.

(2) Does the report state that a continued fall in production combined with existing huge stockpiles of uranium mean that new supplies are unlikely to be needed at least until the turn of the century.
(3) Does the report cast doubt on the viability of the planned Olympic Dam project.

(4) Has the Federal Government made an economic assessment of the proposed uranium mine at Roxby Downs in South Australia; if so, can the Minister provide information indicating the viability or otherwise of the Olympic Dam project in South Australia; if not, will the Government initiate an assessment of the economic viability of the project in view of this recent report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) If Senator Bolkus is referring to the joint publication by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Nuclear Energy Agency and the International Atomic Energy Agency titled 'Uranium-Resources, Production and Demand', yes.

(2) No. The joint report by the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency and International Atomic Energy Agency states that: 'A comparison between short term production capability and reactor requirements indicates that the production from existing and committed facilities could continue to cover reactor requirements until the end of this decade.' The report also examines the level of stockpiles held by utilities and states that: 'the need for new production facilities could be delayed if utilities draw down their stocks, or even slightly advanced if a high forward coverage is maintained.'

(4) No. The question of the commercial feasibility of development of the Olympic Dam project at Roxby Downs is one for the joint venturers. It will depend on their assessment of the future market for copper, as well as uranium. The Government has decided that if a commercial decision to proceed with the development of the Olympic Dam project were to be made by the joint venturers, the Government would permit the export of uranium produced from that mine, subject to the safeguards arrangements applied generally to uranium exports at the time of export.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1643) Senator Jessop asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the public has been deceived as a result of the Budget undertaking that broadcast teletext decoding devices and similar equipment for the deaf would be exempt from sales tax? Does the Minister appreciate that 10 per cent of the Australian community has a hearing loss? Did the Government realise, when the decision was made to back down on the Budget promise and restrict this sales tax exemption to the estimated one per cent of the community that is regarded as profoundly deaf, that a majority of these people would be disadvantaged? It would be interesting also to know what criteria are laid down to define the term 'profoundly deaf'. In view of yet another broken promise and the fact that this represents a relatively small cost to revenue, will the Minister ask his colleague to review the decision in order to assist 10 per cent of Australians who have a significant hearing loss and would wish to take advantage of such devices?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I completely reject the claim that the public has been deceived in relation to the sales tax exemption announced in the 1983 Budget for broadcast teletext decoding equipment and similar equipment for use by deaf persons. The Government undertook in the Budget to provide exemption for videotext, teletext and other comparable equipment of a kind used in or in connexion with television receivers where the system or device is for use and not for sale by profoundly deaf persons.

There has been no backing down by the Government on its Budget undertaking. Item 123A has been inserted in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act to exempt relevant equipment where it is for use and not for sale by a person whose hearing has been certified by the Director- General of Health, or by one of his officers, to be impaired to such an extent that the person is, or is to be taken to be, profoundly deaf.

It may be noted that the exemption is not confined to persons who are ' profoundly deaf' but also extends to persons who are relevantly certified 'to be taken to be' profoundly deaf' for the purpose of the exemption item.

The criteria to be used by the Director-General of Health in certifying the classes of persons who are 'to be taken to be profoundly deaf' is a matter for determination by the Director-General and is still under consideration by him.

However, the Director-General has indicated that the criteria will be wide enough to embrace persons whose hearing is impaired to such an extent that they have a genuine difficulty in understanding television sound at volumes tolerable to people whose hearing is not impaired.
It was never intended by the Government that the exemption would be available to persons with only slight hearing disabilities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (a) What is the estimate of tax revenue forgone from occupational superannuation, for each financial year from 1971-72 to 1981-82.
(2) How are the above estimates determined.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The information required to enable estimates to be made of the tax revenue forgone that is attributable to occupational superannuation for each of these years is not available. However, the 1983-84 Budget statements contained an estimate for 1983-84 of the net revenue forgone through retirement and other employment termination tax concessions. The net revenue forgone was estimated at $2,480m.

The estimate related to the effect on income tax revenue of the tax-free treatment of employer contributions to superannuation funds, the deduction allowed for self-employed and unsupported employees' contributions, the income tax rebate on other contributions, the exemption from tax of fund earnings and the tax treatment of 'unfunded' benefits. The net revenue forgone was arrived at after allowing for offsets for tax payable on funded pensions and on funded lump sums. In arriving at the estimate it was assumed that the tax-free employer contributions and fund earnings would otherwise have been taxed in the hands of employees at an overall marginal rate of 40 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will single people on an annual income of $6,699 and married couples on an annual income of $11,142 be exempt from paying the Medicare levy.

(2) Will postgraduate students who receive a Commonwealth postgraduate award ( CPA) be subject to the Medicare levy, whereas those who receive a university scholarship or CPA allowances for dependants will be exempt; if so, is the Minister for Health aware that postgraduates who receive an award or a scholarship are not regarded as members of the workforce for the purpose of assessing eligibility for sickness benefits.
(3) Will the Minister give an assurance that all postgraduate students who receive awards or scholarships will be exempt from the Medicare levy so as to avoid unnecessary hardship for those students.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A single person whose taxable income in 1983-84 does not exceed $6,698 and a married couple whose combined taxable incomes in 1983-84 do not exceed $11,141 will be exempt from paying the Medicare levy. The family income threshold for a couple increases by $1,100 for each dependent child or student. Where the combined taxable incomes of a couple exceed the income threshold by a marginal amount a 'shading-in' formula applies and the amount of levy payable is determined according to this formula.

(2) The Medicare levy is imposed on the taxable incomes of persons who are residents of Australia for income tax purposes. Taxable income means gross income from all sources (other than amounts which are exempted from tax), less allowable deductions such as expenses of earning income, union dues and gifts to public institutions.

Among items of income expressly exempt from tax and, it follows, from levy, are amounts received under university scholarships. Amounts received under the Commonwealth postgraduate award scheme, however, are not exempt from income tax and are subject to the levy.

As I understand the position, the 1984 annual allowance paid under the CPA scheme is $7,330 gross for a single postgraduate. At that level of taxable income a single postgraduate would pay a levy of 1 per cent in a full year. For 1983-84, levy is imposed at the rate of 0.416 per cent, reflecting the commencement of Medicare from 1 February 1984.

I also understand that additional allowances are paid under the CPA scheme in respect of a dependent spouse ($2,220) and dependent children ($520 for each child). If this constituted the only taxable income of the couple, then neither of them would have to pay the levy as their family income would not exceed their relevant family income threshold.

In regard to the eligibility of postgraduate students for sickness benefits, following representations made to the Minister for Social Security and the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, new arrangements have been introduced for the payment of benefits to students holding awards or scholarships, who through illness are temporarily unable to continue their studies. Broadly speaking, these new arrangements allow students to continue to receive their awards or scholarships provided they remain enrolled in their course and meet certain other conditions, including the provision of a medical certificate and a statement from the tertiary institution.

Where the student discontinues his or her enrolment through illness, they may be eligible for sickness benefits if they intend seeking employment on recovery, regardless of their intention to resume study in a subsequent academic year or semester. In some situations where neither the award, scholarship or sickness benefits are payable, the student may be paid a special benefit by the Department of Social Security if he or she is experiencing hardship.

(3) The question of whether recipients of a CPA can be exempted from the levy is a matter for my colleague the Treasurer. The honourable senator may care to refer this matter to him for consideration when dealing with proposals for concessional income tax treatment in the context of the annual Budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 8 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Communications been approached by the Eidsvold and District Telephone Committee in relation to what it refers to as the discriminatory charges of Telecom's Countrywide Calling; if so, are the claims made by this Committee correct, namely that most country people will face the burden of greatly increased telephone accounts, will not benefit from Countrywide Calling and will have their quality of life affected.
(2) Is this Committee's contention correct when it states that the retention of local untimed calls under the Countrywide Calling system is vitally important and essential.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes, correspondence has been received from the Eidsvold and District Telephone Committee. The Countrywide Calling scheme was introduced to help overcome the problems associated with provision of service in sparsely settled areas. The main factors involved in this development are the need-
for Telecom to proceed with its rural and remote area automatic conversion program in a timely manner;

for larger zones (to limit expenditure on zone identification equipment) which in turn will provide customers with access to a reasonable number of people at lower call charges than would have been applicable if the previous zoning principles had been applied;

to keep community access arrangements intact. Apart from local call arrangements, the community call rate (15 cents for 3 minutes) will apply to all calls within an extended zone, many of which exceed 10,000 square kilometres. This is the lowest rate which could reasonably apply throughout such huge areas.

The honourable senator may be aware that Telecom has made a number of modifications to the scheme since its introduction on 1 October 1983. For example, those subscribers still on manual exchanges in extended zones will retain local call access to their service town until the automatic conversion takes place and calls between extended zones, where the radial distance is within 25-50 km, will now be charged at the community call rate of 15 cents for 3 minutes. This was previously 30 cents for 3 minutes under Countrywide Calling. In addition, Telecom has made many changes to extended zone boundaries so that customers are given the most favourable calling conditions practicable.
In the Eidsvold area it has been practicable to restore some standard zones with the effect that untimed local calling has been retained in most instances.

Overall, the benefits of the Countrywide Calling scheme to many thousands of country subscribers, existing and potential, by way of earlier provision of improved facilities, and in some cases substantially reduced charges, are of great significance to country areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 8 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How does Telecom's Countrywide Calling system operate and what is the reason for its introduction.

(2) Is the Minister for Communications aware of problems that have arisen with the zoning of the Burnett River region and other areas in Queensland and claims by many country people that the system is 'discriminatory and unfair'.
(3) Will local calls in areas affected by this system become 'timed' calls; if so, why.
(4) Will the Minister investigate these claims to ensure that the apparent anomalies are rectified and that many country people will not be disadvantaged by the introduction of Countrywide Calling.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Countrywide Calling is a telephone zoning and call charging system which applies to the more sparsely settled areas. The scheme involves extended (or enlarged) charging zones instead of the smaller standard zones generally used throughout Australia. Apart from calls between subscribers located within 32 kilometres of their local automatic exchange (charged at the local fee rate), all calls within extended zones are charged at the community call rate (15 cents per 3 minutes day rate). Calls to adjoining zones are charged at a rate not more than the 'F' rate (60 cents per 3 minutes day rate).
The Countrywide Calling scheme was introduced to help overcome the problems associated with provision of service in sparsely settled areas. The main factors involved in this development are the need-
for Telecom to proceed with its rural and remote area automatic conversion program in a timely manner;

for larger zones (to limit expenditure on zone identification equipment) which in turn will provide customers with access to a reasonable number of people at lower call charges than would have been applicable if the previous zoning principles had been applied;

to keep community access arrangements intact. Apart from local call arrangements, the community call rate will apply to all calls within an extended zone, many of which are 10,000 square kilometres. This is the lowest rate which could reasonably apply throughout such huge areas.
(2) Yes.

(3) Yes. The overall concept of Countrywide Calling requires some standard zones to be absorbed into extended zones. In addition, the generally accepted limit for the economic provision of local call access in Australia is 32 kilometres and this principle has been introduced into automatic exchanges in extended zones. Accordingly, local call access has been affected in some areas and the charging arrangements outlined in 1 above apply.

(4) All claims concerning Countrywide Calling are thoroughly examined and the honourable senator may be aware that Telecom has made a number of modifications to the scheme since its introduction. In the Burnett River region, and indeed in a number of other areas, local call access has been restored to many customers who lost the facility.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 18 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government intend to conduct an environmental impact study on any new export licence for woodchips.

(2) Has the Tasmanian Government approached the Minister for Primary Industry to extend licences for two woodchip exporters, APPM and Forest Resources until 1988; if so, would such extensions amount to a three and two year respectively, extra licence being granted without consideration of environment impact.
(3) Has any decision been made on this request; if so, what was the decision; if not, when will a decision be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Any new proposal for the export of woodchips will be referred to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment for his views on the need for an environmental impact statement before a decision on an export licence is taken.

(2) The Tasmanian Government supported applications by Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd and H.C. Sleigh Ltd for short term extensions to 1988 (from December 1985 and June 1985/December 1986 respectively) of their existing woodchip export licences.

The Tasmanian Government believed that for the period 1984-1988 individual company-by-company environmental impact statements may be limited in value by Tasmanian Government proposals in respect of a new pulpmill development project. It was therefore proposed that a State-wide environmental impact statement be prepared in 1985 in conjunction with the resource assessment to be carried out for the pulpmill feasibility study and that the existing licences be extended to 1988. This would both enable the companies to maintain their commercial relationships with overseas buyers and facilitate a decision on any resource reallocation that would accompany a possible pulpmill project.
The matter was referred to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment for advice on the need for environmental assessment.
(3) Yes. Following detailed consultations with interested parties it was decided to approve the licence extensions.

The Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments have agreed to jointly commission a comprehensive environmental review of Tasmanian woodchipping and associated forestry operations beyond 31 December 1988. The review will allow a more detailed and comprehensive assessment across forestry operations than would have been possible if the assessment were to concentrate solely on woodchipping operations.

In view of the sensitivity of forestry operations in a number of areas, it has been agreed that it will be appropriate for the impact statement to provide comment on management practices over the period 1984-1988 and any recommendations made will be taken into account by the Governments and the companies during this period.

In broad terms the EIS will consider the long term sustainable yield of Tasmania's forests taking account of sawlog and pulpwood production from both private and Crown land. It will also consider timing of harvesting and proposed management practices by specific areas.

Following lengthy and detailed consultation with my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the Tasmanian Minister for Forests, industry representatives, relevant Departmental officers (Federal and State), representatives of the Conservation Foundation, the Australian Heritage Commission and the Tasmanian Wilderness Society, I concluded that the licences covering APPM's and H.C. Sleigh's existing operations should be extended to December 1988 subject to a number of conditions concerning pulpwood logging in areas of environmental concern, particularly those listed on the Register of the National Estate.

Pulpwood operations in the Lemonthyme State Forest in the north of Tasmania will be delayed until such time as consideration can be given to recommendations of the final impact statement. In addition the Tasmanian Government and the companies have agreed that export pulpwood operations in sensitive areas of the southern forests will be restricted to those areas that are necessary for sawlog removal. This will enable regeneration of these areas to continue and ensure sawlog is available during the period to the sawmilling companies dependent upon this resource.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 14 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated total cost, including this financial year and future financial years, of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam (see answer to Question No. 259, Hansard, 20 September 1983, p. 820).
(2) When is the Royal Commissioner now expected to report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which States and Territory governments have formal arrangements with the Federal Government for the movement of permanent officers from one public service to another while allowing those officers to have general portability of superannuation, long service leave, accruing holidays and other benefits.

(2) Will the Prime Minister ask his officers to identify which State and Territory governments have general portability arrangements with other State and Territory governments, to assist in community understanding of the matter.
(3) Are the arrangements in each case based on legislation, intergovernmental administrative action or some other form and is there a one way flow or a two way flow in each case.
(4) What are the general provisions of each set of arrangements.
(5) Is there a portability arrangement between the public services of the Federal and Queensland governments.

(6) What would prevent the exercise of portability by an officer with a good performance record, transferring to a permanent position in the Queensland Public Service from the Commonwealth Public Service after 20 years excellent service in the latter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are not formal arrangements between the Commonwealth Government and State and Territory governments for the general portability of benefits of permanent officers who move from one public service to another. However, there is provision in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme for the preservation of portability of superannuation rights, in certain circumstances, of persons moving between Commonwealth employment and other employment, including employment with a State or Territory.

On entry to the Commonwealth scheme, a new contributor may pay into the scheme a lump sum received from the superannuation scheme of a previous employer. The employer-financed component of the lump sum is used to 'purchase' a period of contributory service that is added to the employee's actual period of contributory service under the Commonwealth scheme. Employer-financed benefits under the Commonwealth scheme are determined on the basis of length of contributory service, salary and age at retirement. The employee-financed component of a lump sum, or a lump sum that comprises only employee contributions, is paid into the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund and treated as contributions by the employee.
Where a person leaves the Commonwealth scheme, preservation may be effected by means of:
(a) the payment of a transfer value-a lump sum that includes an employer component-to an approved superannuation scheme; or
(b) where the person does not become a member of an approved scheme, a deferred benefit-generally a pension payable on age retirement, invalidity or death.

An approved scheme is one where the new employer has agreed to a reciprocal arrangement with the Commonwealth involving the payment of transfer values between schemes. There are reciprocal preservation arrangements between the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and 22 other public sector schemes-including 16 State university schemes-that enable the payment of transfer values between the Commonwealth scheme and those other schemes. As no State government has so far been willing to enter into such arrangements, a transfer value is not payable in respect of contributors who elect to preserve their Commonwealth superannuation rights on transfer to State employment. However, negotiations are currently proceeding with Queensland on the introduction of reciprocal portability arrangements between the Commonwealth scheme and the principle Queensland public service scheme and certain other Queensland schemes.

The position of individual transferring between Commonwealth and Northern Territory government employment is different, however. Employees of the Northern Territory Government currently contribute to the Commonwealth scheme and individuals transferring between Commonwealth and Northern Territory employment remain members of that scheme. Their accrued superannuation rights are, therefore, fully preserved.

In regard to other benefits, when officers of a State or the Northern Territory Public Service join the Australian Public Service (APS), their prior service with those Public Services is counted as if it had been service with the Commonwealth for the purposes of sick leave and long service leave, subject to continuity being maintained-that is a break in service not exceeding two months in the case of sick leave; 12 months in the case of long service leave. Prior service is not recognised for any other purpose.
Provisions applicable to officers of the APS when they join the Northern Territory or State public services are the responsibility of each of those public services.
The Australian Public Service Board does not hold information on these provisions.
(2) The Australian Public Service Board does not hold information on portability arrangements between State and Territory governments.

(3) The preservation arrangements applicable under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme are provided for in the Superannuation Act 1976. The recognition of prior service with the Northern Territory or State public services for the purposes of sick leave and long service leave in the APS is provided for in the Public Service Act 1922 and the Long Service Leave ( Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976, respectively.
(4) See (1) above.

(5) No. The provisions outlined in (1) apply to officers of the Queensland Government who are appointed to the APS. The Australian Public Service Board does not hold information on portability of benefits for officers of the APS who are appointed to the Queensland Public Service.
(6) See (5) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that a Postillion Landau identical to the Edward VII 1902 Postillion Landau has been constructed in Australia by Mr Jim Frecklington.

(2) Will the Minister look into the possibility of this work of art being acquired by an appropriate institution so as to retain it in Australia for the benefit of all Australians as a national work of art.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I am advised however that, although Mr Frecklington's Landau may be identical in appearance to the Edward VII 1902 Postillion Landau, different materials have been used in its construction.

(2) The Landau is not an appropriate acquisition for the relevant national collecting institutions for which I have responsibility. As the Landau represents an era that is not part of Australia's history, it is inappropriate for inclusion in the Museum of Australia's collection. The Landau does not come within the collections policy of the Australian National Gallery.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Why did the Mount Alvernia Hospital, Bendigo, receive a B classification instead of an A classification under the Medicare program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Mount Alvernia Hospital, Bendigo was initially classified as a Category 2 hospital under Medicare because Commonwealth Department of Health claims data for the year ended 30 June 1983 indicated that the hospital did not fulfil all of the Category 1 criteria. Specifically, the hospital had fewer than the required average number of daily inpatients.

Mount Alvernia submitted that if figures for compensable patients, of which the Department had no record, were taken into account, it would fulfil all the criteria for Category 1. Once this position was confirmed, I reclassified the hospital to Category 1 with effect from 1 February 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

ANSWER.PARA: The following reports of royal commissions, task forces and like investigative bodies dealt either primarily or incidentally with organised crime in Australia:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the magistrate presiding over the Greek social security conspiracy case announce he was going to bring the circumstances of actions by a senior police officer to the notice of the Attorney-General with a view to proceedings being taken.
(2) Has advice been forwarded to the Attorney-General by the magistrate.
(3) What action has the Attorney-General taken as a consequence thereof; if the decision has not been taken, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) I have not received formal advice but have treated the magistrate's public announcement as advice to me.

(3) The evidence given before the magistrate has been closely examined and the advice of counsel has been obtained on a number of questions which arose. On 31 January 1984 the Minister for Social Security and I issued a statement which contained the following paragraphs:

'The Attorney-General has had regard to the comments made by the Magistrate, Mr B. Brown, S.M., on 7 June 1982 concerning former Detective Chief Inspector Thomas, and has decided that no charges should be laid.'

'In the view of the Attorney-General, the evidence currently available to support the charges suggested by the Magistrate is not sufficient to establish the mental element of those offences to the requisite standard of proof and, in all the circumstances of the case, he has decided that the interests of justice would not be served by now instituting criminal proceedings against Mr Thomas.'
'This decision would of course be reviewed if additional relevant material was to become available.'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why were the promises not fulfilled that time would be put aside to consult with those persons or organisations such as the Northern Territory Government, who forwarded submissions particularly in regard to the proposed new rail link between Alice Springs and Darwin to the Hill Report on the Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory (NT).
(2) When will the Government indicate its attitude to the defence aspect of the rail project, which was excluded from the inquiry.

(3) Does the Government agree with the report when it is suggested that the upgrading of the Stuart Highway in the NT does not require accelerated funding to bring it to national highway standards by 1987.
(4) If the Minister for Transport does not have this information at hand will he expedite the answers for the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory, conducted by Mr David Hill, held public hearings at Darwin, Alice Springs and Adelaide, at which parties were invited to elaborate on and discuss their written submissions. Officials of the Northern Territory and South Australian Governments provided the inquiry with clarifications and additional information on their respective governments' submissions.

(2) The inquiry was not required to evaluate the defence implications of proposed transport services to the Northern Territory. The Government has undertaken a separate assessment of the defence implications. It is of the view that a decision now to divert defence expenditure from projects having priority in terms of endorsed planning criteria to the proposed infrastructure work on the railway, would, other factors remaining constant, reduce the level of defence preparedness we could otherwise achieve. This was advised to the Northern Territory Chief Minister and South Australian Premier when they met with the Prime Minister on 15 March 1984 to discuss the Hill inquiry report and to determine the best way of meeting the Territory's future transport needs.
(3) The Hill report does not suggest that the Stuart Highway can be brought up to national highway standard by 1987 without accelerated funding.

The report indicates that the present program of upgrading will bring the Highway to a minimum national highway standard by 1992 at a cost of $72.8m. To bring the Highway to this standard by 1987 would require additional expenditure of $25.3m over the four years to 1987 and an equivalent reduction in planned expenditure over the following six years.
(4) Not applicable.
