QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has there been an increase in the number of arrests of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory since the introduction of the Criminal Code; if so, are figures available and what do they indicate.
(2) Does the Northern Territory Criminal Code infringe obligations under international treaties; if so, which treaties and in what way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The code became law on 1 January 1984. At this stage there is no evidence to suggest that the introduction of the Criminal Code has affected the number of arrests of Aboriginal persons in the Northern Territory.

(2) The Government believes that the code, as it currently stands, has serious implications for a number of civil and political rights guaranteed under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

However, as a result of an exchange of correspondence culminating in a meeting held on 15 March 1984-attended by the Prime Minister, the Chief Minister, the Northern Territory Attorney-General and myself-I was advised on 28 March 1984 that the Northern Territory Government had agreed to amend those provisions at the earliest opportunity.
The subject provisions of the code, as they currently stand, and the civil and political rights in respect of which they have ramifications are as follows:

Section 7Pursuant to this section a person who was intoxicated at the time he committed the conduct the subject of the charge is presumed, inter alia, to have foreseen the natural and probable consequences of his act and to have intended them. He bears a persuasive onus to rebut this presumption so that he has to convince the jury that he did not so foresee and intend. If he is unable to convince the jury, the Crown can succeed in obtaining a conviction by proving only that the accused did the act without having to prove the existence of the traditional and necessary mental element. The provision has implications for the concepts of a fair trial and for the presumption of innocence guaranteed by Article 14 of the Covenant.
Section 51This section enables the Administrator to make regulations proscribing any organisation which either:
(a) in the opinion of the Executive Council has as its objects the use of violence to achieve its ends, or
(b) the members of which, in the opinion of the Executive Council, have, in the Territory or elsewhere, demonstrated a propensity to use violence to achive the organisation's ends.
I emphasise that the making of the regulations proscribing the organisation are dependent on the opinion of the Executive Council as to the matters set out in the section.

The regulations may be approved by the Legislative Assembly by simple majority and there is no provision permitting an organisation either to show cause why it should not be proscribed or to have proscription judicially reviewed on the merits. The section is in very wide terms as can be seen from the exception provided in relation to registered trade unions. Drastic consequences flow from proscription in that belonging to a proscribed organisation, soliciting financial or other support for it, knowingly making or receiving contributions to it or arranging or addressing certain meetings of it are all crimes carrying two years imprisonment. The mere displaying of support for a proscribed organisation by means of dress or any other item is an offence carrying six months imprisonment.
In the absence of any requirements of natural justice and in the absence of the availability of judicial review this section has implications for the following civil and political rights:
the right to freedom of expression guaranteed by Article 19 of the Covenant,
the right to peaceful assembly guaranteed by Article 21,
the right to freedom of association guaranteed by Article 22.

Section 383This section permits a court to impose by way of fine the costs of bringing a charge, including the costs of police investigations, and the costs of the committal proceedings on a defendant who has been found not guilty in circumstances where the jury has given voluntary intoxication as the reason for the acquittal.
Pending the assessment of the amount of the fine the court can order that the acquitted person be either imprisoned or admitted to bail.

Bearing in mind the high incidence of alcohol related crime in the Northern Territory, the Government can understand the policy considerations underlying this provision. However the term 'fine' is recognised both nationally and internationally as a form of post-conviction punishment and the concept of an acquitted person being imposed or admitted to bail, in the absence of further charges outstanding against him, is alien to our legal heritage. This section in its present form has implications in relation to Article 10 of the Covenant which recognises that deprivation of liberty should arise only in respect of persons accused or convicted of criminal activity and Article 5 which preserves pre-existing fundamental human rights existing in Australia. The infliction of punishment after acquittal also has implications in relation to Article 15 of the Covenant which permits the imposition of a penalty only after a due finding of guilt of an offence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When is it expected: (a) tenders for a consultant to assist in the preliminary investigation and specification work on the proposed Australian Antarctic research vessel will close; (b) that the investigation work will be completed; (c) that the specifications will be completed; and (d) that work will begin on construction of the vessel.
(2) Will work on the vessel be carried out (a) in Australia; (b) by an Australian company; (c) overseas; or (d) by an overseas company.
(3) When is it expected that: (a) construction of the vessel will be completed; and (b) the vessel will begin operation.

(4) Will one of the duties of the vessel be to supply Australian bases in the Antarctic; if not, what is being done to replace the current supply of vessels which are now expensive to charter and limited in their availability.
(5) Is Australia's ability to support its bases in the Antarctic hampered by the lack of a suitable supply vessel.
(6) Was Australia's participation in Sibex-1 cancelled because of the unavailability of a suitable vessel.
(7) Is it the intention of the Government to make a genuine attempt to overcome the problem of supplying its Antarctic bases or is Australia's effort in this area to continue to recede.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a-d) and (2) (a-d) The Government is currently reviewing proposals for future Antarctic transport arrangements. Antarctic replacement shipping options will be reappraised in the 1984-85 Budget. No action on vessel acquisition will be taken until the proposals have been considered.
(3) (a-b) The vessel currently used for marine science research, the Nella Dan, will be withdrawn in 1987-88. Ideally, replacement shipping would be ready to commence service by mid 1988.

(4) The research vessel previously proposed as part of a system which included air transport of personnel and continued charter of cargo shipping was not intended to resupply stations. Future station resupply is most likely to be affected by ice-strengthened pure cargo ships which are readily available for long-term charter at reasonable rates. The option of air transport of personnel is still being evaluated.

(5) The resupply of bases with cargo is adequate. There is, however, a shortage of passenger berths on the present vessels and decisions must be taken annually as to the numbers of each category of station personnel to be transported (for example rebuilding staff, scientists, station support staff). Because of the combination of resupply and marine science functions, marine research must be scheduled to accommodate station resupply.
(6) Australia's participation in Sibex-1 was cancelled because resupply scheduling demands meant that sufficient sea time for marine science was not available.
(7) The Government's stated policy in Antarctica is to upgrade existing transport facilities, and to provide financial support for new research projects .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Industry and Commerce finalised its restructuring; if not, when will this be done.
(2) What part has the Minister for Industry and Commerce played in the restructuring or has this just happened by bureaucratic initiative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Most elements of the second division aspects of the proposal put to the Public Service Board have been agreed. The remaining elements are expected to be finalised by the end of April. The Board also has under consideration associated changes in the third and fourth division structures.
(2) The second division proposals were discussed with, and endorsed by me before they were put to the Board for consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what dates was the Bluff Hill Point lighthouse in Tasmania out of action .
(2) What were the causes of the outages.
(3) Would the period of outage have been reduced if the lightstation had been manned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The new light at Bluff Hill Point commenced operation on 8 December 1982. It was reported to be operating irregularly on 24 December 1982 and the fault was finally rectified on 9 January 1983. This has been the only outage of this aid.
(2) The fault was caused by false triggering of the daylight sensing switch.

(3) It is not possible to draw a meaningful comparison as this light was planned, designed and installed to operate as an automatic light. All Commonwealth marine navigational aid lights installed over the past 40 years have been automatic unattended lights.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What effect will the reported savings of $24m on the FA18 program as a result of redesigned electrical equipment racks for the strike fighter's radar have on the total project cost of Australia's order of these aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The reported savings of $US24m on the FA18 program relate to the United States Navy program and are based on 1117 radars.

The redesigned radar rack is planned to be available for incorporation in 55 of our FA18s and on that basis we will save about $A1.3m at the current exchange rate. This saving will be accounted for in the next project cost update later this financial year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any Australian Service personnel been seconded to other countries since 1960, where they would be in control of, or working with, nuclear weapons: if so, (a) how many personnel have been involved; (b) which countries were they assigned to; and (c) what periods of time were involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Personnel records readily available to Army, Navy and Air Force do not indicate that any Australian Service person seconded to another country since 1960 has been placed in a position of controlling, or working with nuclear weapons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Are there contingency plans to use Australian air bases to launch B52 bombers with nuclear weapons against the Soviet Union if war occurs between the United States and the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has no such plans.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Do President Reagan's stated plans to use nuclear waste for making nuclear weapons contravene the Australia-United States Bilateral Agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The 1979 agreement between Australia and the United States concerning peaceful uses of nuclear energy provides that Australian origin nuclear material shall be used for peaceful and non-explosive purposes only and that it shall remain subject to IAEA safeguards until it is no longer usable for any nuclear activity relevant from the point of view of safeguards.

I am not aware of any reports of plans formulated by President Reagan or his Administration which would breach the United States' firm international legal undertaking to Australia in this regard. If the honourable senator could provide the source which prompted her question I will have it investigated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How far has the charting progressed relating to Australian coastal waters.
(2) Is the charting being done entirely by the Navy. If not, what other organisations, companies or groups are involved.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the involvement of private industry in this charting work.
(4) Is the equipment being used in the charting the property of the armed forces or are some resources of private industry being utilised.
(5) Have there been any purchases of equipment which have been specifically brought about due to this survey work, if the equipment being used is the property of the armed forces.
(6) How many service personnel are involved in this duty and what ships and aircraft are being used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Twenty per cent of Australia's continental shelf has been surveyed to standards which allow modern ships to navigate with complete safety. A further 16 per cent has been surveyed with some shortcomings which will require updating at a later date. The remaining 64 per cent is incompletely surveyed and charting for these areas is based on small scale reconnaissance surveys, early lead line surveys or no data at all.

Some 620 charts are required to cover the Australian charting area fully. Of this number, 390 exist but 250 of these are still published in imperial units. Essentially then, about 480 charts have yet to be compiled from original data or converted to metric units.

(2) Publication of the Australian chart series is the responsibility of the RAN Hydrographic Service. However, the data is also obtained from Federal and State mapping authorities, State and commercial marine and port authorities an private mariners and individuals with an interest in the sea.
(3) Yes. However there are practical difficulties associated with the centralised computer data base.
(4) Equipment used in the production of the charts is the property of the Commonwealth.
(5) Yes. The types of equipment purchased are wide ranging and specialist to the task.

(6) Currently about 100 officers and sailors are employed on hydrographic duties in HMAS Moresby and HMAS Flinders, other RAN ships and establishments and the Hydrographic Office. About 85 civilians are also employed in the Hydrographic Office on chart compilation production and distribution. One Bell 206-B helicopter is deployed on HMAS Moresby for survey support tasks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 26 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the fighting between East Timorese guerillas and Indonesian troops flared because of food shortages in East Timor.
(2) Have Indonesian authorities continually denied both the presence and the prospect of such food shortages.
(3) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs in a position to indicate the true position on food supplies in East Timor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Indonesian authorities are monitoring the food situation closely and have sent additional food stocks to a number of areas. Indonesian officials have indicated on a number of occasions that they are able to handle any shortages which may arise.

(3) Our assessment, and that of a number of other observers in Jakarta, is that the food situation in the province is stable. However, localised shortages may arise from time to time due to the vagaries of weather and the problem of transporting food to isolated areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Social Security aware of the difficulties being experienced by adult Aboriginal students in the Northern Territory who are receiving Aboriginal study grants and child allowances from the Commonwealth Department of Education, but are precluded from receiving the family income supplement even though their income is below the income limit set for this supplement.
(2) Is this situation unfair on those students.

(3) Will the Minister take action to ensure that adult Aboriginal students who receive less than the income limit for the family income supplement, and are therefore eligible for this supplement, receive the payable allowances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3): The Commonwealth provides income support to eligible people through the social security program and through various other measures which include the Aboriginal study grants scheme. Where such people have children, they are entitled to an additional payment of up to $12 per week for each child, an amount equivalent to the maximum rate of assistance under the family income supplement scheme.

The relevant legislation does not permit family income supplement to be paid for any child for whom the Commonwealth is already providing income support, thus avoiding situations of dual entitlement. There is no current intention to change this situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 28 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Could the low cost uranium producers in the Northern Territory threaten the economic viability of the Roxby Downs project.

(2) Does the Minister for Resources and Energy consider that the Commonwealth Government decision to restrict Territory producers is intended in part to protect a less efficient operation at Roxby Downs.
(3) How does this attitude accord with statements by the Prime Minister regarding the need for structural change to promote efficiency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government believes that in the short to medium term the market for uranium is likely to remain depressed, and thus the two existing mines, plus the Olympic Dam project will be able to fill the space which is likely to be available in the world market for Australian uranium. The total value of mine production, the total employment generated, and the overall boost to the nation' s economic activity arising from the Olympic Dam project would be very much greater than these would be from any alternative mine producing a similar amount of uranium.
(2) No. The reasons why the Olympic Dam project was granted approval were explained in (1).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: What information is available in addition to that provided in reply to a question without notice in the House of Representatives on 1 March 1984, about the Melbourne-Adelaide railway line, specifically:
(a) proposals for upgrading or standardising the existing broad gauge line between Tailem Bend and Adelaide;
(b) whether the Tailem Bend to Adelaide railway is to be converted to a three rail operation or is to be replaced by a new standard gauge line;
(c) the costs of the options in (b);
(d) the proposed commencement date if any for operation of standard gauge trains between Adelaide and Tailem Bend and Adelaide and Melbourne; and
(e) any proposals for a completely new railway route around the Adelaide Hills to the border of South Australia and Victoria.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) An evaluation of standardising the Melbourne-Adelaide railway line is still being conducted by officers of the Victorian State Transport Authority and Australian National Railways Commission (AN). The present proposal is for a three rail operation between Tailem Bend and the Adelaide metropolitan area. Construction of a new standard gauge line parallel to the existing line or major upgrading or realignment have not been considered.
(c) An indicative cost of a third rail option between Adelaide and Tailem Bend is $17m.

(d) At this stage no firm commitment has been entered into to provide a standard gauge link between Melbourne and Adelaide. This will depend on the outcome of the study being currently undertaken and other budgetary considerations. If the project were to proceed standard gauge trains could be operational within 3 years of commencement of construction.

(e) Initial consideration was given to a number of alternative routes but the proposal for three rail operation between Adelaide and Tailem Bend and direct conversion from Tailem Bend to the Victorian border was considered the most cost effective option.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: How many women hold senior positions in the Department of Defence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The term 'senior positions' has been taken to mean those of Class 10 and above in the clerical/administrative field and their professional equivalents. There are eleven women in the Department of Defence holding such positions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps are being taken by the Government to review subsidies for charities like Meals on Wheels, which provide valuable support to the sick and elderly, thus saving millions of dollars in government support for hospitals and nursing homes.

(2) Can the Government, in view of increasing petrol costs, investigate the feasibility of providing petrol vouchers to further assist these important charities, which are often dependent on pensioner volunteers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am well aware of the problems which some delivered meals services are encountering in providing adequate services to aged or disabled people who require them.

The Government has clearly stated its commitment to the further development of home care as an alternative to institutional care. We believe it is important to give priority to community care programs for the aged and disabled which assist people to remain in their own homes for as long as possible.
The Treasurer, in his speech announcing the last Budget, referred to 'the development during 1983/84 of detailed proposals on community care'.

My Department is currently reviewing its policy and funding arrangements for all domiciliary and support services including delivered meals services. I wrote to all State Ministers last year seeking their views on ways to improve community care programs generally.

Many delivered meals organisations have written to the Department outlining their difficulties. It should be noted that in the past government subsidy has been provided as a contribution to service costs rather than to cover total costs. Some organisations cope extremely well with the subsidy provided while others suffer financial difficulties.
The points made by organisations, such as the consideration of a petrol voucher system, are being taken into account in the present review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1983 (Hansard, page 855) Senator Reynolds asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the expense of caption television decoding equipment is out of the economic reach of many deaf people? At present the commercial television networks are supporting the captioning venture but, if the deaf and hard of hearing are prevented from having access to this service for economic reasons, television stations could be in a position to use poor decoder sales as an excuse to withdraw from sponsorship of the sub- titling service. Therefore, can the Minister have investigated sales tax exemption on decoding equipment, which would help to alleviate the present situation? Furthermore, can the Minister undertake to investigate a complete review of sales tax on all technical aids used by handicapped persons in their homes?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In the deliberations preceding the 1983 Budget the Government saw the obvious benefits to the deaf of videotex equipment which enables speech and information to be reproduced in visual form on screens of television receivers or monitors designed for use with such equipment.

For this reason a new exemption item (123A) was inserted into the First Schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act for such equipment where it is for use and not for sale by a person certified by the Director-General of Health to be profoundly deaf or to be taken to be profoundly deaf.

Caption television decoding equipment is therefore currently exempt from sales tax where it is purchased for use by a person who has been certified by the Director-General of Health to have an appropriate hearing disability. Broadly, the exemption will embrace persons whose hearing is impaired to such an extent that they have a genuine difficulty in understanding television sound at volumes tolerable to people whose hearing is not impaired.

In addition to item 123A there are several items in the First Schedule to the abovementioned Act which provide exemption for a wide range of goods used by disabled persons. These exemption items include-

(i) item 42 which exempts surgical appliances such as artificial limbs, crutches, bath seats of a kind used by invalids, surgical boots, braces and irons and invalid wheel chairs including motorised invalid wheel chairs, invalid tricycles and spinal carriages;
(ii) item 42A which exempts battery-charges for use exclusively or principally in recharging batteries used in invalid wheel chairs;

(iii) item 42B which exempts medical or surgical appliances of a kind used exclusively or principally by persons suffering from sickness, disease or physical impairment for the purpose of alleviating or treating that sickness, disease or physical impairment or their effects, for example, artificial ears, hearing aids. et cetera;
(iv) item 42C which exempts goods to be used in the modification of a motor vehicle solely for the purpose of adapting it for driving by a person who is suffering from a physical impairment; and

(v) item 123 which exempts goods designed and manufactured expressly for use by persons suffering from sickness, disease or disablement being goods of a kind not ordinarily used by persons who are not suffering from sickness, disease or disablement, for example, braille machines, optacons, wheelchair transporters for carrying disabled persons up and down stairs, et cetera.

Item 123 is, in effect, a catch-all provision which provides exemption for all technical aids used by handicapped persons that the aids are designed and manufactured expressly for use by handicapped persons. Item 123, however, does not exempt general purpose goods such as typewriters, computers, sound recorders and dictation machines. Where such goods are purchased for use by handicapped persons they are taxable.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1945) Senator Watson asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is he aware that required art materials for tertiary fine arts students can cost between $1,500 and $2,000 per year and that this expense causes great hardship for students on tertiary education assistance scheme allowances? Can consideration be given to exempting art supplies required by full time arts students from sales tax as occurs for essential equipment needed in other tertiary courses?
The Treasurer has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that most art supplies are subject to sales tax at the rate of 20 per cent as are the majority of materials purchased by tertiary and other students for use in their studies. Equipment for use in tertiary courses other than fine arts is not specifically exempted from sales tax.

Goods for use and not for sale by non-profit schools and universities are conditionally exempt as are scientific instruments and scientific apparatus for use in universities and schools. Text books are exempt from sales tax.

An exemption for art supplies required by full time fine art students would entail significant administrative difficulties and the request for such an exemption is one that is appropriately considered in a Budget context. I have arranged that it be noted for such consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 March 1984 (Hansard, page 447) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the issue of receipts to patients who are claiming reimbursement from Medicare.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The reasons for the decision not to return account documents have been outlined in answers to previous questions on this matter. Although the Health Insurance Commission had introduced a number of measures to compensate claimants for the surrender of their account documents, there was still some concern about the procedures where the patient was making a claim for cash benefits. It is not correct that the matter was reviewed as a result of complaints from Medicare staff.

The details of the procedures for cash claims were announced in the House of Representatives on 7 March and appeared in most major newspapers throughout the country. The procedure is that an assessment advice will be issued on request to patients seeking cash reimbursement. The procedure was implemented in all Medicare offices by the middle of March.

It is believed that these arrangements will remove any further difficulty that people may have in surrendering their account documents to Medicare. There may be some people in the community for whom these arrangements may still be unsatisfactory and in these circumstances provision has been made for the accounts to be returned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 March 1984 (Hansard, page 789) Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice relating to the retention of account documents by Medicare.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

Regulations under Section 19 of the Health Insurance Act detail the information that must be shown on accounts to determine whether Medicare benefit is payable. The account documents play a formal part in the establishment of whether benefit is payable and few would dispute the necessity for their being surrendered to Medicare staff so that benefit can be assessed.

The signed Medicare claim form quite clearly is not sufficient for administrative and audit purposes. Medicare seeks to retain account documents in order to avoid the opportunities for account manipulation and fraud that have existed in the health insurance industry. Cases of fraudulent practices cannot be pursued without the documents that support the claim. In addition, the auditability of reimbursement to health funds where account documents have been returned was questioned by the Auditor-General in his report to Parliament in May 1983.

The Health Insurance Commission has taken a number of steps to provide claimants with information on benefits paid for tax purposes and this has now been extended by providing an assessment advice for cash payments where requested by the claimant. This form of advice was announced to Parliament on 7 March and the assessment advice forms became available, on request, in Medicare offices from about mid-March.

The Commission recognises that there may be persons in the community for whom these arrangements are unsatisfactory, and in these circumstances provision has been made for the accounts to be returned. Where this is done the benefit must be paid by cheque rather than cash so that the Commission can secure a record of claim documents before their return. Advice available to the Commission indicates that there is no legal impediment to the Commission retaining account documents.
